content.description: What differentiates Old Hong Kong Kitchen in the nosh nexus that is Novena? Untraditional lean roast pork with a layer of crackling that makes up for the lack of fat; Peking duck with a uniform cushion of fat and crisp molasses-coloured skin that detracts from the absence of the integral spring onion; and a fresh mango purée with coconut ice cream that washes the rest of the sodium-heavy fare down well.

On any given night (or morning) this coffee shop is packed to the rafters, a favourite spot to swing by for supper or post-clubbing/pre-dawn fuel. Happy and hungry punters tuck into favourites like the perfectly crisp tosai, plates of tasty nasi goreng or delicious nuggets of chicken tikka, butter chicken and prata, before finishing it all off with a super-sized Milo dinosaur or teh cino.

This family-run confectionery dates back 55 years and gives a nod to the good old days with its retro-tiled floor and antique cabinets. On a day-to day basis, their muffins (13 flavours including durian, cheese, coffee and strawberry) fly off the shelf like hotcakes, as do the fluffy, light egg tarts ($0.70 each) and chunky chicken mushroom pies ($1.30 each). But what keeps the customers coming back year after year? The old-style flaky tau sar pia and delicious wifes biscuit ($0.60 each), and the traditional Teochew pastries customary for betrothal baskets.

content.vendor-category: Well & Good | Deals of the month

content.description: From the restaurateurs of Food Republic comes Food Opera, an upmarket spin on the food court, whose 22 hawker stalls come complete with chandeliers, commissioned art, acrylic chairs and marble tabletops. Hawker fare in hoity-toity surroundings may feel contrived, but the ambience is set to match that of the equally smart new mega-mall.

In Spanish, pinchos means small bar treats, those little finger foods that friends and family typically order en masse to share and sample a lil bit of this and that. Spaniards have certainly made a name for themselves as a fun lot, and now that lively ambience is replicated in Rochester Park @ one-north in the alfresco premises of Pinchos tapas and wine bar. Check out live music sessions on Mondays, trivia on Tuesdays or magician acts on Fridays.

entry.name: Mr & Mrs Smith The Couple Store

version.name: Mr & Mrs Smith The Couple Store

content.description: Looking to spice up the bedroom antics? Head up to this newly opened adult store. Inside, products such as Sasmar’s Conceive Plus lubricant (formulated to provide optimum conditions for sperm survival) and the Endless Pleasure vibrator are bound to thrill. The store’s trump card, however, is its exclusive range of Liberator Shapes, a collection of wedges, ramps, cubes and scoops – think Lego blocks, but these are used to create the perfect platform for every sexual position you can imagine. If you’d rather not be seen walking out toting boxes and bags of goodies, the store also provides a home-delivery service for orders above $200.

Tucked away in the back corner of the old Bukit Timah Fire Station, owners Javier and Sharon have turned this hidden gem into a restaurant with soul. Starters, including ceviche with a tangy twist and crispy calamari, are the real standouts, but mains are equally outstanding. The Make Love Not Raw Burger is a solid offering and a special of succulent prawns grilled to perfection is served alongside gleaming black rice in squid ink. The piece of nori-wrapped salmon is a touch overcooked, but the sides of wasabi mash and mushrooms in white wine and balsamic vinegar make up for it. A chocolate fondant is a little underwhelming, but deep-fried cheesecake balls provide a decadent finish.

A relic of Singapores history, the words Killiney Post Office conjure up nostalgia and memories of a different era. But today, its glass walls and steel architecture offer a completely different ambience for sophisticated yuppies who desire the combination of history and modern design offered by KPO (named for its location at the junctions of Killiney, Penang and Orchard Road). The two-storey bar feels like a modern home, with comfy sofas strategically placed at the corners, and even a greenhouse on the second floor. There is a balcony where one can watch the traffic whizz by while sipping a martini, and slow ambient beats set the mood for a laidback, louche evening. Drinks are well priced, with decent promotions (Sapporo and Asahi at $7 per bottle). A wider-than-usual bar menu offers great bites try the barbecue pork ribs for a latenight snack.

Food and drinks price range: $7 to $20

While the melting pot trend the fusing of distinctive cuisines became overwhelmingly popular in the 90s, restaurants started to realise this was leading to confusion. Luckily for us, they have taken on more of a salad bowl approach here. Each country is represented by separate bowls, some filled with Thai seafood green curry, others overflowing with fish tikka; platters of fresh sashimi are just around the corner from the station, which features a board covered in fine French cheeses. If forced to stick with one section of this buffet for the night, we would skip the trip around the world and dive under the sea. The raw bar is covered in freshly shucked oysters, tender tiger prawns and succulent lobster claws waiting to be cracked. Leave room to sample the vanilla panna cotta topped with raspberry coulis, and the white chocolate mousse and green apple sauce, which both required second helpings.Dinner buffet $65++.

Make like a new-age mum or dad and buy your kids flamboyant, hand-stitched and embroidered dresses, headscarves, blouses and skirts from The Life Shop. For the boys, LIFEBabys camo collection of tops and bottoms in earthy tones will bring the cool factor to the wardrobe.

At 1 Caramel, you can have your cake and eat it too. With 27 freshly baked cakes to choose from, you’re bound to find a slice that satisfies your sweet tooth. For tangy, sugary craving, the lemon roulade with light mascarpone cream is recommended; for the tropical fruit lover looking to indulge, a slice of the mango mascarpone cake with a delicious coconut crumble bottom is pure heaven. Shaking things up a little is the densely textured Red Velvet cake with a dark chocolate frosting and the ultra-girly rose mousse and lychee jelly combination; both perfect with a cup of tea. There are a few more concoctions we’re dying to try on our next visit: the impressive-looking dome-shaped Sachertorte, a red miso soufflé and the D’Caramelita, which we hope tastes as yummy as its sensuous sounding name.Costs: From $2.50 (mini cupcake), $7.90 (slice of cake)
Get suits and dresses from this French couture brand.
One of the best Cantonese restaurants in Singapore. If possible, sit outside on the veranda overlooking Orchard Road and soak up the bustling atmosphere.
Learn to salsa, salsa casino rueda, merengue, bachata and street cha-cha-cha with June and Jackson.
A studio where natural healing activities such as yoga, accupressure, naturopathy are conducted on an ad-hoc basis. Go to their website for more information.

Few experiences satisfy the mind and body as thoroughly as a Great British pub, replete with real-ale pumps, chatty landlord, timeworn trinkets and frayed sofas. It was with optimism, then, that we approached The Queen & Mangosteen, a ‘Gourmet British Pub’ whose very name conjures quirky antiquity (Victoria was reputedly a fan of the succulent fruit). Sadly the nostalgic daydream dissipated on first sight. This joint’s all gleaming surfaces, blaring pop and over-zealous air-con, with efficiently blended cocktails and ‘craft’ beers instead of British ales on tap. In other words, despite the smart lounge and anglophile aspirations, this isn’t a traditional pub at all – it’s a slick yuppie gastrobar. Q&M’s (hardly unique) selling point is its waterfront setting, and at night, cruise ships docked outside VivoCity fill you with romantic yearning for far-flung locations. The food is robust, if hardly spectacular. With its adventurous recipes and swish seafront vibe, Q&M has tried hard to marry the demands of a discerning palate to a vibrant semi-alfresco venue, but the end result feels strangely anonymous. ‘Gourmet’ at a stretch, then, but this is about as quintessentially British as a Singapore Sling.

Whatever you need in your living room, kitchen, bedroom, or miniscule outdoors, you will find in iwannagohome. You'll get rock star beds, polka-dotted salt-shakers, wooden bowls, pop-art buddhas, metal birdcages and other home-y paraphenalia. We recommend the silver-plated teabag holder as a housewarming gift.

'O2Plants is the innovative provider of interior landscaping for offices, events, restaurants, hotels, and shopping centres in Singapore. Our mission is to bring you the best quality plants and serve you with exceptional service.' from the website.

A yoga centre that specialises in Iyengar Yoga 'that develops strength, flexibility, stamina, concentration, body alignment and brings deep relaxation'.Contact Sandrine Laborde at sandrine@iyengaryoga.sg or call her at 9161 6434 for more information.
Develop your prints or create calendars and coffee-table books. There are six branches in Singapore and you can order your prints online.
For special photographs that deserve wall space.
Sells used equipment and does camera repairs.

Barossa is a self-styled Australian restaurant and wine bar that really hasn’t done its homework. Daven Wu asks, 'What’s so Australian about miso cod fillet, mushroom soup, mango-tandoori-chicken pizza, or spaghetti and meatballs?'

In the very best of Chinese traditions, Chaozhou Inn is a place where you can sit down, order, gossip, eat and be out of the door in an hour. The menu is a tempting mix of the familiar (braised meats and roast pork) and the fabulously esoteric (duck tongue with orange sauce, chilled jellied pig trotters, charcoal-grilled pig’s nape, and pig’s stomach fried with XO sauce). A plate of roast pork and char siew is served unadorned, resplendent in its low-key combination of smoky sweetness. Duck is braised simply in a fermented bean paste and then served, thinly sliced, alongside strips of tofu scented with five-spice powder; the flavours are admirably subtle. Vegetarians also get a look in with treats that extend beyond the usual half-hearted sautéed vegetables so often seen at other omnivorous restaurants. Paired with the pale-hued vegetarian fried rice, the opulently named Four Treasures was a fragrant blend of gingko nuts, assorted mushrooms and the tart hit of kiam chye. The setting is cosy, the prices affordable, the staff knowledgeable (if a little harried) and, judging by the rapid turnover of customers, it’s a bona fide crowd-pleaser.
Galerie Waterton features paintings from established and emerging Southeast Asian artists. The gallery has a strong focus on Indonesian art.

When this local outfit first opened its doors we were unsure how long it would stay open. A local microbrewery, seriously? Months on, it is owner and brewmaster Ernest Ng who is having the last laugh. The bar continues to attract a regular clientele and is even filled on a Tuesday night. While it could be argued that the patrons are attracted to the food and lovely sylvan environment, one cannot argue that point too much when most tables sport a jug or two of the homebrew. The Monster Green Lagers Hulk-like hue comes from the addition of spirulina and may not suit a classic beer drinkers palate, so order the hoppy Summer Ale before you reach your final verdict.
content.openingtimes: Sun-Thu noon-11pm; Fri-Sat and eve of public holiday noon-1am.

content.description: If you are looking to see and be seen, this is most definitely not the place. However, if you just want a spot to shoot some sh*t (or, more specifically, some darts), this may be a new hidden gem. What used to be just one of the many Asian furniture stores, spread all along South Bridge Road, has now been converted into a bar. While many beautiful chests and paintings are still for sale the owner has a passion shes not willing to give up the focus has definitely shifted to the bullseye and cheap booze.A pitcher of Tiger runs for $18 and is served with sembei and prawn crackers. Show up on a Friday night and theyll even toss in a free plate of whatevers cookin. We scored a bowl of chicken curry that one of the patrons claimed as the best in Singapore. The music fits the crowd; they were probably hip in the 80s, but have been layin low ever since (think Dancing Queen and Money for Nothing).

This cosy, dimly lit pub calls attention to its Korean fried chicken providing a more delicious meaning to the acronym KFC. Look out for the eclectic food this kitchen pumps out, like spicy pupa (honey bees), and fried kimchi with Spam and tofu; but fear not, you will still get your quota of the typical fare as well, such as Korean rice cake and ginseng chicken soup. Standouts are the garlic-sauce-fried chicken, spicy chicken stew and instant noodle soup with a medley of sausage, tofu and vegetables. Drown it all down with their refreshing cucumber and lemon soju.

Within the bustling enclave of The Rail Mall, Ramen Ramen is regularly filled to the brim with diners devouring both traditional and modern Japanese soup dishes and sides. Owner Lim Wei Gien prepares the milky tonkotsu broth every day, allowing flavours to simmer for more than 20 hours. Recommended are the meaty Burger-men and Lum-Lum-men (braised beef in zesty herb sauce). If your taste buds have you wanting something off the menu, requests for specific concoctions can be accommodated. Side dishes are also bountiful: try the piping hot pumpkin korokke (Japanese croquettes) and karashi ebi (prawns garnished with a mouth-gasping mustard mayonnaise). Service is prompt and the mood is upbeat.

If youre up for eating whale sperm, you might want to dive into the deep end and sample the chefs surprise menu. The not-so-adventurous eaters will be thrown a lifeboat when they order dishes like the super-fresh maguro and scallop sashimi, and freshly battered tempura prawns that are crisp and juicy to the bite. Highly recommended is the barbecued fugu (puffer fish) and the caramelised barbecued pork with lotus root. With the chefs whipping up spot-on dishes all night, it was strange that an order of simple handrolls could be so disappointingly soggy, bland and small. Otherwise the food was consistently good, although a tad overpriced.

Mr Prata, located near Evans Lodge and a stones throw from the Botanic Gardens, churns out prata and rich curries to many a hungry soul in need of a 4am food-fix. The modest alfresco-dining establishment may be lacking comfort, but makes up for it with its diverse menu and brisk service. At the last count, more than 40 prata festooned the menu, complemented by both meat and vegetarian curry dishes from all over India, naan bread from the tandoor, and Singaporecentric fusions (see Mee & Meehoon Mix Goreng). Wash it all down with a manly Milo Godzilla and youll be complete at least till tomorrow, same time, same place.

Purists tend to turn up their noses at this joint, claiming its too touristy. Ignore them. The vibe is lively, the service brisk and the food is well cooked. You cant ask for more. Granted, the fish head curry is probably Tuna carpaccio and crabcakes Double Bay Best for Meat and greet An all-you-can-eat feast at Casa do Churrasco Brazil Food&Drink 28 Time Out Singapore May 2009 TimeOutSingapore.com better at Muthus down the road, but thats almost splitting hairs; especially when the rust-red mutton masala is delicious, while the creamy richness of the prawn and spinach curry, or the chicken in velvety yoghurt sauce are well-paired with a heap of biryani.

This truly is a meat-lovers paradise. Vegetarians, be prepared if you happen to be dragged along by insensitive friends, as the giant skewers of beef wrapped in bacon, glistening sausages and ribs falling off the bone may not sit well. However, the carnivores in the crowd can just sit back and get excited as all sorts of juicy pieces of cow, chicken, lamb and fish are carved onto their plates. Tip: avoid gorging yourself on the hearts of palm, mixed beans and potatoes at the salad bar this is just their way of filling up your belly before the good stuff arrives. In addition to the parking-lot location and drab setting, there is also something very wrong with the service ethos. The friendly wait-staff festively prepares caipirinhas at the table to complement the all-you-can-eat meats doused in salt, but when they deny diners a glass of tap water it leaves a very dry taste in the mouth. The Brazilian tiramisu sprinkled in coconut helped provide a sweeter flavour to finish the meal.All-you-can-eat lunch $32++, dinner $39++.

Pies, fish and chips: with its wall of windows facing the street, the newest bistro serving Aussie food has a warm breeze and friendly staff to complement the informality of its speciality dishes. Named after the glamorous Sydney suburb, the restaurant attracts a cosmopolitan post-work crowd in search of tasty casual fare. Seafood lovers are in for a treat and would do well to start with the tasty tuna carpaccio served with a bushel of alfalfa sprouts. For something heartier, try the large, full-flavoured, blue swimmer crabcake, served with a tart lemon mayonnaise. We were impressed by the fresh flavour of the barramundi, fried in a coriander and sumac batter and served with thick-cut chips and salad. Even though the sticky date pudding was heavier and more gelatinous than golden syrup-soaked sponge, well still return for the all-day Sunday brunch to tackle the molten lava chocolate cake.
This bicycle shop specialises in Swiss road bicycles. If you're thinking of a carbon frame from the Alps, here's the place to get it!

At TR Bikes, you'll get fully customised bikes that use only the very best parts! They deal with some of the best custom builders in the bicycling industry such as Sycip, Retrotec, Inglis Cycles, Aherne Cycles and Kent Ericksen.Contact lynten@trbikes.com for more information.

You'll get a bird's eye view of Singapore's cityscape at the Equinox Restaurant as it's located on the 70th floor of . The amphitheatre style restaurant is decorated with elaborate three-storey high teak and rice paper lanterns, Hu Tong-patterned wooden trellises and a wall made from mother of pearl. Best for dates to impress or special occasions, like popping the question, 'Will you marry me?'
content.openingtimes: Mon-Sat noon-2.30pm, 6.30-11pm; Brunch: Sun 11am-2.30pm; High Tea: Daily 3.30pm-5pm

content.description: This is the latest addition to the Timbre franchise, known for its laidback vibe and showcase of local bands. While the other two outlets feature livelier music, Timbre@ Old School is home to the acoustic sounds. Fittingly, the venue keeps a chilled ambience. Value-for-money happy-hour promotions two Erdinger pints and an order of buffalo wings for $28++, or one bottle of house wine and a pizza for $38++ make this venue a great hangout for a quiet evening among friends. If you are looking for an intimate location for a casual date, or just to spend some time listening to fantastic vocals, Timbre@Old School is where its at.

An upscale joint attached to The Prime Society, this boutique bar is one more watering hole to pop into when you’re in the Dempsey Hill neighbourhood. While drinks here don’t come cheap, they’re quality tipples. Premium spirits – Valt, Sullivan’s Cove and Hendrick’s Gin – are on offer, along with wines from Astrolabe (New Zealand) and Tinazzi (Italy), formerly only sold privately. With exposed brick walls, marble-topped tables, leather bar stools and eclectic nu-jazz sounds, mark this spot down as one to go to when you’re out wining and dining on the business dime.

address.street: Liang Court Shopping Centre, 177 River Valley Road, Clarke Quay
Liang Court Shopping Centre, 177 River Valley Road, Clarke Quay

content.description:
What magic do they weave with the ramen in the kitchen to make it so bouncy and lush? Each big bowl is already a meal in itself, the earthy broth (there are only three soup options – chicken, spicy chicken or nuts) spiked with either pork balls or boiled pork slices. It’s the connoisseur’s version of Maggi Mee. And if you’re feeling hungry, there are additional toppings to be had, ranging from an almost-coddled egg to omelettes and dominos of soy pork belly braised in soy sauce. Reservations are not taken.
This restaurant was featured in 'The High Five: Bowls or Ramen' (TOS Feb 2010)

It didnt take long for news to get out that Patrick Tan had left Shiro, but judging by the quality of a recent lunch at his new digs, hes not lost his touch. If the budget allows, deliver yourself into Tans hands. Depending on the season, he might send out impeccably cut sashimi, Japanese oysters, radish steeped in stock and then inserted between strips of seared beef that fairly melt on the tongue, layers of deep-fried bamboo shoots, and jelly infused with plum wine. And unlike Shiro, Chiharu is defiantly child-friendly.

A recent visit to Chip Bee Gardens was a nice reminder of how cosy this stretch of Holland Village still is. The à la carte menu here is surprisingly small, with barely three mains. Investigate instead the well-priced set meals where the range is larger and includes a hefty cut of veal wrapped with bacon, and a thick juicy steak on a pile of fries. As good as the mains are, the desserts are strange, such as the strange platter of fruits, and two meringue bricks topped with commercial whipped cream and ice cream. Stick to the lemon sabayon tart.

Like Cinderella, Wan Hao suffers a little from unwarranted neglect. Its hideaway location doesn’t help, but a recent dim sum lunch proved it was worth the effort to find it. Despite the lack of fatty layer, the burgundy-hued roast pork was still perfectly moist, while standards like the buttery char siew soh and translucent har gao were masterly. Standouts were the scallop sweet soup pooling over snowy rice and pepper-flecked garoupa, and a sesame seed-coated zhin doi stuffed with longan, melted chocolate and whisky that was as unexpected as it was addictive.

Its a sign that a zhi-char joint is beyond good when you look around and find almost every table is filled with white-shirted cab drivers. The raucous, frat-house atmosphere settled a little when the tiny kitchen sent out crisply battered prawns draped in a creamy pumpkin sauce flecked with curry leaves, followed by a bronzed fish infused with sambal. The tender chunks of pork ribs marinated in Marmite (yes, you heard right) was stellar, though it was a tough finish for first place against the long beans sautéed with dried shrimp.
Stylish sister restaurant of Min Jiang at Goodwood park. Try their Beijing Duck and don't forget to gawk at the Ernesto Bedmar decor.

Sarang (Korean for ‘love’) distinguishes itself with a smartly thoughtout menu that doesn’t try to be too esoteric or clever. The musically named mukeunji galbi jjim is a dish of meaty, sweet ribs stewed in a mellow kimchi broth that seems a little lost in the tropics, but which you imagine would go down a treat in snow-swept Seoul. Dwaejigogi bossam is the Korean version of a sang choy bao: thickly cut, sliced and boiled pork is rolled up with lettuce and fresh kimchi, and slathered with chilli sauce and garlic discs; while dolsotbap is a yummy mix of smoky rice and a soybean-sauce stew strewn with straw mushrooms and tofu. Kimchi – the national treasure of cabbage preserved with entire fields of garlic – is featured prominently in just about every dish, so it may help to temper the pungency with the delightful yuja cha, a lightly tart lemon and honey brew.

If fancy French fare is your thing, Absinthe delivers in spades. The sage-green wallpaper is a subtle nod to the colour of the liquor that lends its name to Our essential guide to Singapores best restaurants and bars, old and new updated every month the restaurant, and the open window to the kitchen offers a glimpse of the bustle behind the scenes. The lively jazz soundtrack provides an upbeat vibe, while candles flickering on each white-clothed table shout romance. The entrée of foie gras is meltin- your-mouth delicious and the addition of tiny hibiscus flowers gives it a perfect acidic punch. The roasted black cod is also a standout: served on a bed of saffron risotto that is far lighter and less creamy than expected and more successful as a result its the addition of a dill-scented jus that takes it to another level. A highlight among the skilfully made desserts is the absinthe sorbet accompanying a blueberry crème brûlée. But Absinthe is not just about the food; the restaurant has a charm that justifies the high price tag.

Suit sluts, pay attention, the new BOSS Selection Tailored Line, under the creative direction of German designer Ingo Wilts, will soon be within your reach. If youre an admirer of BOSS fine cuts and classic styling, youll probably go into credit-card debt (or you can start saving now) for this new luxe range described as impeccable handcrafting as well as loose, unfused workmanship.

Blame it on the likes of J.Lo and the (some say) oh-so-fabulous Paris Hilton, but the deluxe tracksuit is not going away anytime soon. At the height of its popularity – circa 2004 – these two divas, along with a handful of other comfort-chic loving celebs, drove the cachet of Juicy Couture’s velour and terrycloth creations into the stratosphere. And now, the brand has finally set up shop here.The walk-in-closet-styled store is imbued with the brand’s desirable Southern California-meets-English countryside style: lipstick-wearing deer heads, Victorian busts with a subtle goth edge, and not forgetting its heritage, a glory wall of tracksuits galore (this season’s favoured shade, yellow) sporting signature JC slogans and icons.For those not t-suit-inclined, there are sundresses, lingerie, matching mummy-and-me outfits, velour diaper bags, graffiti-style wellingtons (useful for the monsoon season), fun plastic timepieces and charming, erm, charms that open with a flick of the finger. For this spring/summer 2009 collection, there’s a certain Capri breeze blowing through their racks: pretty eyelet peasant tops, cherry prints, graphic block print sheaths, gladiator flats and teeny, tiny shorts. Soon to come, Juicy Couture for Men. We see the queues forming already.
Juicy Couture Interior

It’s difficult to remember a time before Dempsey Hill became a byword for gastrofab. This moodily lit, high-raftered space has been used to dramatic effect with giant birdcage lamps, a shimmering curtain of glass, soaring filigreed screens, and tall, wing-backed sofas crowded with pillows in Khun Jim’s fabled silks. The tom ka ghai combines the sweetness of coconut with mellow, perfectly cooked chicken strips. The mussaman curry is served with small cubes of beef and potato steeped in a creamy, burgundy sauce of cinnamon, galangal and cardamom. The green chicken curry is warmed by mellow notes of lemongrass, and it is difficult not to inhale the fried kway teow that’s stained black with soy sauce. Dessert should definitely not be skipped, an incomparable tab tim grob – the diced water chestnuts, stained a lipstick red, swimming in a light coconut bath with yellow flashes of jackfruit – and a perfectly judged mound of warm sticky rice to accompany the mango pieces create a grand finale.
turn:styles was featured in Convival Pursuit: Wild West Pubs.

Its not the citys smartest bar, and definitely not the coolest. But where the Lizard scores low on hip quotient, its genuinely lovely waitstaff goes to great lengths to foster a family atmosphere, and succeeds. Large screens carry sporting action, but are positioned discreetly so conversation flows as freely as the draft Euro beers (Leffe Blonde, Hoegaarden) and San Miguel. A chillout area and stash of magazines towards the rear makes a comfortable retreat for leisurely (or lazy) lounge lizards; meanwhile pinball machines and a pool table keep restless types occupied. But what really stands out aside from the earthy, genial ambience is the menu. Though this seems an unlikely destination for gastropub gourmets, the bar food isnt just unfeasibly cheap but of excellent quality.  The Lazy Lizard was featured in Convival Pursuit: Wild West Pubs.
The Beer Station was featured in Convival Pursuit: Wild West Pubs.
Persepolis was featured in Convival Pursuit: Centered & Down South Pubs.
M Bar was featured in Convival Pursuit: Centered & Down South Pubs.
Lot, Stock & Barrel Pub was featured in Convival Pursuit: Centered & Down South Pubs.
The CountrySide Cafe was featured in Convival Pursuit: Centered & Down South Pubs.
Beds was featured in Convival Pursuit: Centered & Down South Pubs.
Ming's Cafe & Pub was featured in Convival Pursuit: Up North Pubs.
Happy Daze Café was featured in Convival Pursuit: Up North Pubs.
Dolphin Tavern was featured in Convival Pursuit: Up North Pubs.
Bliss Restaurant @ Punggol Park was featured in Convival Pursuit: Up North Pubs.
Admiral Bar & Grill was featured in Convival Pursuit: Up North Pubs.
The Marina Barrage was built across the mouth of the Marina Channel to create Singapore's newest reservior. On weekends, expect to see kayakers (find out more) paddling within the reservior.

A great alternative to pumping iron or jarring jogs, fencing provides a full-body workout and a chance to master a sport that very few people are good at. One-on-one lessons with experienced coaches will have you parrying and thrusting with all the grace of a professional in no time.  Check their website for class schedules.

Jitterbugs Swingapore is a dance and entertainment lifestyle company that offers Lindy Hop, Salsa, Jazz, Hip Hop dance classes. Gals, if you're thinking of getting naughty, check out their Exotic, Pole Dance classes.Check their website for class schedules.
Vie Bar was featured in Convival Pursuit: Lazy East Pubs.
content.openingtimes: Sun-Fri 4pm-1am; Sat & eve of public holiday 4pm-2am.

content.description: The Dog & Bone Pub was featured in Convival Pursuit: Lazy East Pubs.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Fri 5pm-midnight, Sat, Sun & eve of public holiday 5pm-1am.

content.description: Main courses $18-$42.

You may already be aware that this well-known hotels lounge bar offers overpriced glasses of champagne, a menu that lists mo mixology from around the world (WTF?) and a caviar motini for $1,888 (yes, youre reading it right). Its no surprise no ones ever ordered the rare Russian fish-egg martini, but despite the prices, the bar staff are delightful and theres a very happy happy hour. Try the Adams apple martini, a mouth-tingling, sweet-andsour delight at $20++ (not included on the happy hour menu), or a classic dry martini for $13++. Its not as cheap as chips, we know; but if youre there from 6pm, as we were, youll also be served a small selection of to-die-for Italian olives and a sample of tapas that will help hold you over after one martini too many.

Located in Pasir Panjang, taking a step into this funkadelic London-loft-style warehouse is like being transported back in time. Stacked up to the ceiling with homeware and knick-knacks from yesteryear, you find yourself manoeuvring your way around '40s art-deco ashtrays, '70s cantilever dining chairs, '60s remote-control tin toy cars, an Eames-era plastic champagne container, a '60s pod chair with inbuilt speakers, and an avant-garde fiberglass chaise longue all the while trying not to knock over standing cylindrical lamps. There's something for everyone: the old dears will be reminiscing about the good ol' days and the young folks, well they'll lap up the second-hand retro-chic on offer here. Lorgan Wong started restoring colonial furniture with his father when he was just a child. As he got older, his appreciation for vintage furniture grew, the knowledge he accumulated from myriad design books allowing him to recognise the original make-up of the piece. 'I take pride in the ability to restore things as close to their original state as possible.' Most of Wong's pre-loved possessions-for-sale are flown in from Germany, the Netherlands, Denmark or Norway, with others found right here in Singapore. As for what to buy and how much to pay, Wong recommends going on eBay as a pricing guide and referring to magazines like ELLE Decoration (UK) as a guide to trendspotting. But if you're still in need of affi rmation, Wong who is usually found at the store meddling with a broken transistor radio or restoring a broken lampshade will be there to point you in the right era.

Got a hankering for a headless beer with uninterrupted views of a construction site? Then take yourself down to One Fullerton where the Lo & Behold Group recently opened this bar-cum-restaurant. With The White Rabbit and Loof as company cousins, this new waterfront spot just along from the Merlion should be something to write home about, but sadly its not. Lovely staff it may correctly boast but work a beer tap or a till they cannot. Based on a 1960s American diner, the interior design is only vaguely retro-funky and the fries from the menu this writer tried were overcooked and overpriced. Having said that, the rest of the menu looks enticing and in line with a theme of eggs. Consider the truffled egg toast for a taste of the exotic, or the pancakes with egg and bacon for something a little off the beaten track. And do pop in for the outdoor seating, evening views of the bay and a reasonably fresh sea breeze.

Its beloved of bikers and pool players, but the jurys still out on BLooiEs. On our first visit to their Bukit Timah outpost we faced a cold reception in every sense. Deafening rock, air-con so preposterously high it felt like winter in Montreal, brusque service (Here. Sign it. With the pen, ordered a waitress) and dire food (an undercooked steak, with carrots so hard they almost broke my fork). On returning, warmth was all around: soft pop music, the wait-staff all smiles and charm, and a perfectly decent Cajun chicken burger. Pick your night to avoid the Roadhouse blues, and youll find an enticing menu of high-cholesterol treats in a cosy, roadside-diner ambience: spacious surrounds, moose head and rugby shirts on the wall, well-stocked brickwork bar, TV screens and leafy, out-of-town location. A beery, blokeish bonhomie prevails, so dont take a date unless youre a serious ah beng. Botak Jones does this stuff much cheaper, too, but BLooiEs shades it for style and comfort.Drinks $10-$18.
BLooiEs was featured in Convival Pursuit: Lazy East Pubs.
content.openingtimes: Sun-Thu 11am-midnight; Fri, Sat and holiday eve 11am-1am.

entry.name: Crystal Jade Korean Ginseng Chicken & BBQ

version.name: Crystal Jade Korean Ginseng Chicken & BBQ

content.description: The name of this mood-lit and rather plush restaurant says it all, really. Hot plates are embedded into the table of each cosy, brown-coloured booth, though if the idea of smoky cooking is not your thing, the kitchen will take over barbecuing duties. The titular chicken soup is warm and herbal-ly (but not so much that it tastes medicinal), while each mouthful of the tofu soup speckled with baby clams and broad beans revives dull spirits. Alternatively, try pairing some sizzling stone-cooked mushroom rice with thick slices of sweet boiled pork.Main courses $16-$28

Fans of the Ultimate Fighting Championship can now do more than indulge their aggression online serious Mixed Martial Arts (MMA) training is finally available in Singapore. Touted as South-East Asias largest and most comprehensive MMA gym, Evolve offers Brazilian jiu-jitsu, muay thai, boxing, submission grappling, street self-defence, wrestling and other classes amid state-of-the-art facilities which include the first official MMA Octagon ring in the region. It even boasts world-class champion instructors, as Evolve is the only gym in the world to be affiliated with both the Renzo Gracie Academy (named after noted Brazilian jiu-jitsu and MMA fighter) and the Sityodtong Muay Thai gym in Thailand.Membership starts from $189 per month.

You get to tour Singapore's local brewery, taste beer straight from the tap and buy souvenirs of your brewery visit. Email corpcomms@apb.com.sg or call 6860 3005/007 to book a tour. Prior booking necessary to participate in the Tiger Brewery Tour.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Fri, tours at 10.30am, 2pm, 4pm & 6.30pm. Each tour is about 90 mins.

content.description: Main courses $18-$42.

The very friendly prices help explain why the Thai Express chain continues to be so popular especially in these cost-conscious times with teenagers, young couples and families. The quick-fix street-food menu is (for the price) competent and consistent in quality. The thickly gravied laksa with chunks of fish is particularly good, as are the chicken wings stuffed with minced pork dipped in a lemongrass sauce. There are vegetarian options the tofu curry with rice hits the spot every time. The bright and cheerful red setting and alert service are pluses.

Surely, its name is uninspired and so is its hawker location. But dont be sceptical about the quality of freshly prepared pasta and pizza that buddies Max and Melvin whip up as you order. The $6 set meal is great value for intense carb-craving. It comes with an extremely soothing mushroom soup cooked with heaps of garlic bits, a slice of garlic bread and the pasta of your choice. Go for the seafood spaghetti with chilli crab sauce, cleverly pairing the egg, tomato and sauce with pasta instead of the usual Chinese buns, and adding a generous serving of fresh shrimps, clams and fish. The pizza is not spectacular, but do leave room for dessert. The home-made tiramisu doused in rum is light and delicious.

When a restaurants name directly translates as the grandmother, you can expect food cooked just like mamma cooks it. But unless you grew up in an Italian home, this may not bring back warm memories of Sunday dinner. Still, home is where the heart is, and La Nonna maintains the homely vibe through nice touches like the handwritten (ie, computer-generated handwriting) menu. The rigatoni with tender chunks of braised oxtail was delicious right down to the last drop of sauce, and the beef ravioli in a cream sauce is lifted by liberal amounts of fresh parsley and a truffle compote. The more experimental dishes such as the cream of pumpkin with stingray are iffy; the fishy smell and taste can be a little hard for some to swallow. The risotto, while cooked to the right texture, was disappointing; the foie gras was overdone and the asparagus limp. Our advice? Stick with the more traditional dishes and youll do fine.

Make no mistake; Yantra is not just another north Indian restaurant, it is JS Gills (of Royal Sporting House fame) chic Indian fine-dining outpost and it rocks. Should you fail to be impressed by its elegant interior (which looks like a page from Vogue Décor) and glass-encased open kitchen with four gigantic tandoor ovens, taste the awesome dishes that are being served. Get your palate rolling with kachumber, a refreshing salad of tomatoes, onions and cucumber tossed with an Indian spice-infused lemon juice dressing. Its worth making a trip just for the anise-scented, sausage-like grilled minced lamb on skewers mutton seekh kebab, a flavour-packed treat. But if you like it all saucy, the boneless tandoori chicken in a satin-smooth, fenugreek-perfumed broth of tomato butter, murg makhani, is the perfect accompaniment to the crisp and light naan.
content.openingtimes: Daily noon- 3pm; dinner Sun-Thu 6.30-11pm; Fri & Sat 6.30-11.30pm.

content.description: Your dollar certainly goes a long way at Java Java Spa. Book a 60-minute Royal Javanese Massage ($50) and receive a one-off complimentary Ginger Herb Body Wrap ($25) or Body Mask ($30) for the entire month of February. Note: the promotion is not applicable for first-time trial customers who already enjoy the fabulous price of $35 for the lot.
Tucked away in Old School, this gallery promotes primarily Chinese Contemporary Art in all kinds of media.

Along with the obvious Spanish tapas olives, salami, calamari Zsofi gets creative with a ham and cheese croquette that closely resembles a deep-fried grilled cheese sandwich, skewers of asparagus wrapped in crispy bacon, and deviled eggs sprinkled with caviar that bursts in your mouth. This is an excellent addition to Little Indias cosmopolitan restaurant scene, but make sure not to show up starving we waited 45 minutes for our food to arrive. It pays to order a drink (free food!) and have some patience it will pay off in the end. Free tapas with every drink. Tasting platter of six different tapas $14.

Yes, authentic Mexican food is hard to come by in Singapore, but Viva Mexico part of the recently renovated Cuppage Terrace comes the closest, starting with a bona fide Mexican chef in the kitchen and ending with a rich pumpkin dessert baked with cinnamon, sugar and cream. Things bode well when free corn chips and two kinds of salsa arrive (literally) seconds after you sit down, with a salsa verde thats good enough to drink. Though theres an eclectic side to the menu, stick to the standards, particularly the chicken enchiladas boneless chicken breast wrapped in soft corn tortillas, with a side of refried beans looking a bit forlorn without a side of rice. Also notable is the depth of the drink menu (another authentic trait if you ask us), which includes more than a dozen kinds of 100 per cent Agave tequila plus reasonably priced $10 Jose Cuervo shooters and a delicious, smoothie-style blackberry margarita. Service is top-notch, attentive and knowledgeable; we now know the difference between sangria and sangrita.

The first thing to know about Forlino is you should completely ignore the PR hype about its chic and sexy interiors. Focus instead on the food by Michelin-starred chef Osvaldo Forlino. The excellent vitello tonnato (thin strips of perfectly roasted veal arranged in a pretty flower around a mound of tuna and caper-scented sauce) or handmade tagliatelle, which tangled wondrously with a ragù of duck slivers and foie gras. Desserts, too, were exemplary. The pannacotta trembled deliciously on the edge of liquefied milk; its creaminess was a lush counterpoint to the syrup and flesh of golden figs. And the petits fours (nuggets of pure dark chocolate) deserved their own entry on the main dessert menu.

Tucked away in a shophouse smack in Singapores alternative precinct, newcomer Dim Joy promises much in the novelty department, but the differences are largely cosmetic. Hong Kong chef Feng Song Tangs 15 years of experience show in his standards his roe-topped siew mai has just the right texture and juiciness, while the century egg porridge is satisfyingly smooth and fairly bursting with flavour. Slightly dry barbecued pork somewhat marred the chee cheong fun and char siew pow; but the custard buns rich sweet-salty goodness and Fengs own durian snow pearl, where he displays a remarkable mastery of the fruits pungency, were perfect endings. The open-concept kitchen, airy and naturally lit dining area and non-intrusive bossa nova/jazz score add just the right twist to an otherwise traditional experience. Service is brisk and attentive.
Dim sum $3-$8.
content.openingtimes: Mon, Wed-Fri 11am-3pm, 6-10pm; Sat & Sun 10am-3pm, 5-10pm; closed Tue.

content.description: Australian haunt Boomarang Bistro & Bar begs to be a beer-stained watering hole, with its open-air seating, picnic-style wooden tables and lowback chairs. But thanks to a menu boasting a $90 Wagyu steak and king prawn salad, its a casual balance of comfort and class instead. Try the mid-range lunch/dinner menu with a thick Wagyu beef burger topped with beetroot and cooked to our liking, or the tender Angus steak sandwich with barbecue sauce on lightly toasted flatbread. Theres emu, crocodile and kangaroo on the all-day grazing list for the more adventurous, and a deep breakfast menu that rivals nearby neighbour Epicurious. Give the desserts a pass the brownie was dry and hard.

Try Miracle Garden Holistic Spas Miracle Radio Frequency Face treatment ($150), a non-surgical facelift which applies a high frequency to tissues and converts into biothermal energy to stimulate the breakdown of fats. The Cytokine Meso Facial ($150) is another new offering it employs the Epidermal Growth Factor and Basic Fibroblast Growth Factor to increase the skins own collagen and elastin levels, resulting in enhanced radiance and smoothness. Then, have a healthy meal at its adjoining Blue Basil café, which specialises in fresh produce prepared with homegrown herbs.

Residents around Bedok Reservoir will be happy to know that a new hair and nail salon has popped up in their neighbourhood. Classic manis and pedis go for $38, while express mani and pedis are a steal at $5/$8 (colour only, no filing and shaping). Call ahead for appointments.
(). [MRT]

The red wall pads, gold accents, faded timber floors, tables set spaciously apart and ceiling fans create an unusually authentic Thai setting. The menu is fairly standard but done very well. The large and crisp rice crackers are paired with a pork and coconut dip, while the mango salad is a rich blend of dried shrimp, charred salted fish and peanuts. The dark-hued olive rice goes well with a fat butterflied fish wearing a thick, lipstick-red coat of sambal. Yhingthais charm, however, comes from discovering the odd gem, like sliced chicken feet salad and fish maw fried with crab meat.

This restaurant specialises in intense flavours laced with a touch of sweetness. Its rare to find a place with this calibre of cooking and where dinner for two sets you back barely $50. The fork-tender beef rendang is creamily sweet, the fried fish is golden, and the tahu telor is a smoky, shaggy pile of eggy, crisp tofu. For veggies, the keredok a small bowl of salad and emping crackers tossed with a tart, spicy peanut dressing is lovely. Have dessert somewhere else, though; they only have a rather uninspiring buffet of fruits and a couple of coconut-flecked kueh.

Mustard a key ingredient in Bengali and Punjabi cuisine makes its presence known in this restaurants menu. The maacher cutlet, which tasted like an upmarket version of fish fingers, was nicely breaded and fried, and paired with a warm mustard dip. The small pot of eggplant gently sautéed in mustard oil was delicately paired with luchi (Punjabi puffed bread), while the fluffy mutton biryani was just the thing to soak up the yoghurt sauce of the unusual rose-water scented chicken rezalla curry. The place fills up in the evenings with locals and young travellers from neighbouring hostels, so book ahead.Main courses $10.90-$15.90.

Its amusing to find a terrific French kitchen in a non-airconditioned shophouse in the middle of Little India. Open only for dinner, the place fills up quickly with locals and French expats who want to enjoy their caramel sweet onion soup and fragrant cut of duck pâté. Nicely oiled lamb chops are perfectly paired with sautéed herbed potatoes and aubergines, while the richness of the roast duck is cut with a creamy risotto. We found the honey cheesecake too milky and the chocolate cake oddly textured, though. Then again, the diners at the next table practically inhaled their profiteroles.

ARC is brought to you by the same people who gave the island some serious fashion street cred at Actually and Wooonderland. Its stocked with unheard-of brands such as Omnigod, Vandalist & Instantology, and others like Laundry 202 a popular South Korean line that favours monochromatic tones, oversized lapels and a masculine silhouette and Suh Sang-Young, which has built a cult following with its distinctive Asian-cut (read: petite) menswear. Expect many other Asian designer labels to feature at ARC; but in the meantime, set aside some moolah so you can do more than just window-shop.

The name, the crowds of American teenagers, and the expats and mixed couples pretty much give you a clue of what to expect. Corn cooked every which way is the order of the day. Throw in a speedy kitchen and a wait-staff that knows its stuff, and you have a recipe for a rollicking great Friday night. The guacamole is a surprisingly subtle mix of avocado, onions and a hint of lemon. Enchiladas gently fold around a salty-sweet pile of crabmeat, while the DIY hard shelled tacos (piled high with cheese, sour cream and guacamole) help you remember why youve always loved finger food.

Once upon a time, two suits called it a day at their dreary Raffles Place jobs and decamped to Japan to learn the secrets of Zen temple vegetarian cuisine. The pair now runs a bijou catering cuisine during the week and takes over Gotos premises to serve just lunch on Sundays. This is exquisite vegetarian fare served kaiseki style, and the menu changes monthly. Our recent lunch included a silky tofu made of puréed sesame seeds, tiny logs of braised eggplant sprinkled with chrysanthemum petals, sweet potato discs in miso soup, and delicate mushroom-flecked potato croquettes.  Six course kaiseki $45.

The salacious innuendo in this bars name is hardly representative of what it really is. Sure, the waitresses are wearing bikinis, but theyre not the skimpy, stringy kind. Plus the girls are more cute than smokin hot Brazilian goddesses they will clearly not tolerate any itchy fingers so anyone hoping to get fresh should forget it. What you can look forward to are sweet deals for Asahi beer (three for $25) and an ample selection of hard liquor, including Jägermeister. Food is also served but unfortunately, poor ventilation means youll leave the bar smelling like your lunch. One can only hope that some hardbodies coming off the beach find eau de roast duck attractive.

This place is under-serviced sometimes, but the tiny kitchen deserves a round of applause for pushing out meals at a clip. Comfort food with unexpected touches is the name of the game here. At the counter, popiah is rolled and kueh pie tee shells are filled. Pork ribs are slathered in a plummy sauce and dotted with white fungus curls, while the tofu is braised with a home-made special sauce. The portions are huge, especially the wonderful chicken soup that includes a quarter-cut wallowing in a clear herbal soup infused with ginseng and red wolfberries.Main courses $8.90-$16.80.

Squirrelled away in the heart of an HDB warren is this in-the-know zhi-char joint, where generations come together to feast on old-fashioned fare like smoky coffee ribs, thickly sauced tofu braised with tiny pinheaded mushrooms, butterpork ribs and excellent salted fish fried rice thats showered with fried anchovies. The dishes which come in super-sized portions, even the small orders come out fast and furious, while the matronly and scarily efficient Cantonese- speaking staff could teach everyone in town a thing or two about service.

The thin apple slices topped with smoked salmon and ricotta are just a sample of what this kitchen has got up its sleeve. Thick, diagonal cuts of veal are encased in a terrific, breadcrumbed shell, and the meats sweetness is accented with lemon and sprinkles of coarse sea salt. The pappardelle loops tangled in rich duck ragu are perfumed with sweet carrots and tomatoes. Our mushroom risotto, though heavenly, suffered from the indignity of being finished in five spoonfuls. At $25, the pitiful portion was a puzzling lapse. Dont have dinner here its like eating in a ghost town. Primetime is morning, lunch and afternoon tea.Main courses $16-$36.

We called it over a year ago, and lo and behold, we were right. Theres just something about the Amoy and Club Street area that attracts designsavvy, standalone stores. First came Strangelets, and now Trolley, a new multi-label lifestyle store nestled in at No 20. Opened by actress and The New Papers Babe of the Year Mindee Ong, Trolley has already grabbed our attention with its curation of products from Elmar Floetotto, Stadler Form and Duo Design.
There are regular shuttle bus services from nearby Clementi MRT station, universities and neighbourhoods, directly to West Coast Plaza.
The Cage is Singapore's "First indoor football stadium" with six 5-a-side pitches.

Celebrating its first birthday on 14 August, this club boasts red floors and lighting, oversized white beds and plenty of interpretive dance, all in a massive 13,000 sq ft space that practically cries out to be filled by big-rollers, show-stoppers and industry insiders. Features include a main dining area (LaSalle Neige), a room for private parties (La Chambre Privée) and unisex toilets (La Check Under the Stall Door First).

Modern Chinese cuisine designed to balance technique and presentation while sampling from other sources can be a difficult tightrope act. Timidity wont work; a proper hybrid needs wit and a spirit of invention, plus flawless execution. Jing wields the first two confidently, but doesnt always deliver on the third. Take the appetiser combination of wasabi mayonnaise prawns and Peking duck with foie gras. Jings lacquered skin and sautéed foie gras were a notable improvement on their antecedents, crisp and plush textures harmonising elegantly in the key of duck. However, the so-so prawns were lacking. But brighter moments outnumber lacklustre ones. Morsels of lamb are cushioned on soft radish cake cubes stir-fried with egg an unexpectedly good combination, as is the perfectly cooked, moist fish fillet baked in a peppery honey sauce. For dessert, lusciously fruity mango pudding didnt need any of its six garnishes to shine, while a smooth avocado cream dotted with sago achieved the perfect note of sweetness. Average lunch $68, dinner $88.

This modern bistro grill opened in late August 2008 at Pan Pacific Orchard (formerly the Meritus Hotel Negara), serving contemporary European cuisine. Although early reviews say its pricey, it still worth the visit just to satisfy your craving for Blackmore full-blood Wagyu beef or free range and organic Kurobuta pork. We know someone, somewhere out there is craving organic pork.
Lunch $ 16-$28, dinner $24-$150

After so many years, this self-styled English Rose Café still turns out a substantial afternoon tea. But its the à la carte menu that holds some nice surprises (inasmuch as English food can surprise) among them a generous serving of niçoise salad with moist French beans, perfectly done eggs and anchovy strips; fat pork sausages served with crisp bacon and a pile of caramelised onions; and a satisfying round of cottage pie. The French fries are addictively good, while the just-right apple pie sets the standard for this town. A live singer entertains with golden oldies from Wednesday to Saturday nights. What more could you want from a restaurant?

Framed by hot pink doors and adorned with pink bubbles, the shops central feature a mannequin lounging in her bathrobe in a bathtub makes perfect sense. Here you can find Missoni-esque dresses (from $169), white shirt-collar chokers, bow ties and even shutter sunglasses. Revel in an extensive shoe selection from netted gladiator sandals, edgy heels embossed with gold metal bolts to strappy heels made entirely out of zippers ($90-$149) that would put even Rihanna to shame. This store gets our vote for its urban sophistication with just the right amount of eccentricity.

Hailing from Bavaria, the 925 Sterling collection has been thriving since the retro 80s. These delectable charms in the shape of diamanté handbags, stilettos, cell phones, lipstick and hundreds more designs have been attracting consumers of all ages.

Looking to follow a fashion trend without blowing your budget? Drop by 2cm. Designed to resemble a fully extended dressing room-cum-runway, the space is perfect for browsing, trying on pieces and contemplating. Indulge in its range of chiffon baby doll tops, cropped jackets and satin cocktail dresses made special with small details like beautiful piping and intricate lacework. A knack for mixing linear patterns with statementmaking brocade belts is just one of the embellishments that characterises this eclectic collection.
Admission is free but heritage tour fee applies: $10 (adults) $8 (55 years and above) $5 (18 years and below) $3 (NUS students)

If youve got futsal stars in the making, then sign them up for this small-sided football league. Besides providing a fun and safe environment for kids to pick up basic soccer skills, adults can get in on the action by signing up to be part-time coaches.
Ages 18 months-5.

$375 (registration fee, includes ten sessions and a Socatots kit), $300 (renewal fee, includes ten sessions).

Much has been made of Tippling Club and its five-, ten- and 15-course dinner menus. What you must know is that every course is a foodand- drink duet, specially tailored to match the other. Consider fat Hokkaido scallops in crisp golden shells of potato spaghetti, garnished with basil jelly dice and sweet onion purée: alone, its merely a pleasant jumble of sugar, starch and umami, but its thrown into sharp, delicious relief when washed down with acidic Rocky Valley Riesling. Similarly, braised Wagyu beef is served with horseradish-potato purée and wrapped in a transparent beetroot gelatine envelope to match its velvety Malbec counterpart. Whatever you do, dont even think of driving home if youre opting for the 15- course menu, although make sure you grab the sachet of tippling tea, a morning-after remedy, on departure; it worked like a charm.  Lunch set menus from $29; dinner set menus from $195 with drinks/$125 without.

Another Harry's joins the pack, this time at newly refurbished location Cuppage Terrace. Perfect to escape the hordes of Orchard Road, have a drink and listen to Harry's regular guitarist Paul Ponnaduria.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Thur 11.30am - 2am; Fri, Sat and Eve of PH 11.30am-3am, Sundays 11.30am-1am.

content.description: Shoe fiends alert! Theres a chic new store on Club Street. At Eve, youll find Manolo Blahniks standing alongside other pricey imported ladies footwear labels. Each international brand brings its own character and charm to the heady mix: theres the Londoners choice of art for the feet, Georgina Goodman ex-OC star Mischa Barton and actress Sienna Miller have been seen pummelling the streets in these famed heels. Hetty Rose, on the other hand (or foot), goes eco-friendly with vintage kimono fabric and recycled leather, while Rupert Sanderson builds his shoe empire on simplicity. Lastly, Finsk is praised highly by Manolo Blahnik himself as divine, due to its designs modelled after that of a chair the heel and sole are the legs, and the shoes upper is the seat. One things for sure theres no lack of well-heeled choices for designer-philes.

Singapore has a handful of Irish pubs already, but The Toucan ranks alongside Muddy Murphys as one of the best (its location in the somewhat seedy Duxton Hill notwithstanding). The look of an archetypal old-school boozer is ably re-created indoors, complete with a cosy lounge area, big-screen TV and pool table. Outdoors, though, is the real draw: heres a proper pub garden dotted with ample bench seating, plus the occasional barrel, wooden barrow and wishing well. It all sounds terribly tacky but, remarkably, it works. And on a warm Singapore evening is there any other type? a pint of Guinness ($11) here is exactly what a thirsty, mildly homesick expat hankers for.Drinks $9-$35.

In a stretch with such a dense concentration of eateries as Holland Villages Lorong Mambong, it takes something extra for a place to stand out. In Al Qasrs favour is Lebanese head chef and owner Ghazi Georges Khanashat. Astonishingly, he uses no salt in his cooking herbs and spices are cleverly mixed to create flavour; though in the case of the eggplant, garlic and walnut salad, this translated into a rather bland dish. But most flavours are clean and pure, whether its the astringent green of rice wrapped in vine leaves, a creamy hummus fragrant with toasted pine nuts, a fresh halloumi cheese salad or the fluffy pita wraps of shredded lamb scented with cloves.Main courses $10-$25.

The swankier sibling to En Dining Bar and En Grill & Bar round the corner, Z'en is where to take a date or treat yourself. Serving up good-quality traditional Japanese fare, take a seat outside to watch the world pass by or book the VIP room for special events.

This is the newest addition to the En group's domination of the Mohamed Sultan stretch and a very welcome one too. Next to En Japanese Dining Bar, the grill is a slicker space offering up grilled and deep-fried skewers as well as kushiyaki, robata-style and teppanyaki dishes.

Luxury F&B company onelifestylegroup scores a hat-trick with its third restaurant, 24-hour Unopuro. Hungry ravers can tuck into a hearty post-clubbing meal of pizza and Roman- style Wagyu steaks – courtesy of chef Salvatore from Naples.
Pizza and pasta from $8.88 from 11.30pm-6am; breakfast from 3-11am on weekdays and all day on weekends.

Standing for La Source Philosophy, which means love of wisdom in Greek, LS Philosophy is a new luxury day spa providing the best in holistic beauty. Conveniently located in the heart of town, it boasts spacious treatment rooms replete with luxury amenities and personal iPod stations, a hair spa by Kérastase, a private hair salon and a café and bar. The spa also stocks exclusive Officina de Tornabuoni natural, therapeutic skincare products and health supplements from Italy.

Play areas, activities, child-friendly menus and special deals make dining out with the kiddies less of a hassle. On Sundays, face- and hand-painting and balloon-sculpting activities await your little ones (12.30-2.30pm).

Youll find a myriad of knick-knacks in this nook, from magazines like Wallpaper* and Believer to independent handmade zines, animal-shaped rubber bands and even utensils. Located on the third storey of a shophouse along New Bridge Road, this new bookstore would appeal to those who are into Japanese aesthetics (read: its cutesy). It also has an online storebut if youre looking to actually buy books, Casual Poet might be a little too casual.
Not so haute cuisine in Rochester Park

TOS Update (Mar 2010)
Hola tapa! Pork cheeks and pumpkin sauce ($15), Madrid-style beef tripe stew ($12) and paella española ($80 for four to fi ve people, order one day in advance) are just three of the 35 dishes on the new menu of this drinking and dining spot. #01-29 Orchard Hotel, 442 Orchard Rd
Original story:  On reflection, its a little perplexing why Singaporeans havent taken to tapas with more enthusiasm. After all, if youre a fan of dim sum and sushi with their bite-sized accessibility, its not a particularly big culinary leap to this most loved of Spanish foods. I find it odd that no one in this town serves tapas the traditional way. The counterbased form of snacking is, for me, one of tapas great joys: perfect individual morsels to be enjoyed, at all hours of the day, with a glass of chilled cava. The newly opened Bodega Y Tapas warmly lit and framed by quirky walls painted with black bulls and red flowers has none of this DNA. Whats served, instead, are small plates of food that usually need to be shared between two or more, and only at fixed lunch and dinner hours. While the food itself is authentic, there is much more to the tapas experience than this. Spanish chef Bernardo Novas Pardeiro does a smart job in sending out delicately wrought, full-flavoured offerings. Hes helped by quality ingredients the staple of all good tapas that he rarely does much with, except perhaps a quick sauté or a flash on the grill. Small discs of chorizo sausage oozed their ruby red oils. Chunks of tuna came simply skewered on fragrant rosemary stalks. Meatballs arrived doused in a tomato sauce that was bronzed with crushed almonds and garlic. Potato croquettes were nicely creamy and elastic, while the pear and chocolate pie charmed with its understated blend of sweet and bitter. At another meal, Pardeiro sent out his version of devils on horseback: fat, sweet scallops wrapped with streaky bacon and prunes; the combination of sweet, fat and slightly tart was an instant crowd-pleaser. Even humble potato wedges were given a lift with crisp shells and a lemony, paprika-flecked dip. And because the kitchen relies so heavily on good ingredients, any slip is immediately obvious. Less pleasing were the bland beef cubes sautéed in flavourless garlic, and a powdery, rather damp crema Catalana, the Spanish version of a crème brûlée. Along with inadequate ventilation from the kitchen, service needs a serious overhaul. Bread was never served as a matter of course, not even when all that oily chorizo just begged to be mopped up: one order never arrived, and on a second visit, the log of bread finally materialised after three follow-ups. It then appeared on the bill as a $2.94 item. Later, the bill arrived buried in order chits. When we asked why, the reply was, So you know what you ordered. Even when the place was barely quarter-full the wait-staff were harried, distracted, and sometimes haughty and bordering on plain bo-chap. Words by Daven Wu

From the IndoChine group comes Savanh, a bistro/lounge/restaurant that serves Asian tapas (read: the familiar spring rolls from IndoChine which is, not surprisingly, next door). Though some of the décor is questionable (pink chandeliers?), the starters are reliable and the bar area with its three-storey waterfall enjoyable.

A chic outdoor bar that lets you unwind amid the lush greenery of Dempsey, complete with animal-themed topiary. But dont let your expectations get too high: the bar staff isnt quite up to scratch. Service aside, we highly recommend the divine Mini-Mary, a spicy shot that comes with a cherry tomato, and the Gin Fizz, a heavenly mix of gin, lemon juice, syrup, soda water and a dash of egg white.Main courses $28-$58.Read also: Nightlife preview on The White Rabbit.
Mr Bean's Cafe was a Runner-up in Best Late-night Dining in our Who is top of the Table? feature.

Chef Ronnie Chia takes the helm at Tatsuya, newly relocated from the Park Hotel, its home of six years. Taking the place of the short-lived Dim Sake Bar, Tatsuyas small and simple-yet-classic 48-seat dining room boasts both tables and a sushi bar. The melt-in-the-mouth fish is to die for (flown in fresh from the famous Tsukiji fish market in Japan) but you definitely pay for the taste at $100 for a mixed sashimi platter for two. Not everything on the menu comes from under the sea; splash out on a piece of beef sashimi at $20 a pop, or let the chefs do their thing with the traditional Japanese menu at a minimum of $150 per person.

This place fills up quickly during the week with a noisy, exuberant lunch crowd of bankers, secretaries and legal eagles. Reasonably priced set lunches are available; meanwhile, a stern-faced chef behind the counter prepares the pricier sashimi and sushi. The hand-rolls are generously stuffed, and the salmon is gently grilled till the flesh falls off with a gentle prod of the chopsticks. Our favourite offering is the Botan Bento a huge tray of tempura, sashimi, subtly flavoured braised vegetables, chawanmushi, miso and fruit. A big plus is the brisk service, essential when youre trying to beat the lunchtime rush.

The red booths and dark timber give even the most casual tea here a rather luxe French-style vibe. The best seat in the house is by the window to people-watch, while sipping arguably the best hot chocolate in town. If youve just hit the jackpot, splurge on the $450 Iranian oscietra caviar. Otherwise, stick to the excellent Croq Ferdinand a slab of toast topped with gruyère cheese, Parma ham and mornay sauce and a Nordic platter of wondrously rich and salty-sweet salmon, creamy salmon mousse and thick, fleshy cuts of herring, all served with chives, cream and fat globules of salmon roe. Our eggs Benedict was fatally flawed though by a thoroughly overcooked poached egg.
Wine Network was a Runner-up in Best Wine Bar in our Who is top of the Table? feature.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Thur 12noon - 12amFri, Sat & Eve of Public Holiday: 12 noon - 1amSun 12 noon -11pm

content.description: Mezza9 was Runner-up in Best Champagne Brunch in our Who is top of the Table? feature.
Curry Favour was runner up in Food for value under $25 a head on our Who is top of the Table? feature.
Ponggol Seafood was a Runner-up in Best Chilli Crab in our Who is top of the Table? feature.
Spizza was a Runner-up in Best Pizza in our Who is top of the Table? feature.
Rocky's was Runner-up in Best Pizza in our Who is top of the Table? feature.
Ya Kun was a Runner-up in Best Breakfast in our Who is top of the Table? feature.
Scrupmtious Cafe was a Runner-up in Best Breakfast in our Who is top of the Table? feature.

For a city so obsessed with food, its surprisingly hard to find a decent burger joint besides the obvious: Hard Rock Café. The discerning foodie might want to try Wild Rockets low-key café Relish, tucked away in what appears to be an antique furniture outlet. The menu pairs burgers with fantastic imported beers, from Pink Killer to Sapporo; each ale arrives in its respective brewing companys distinctive glass, Belgian-style. The pièce de résistance is the Ram-lee burger a refined version of Malaysias hallowed Ramly burger complete with neon-orange chilli sauce. Check out the happy meal beer and a burger for $28.
Burgers $17-$19.Relish was a Runner-up in Best Burger in our Who is top of the Table? feature.
Astons was a Runner-up in Best Burger in our Who is top of the Table? feature.

The Business Times Budding Artists Fund ─ an initiative by The Arts House, aims to enable children to pursue their artistic talents. Offering professional training in dance, drama, new media, visual arts, music and singing, the Fund will provide long-term, comprehensive arts training to develop the talents of children with strong interest and artistic potential. A strong scholarships programme makes it possible for all children to enjoy professional training in the arts. All profits from the course fees are reinvested towards the further training of children from financially disadvantaged families.

Tucked away from the bustle of Orchard Road, this art museum at the newly built Luxe building, with 700 square metres of exhibition space, is bent on propelling contemporary Chinese fine art to the forefront of the South-East Asian art world and beyond.

Eastsiders will be thrilled to know that they dont have to travel to Orchard Road or Holland Village anymore to visit Toni&Guy. Located in a refurbished Peranakan shophouse amid the gastronomical delights of Katong, the East Coast branch officially opened earlier this year. Helmed by directors May Eng and Dawn Soo, you can also catch another popular stylist, director Connee Law, who shuttles between the East Coast and Holland Village salons. In keeping with the neighbourhoods ambience, the vibe is raw and relaxed, with timber panelling and exposed brick interiors. Aside from offering the usual cut-colour-wash-blow dry services, you can also indulge in the System Professional treatments and colouring services using Wella products on the second floor. Then, head to the room next door for a manicure and pedicure to complete the whole pampering experience. What we love most perhaps is the complimentary pick-up service thats exclusive to this branch; the salon arrange rides for clients living in the east, even if youre coming directly from Changi Airport.
Moomba Tuckshop won Best Sandwich in our - Who is top of the Table? feature.

Though pronounced Strange-lets and not Strangel-ets, this quirky little nook will definitely choke the hell out of your credit card. Offering creations by chic designers like Nils Holger Moormann and David Restorick, the store is a delight for fans of luxurious furnishings think beautiful lamps, sleek bookcases and other peculiar decor items like fertility dolls. Strangelets also has a lovely collection of Xhosa crafts by the Imiso design collective, thanks to co-owner Joshua Comaroffs South African roots. Clockwork beetles (available in three sizes) from Insectlab and Moormanns mutant chair-cumbookcase piece are a couple of must-see curios, but impulse buyers beware: the bill is going to hurt.

DYMK stands out loud and proud along a line of shophouses with its bright red-and yellow façade. This bar/café caters both to the drinking and teetotaller crowd with its house-special cocktails and premium Vittoria coffee. Once you enter, sit back and chill on the first floor or swing yourself up to the second floor, where retro music and mood lighting will get you into the groove.

One of Singapores most popular vino importers now stocks imported cheeses, Parma ham, speciality sausages, antipasti and more and thats just at the deli. Check out its new bistro, where patrons can wine and dine before polishing off desserts like cannolis and apple crumble by chef Matthew Garon from Boston.

In a fickle town like Singapore, it means something when a restaurant has been in business since 1953. The home-style cooking here is lush and intensely flavoured. Best of all, prices are extremely reasonable for the portions: an $8 small serving will easily feed two. Among the dishes to try are fried discs of squid, with the evocative taste of smoky belachan, and eggplant braised in soy sauce. Fluffy fooyong is streaked with tiny prawns and crabmeat, while pork strips sautéed in chilli and assam are the perfect comfort food. For dessert, the chendol, drenched in a white blanket of coconut cream, is unforgettable.

The regular lunch crowd here is dotted with Japanese business suits, so thats already a reassuring sign that all is well even as you settle down at the narrow chefs table. The sushi is truly outstanding with fat tuna belly, sweet prawns and firm salmon. If youre feeling particularly indulgent, the slightly spicy rolls of lurid orange mentaiko (pollock roe) are nutty and delicious. Needless to say, its not a cheap joint, but the lunchtime bento boxes featuring a rainbow of sashimi set the bar.
Bento boxes $30-$60.

After all these years, this place still manages to pack them in, especially at the weekend. All this without any fancy decor, though were rather fond of the tree-lined views of the bay through the windows that curve along the restaurant. No one seems to mind that a simple dinner for two could set you back $70, but this could be because the Chinese and Malay menu of homey classics is consistently good. Were fond of the thick logs of fish cakes floating through the creamy laksa, the richly pungent rojak and the fragrant chicken rice.

Though the trek up to the newly minted Helipad bar seems to go on forever, the effort is rewarded with spectacular city views from the rooftop, especially of Clarke Quay (the bar is directly across the river from the G-MAX Reverse Bungy). The stylishly moody interiors (with an oddly placed DJ box right in the middle) ooze a relaxed vibe, while the comfy seats induce long stays. Best of all, friendly staff served up our drinks quickly. We suggest the refreshing Absolut Mango with cranberry juice.
Drinks $11-$18

Sticking to an exercise regime takes discipline, but for commitment-phobes who balk at subscribing to a years gym membership, Fitness Factory is the perfect alternative. This new boutique gym claims to be the first in Singapore to provide personal trainers for non-members on a first-come, first-served basis, a promise we hope they live up to.
See also We love: Couple treats

This museum features the most comprehensive collection of Peranakan artefacts in the world, displayed through ten galleries that explore the various facets of this vibrant culture.Peranakan Museum was also featured in Straight out of the past. Things to See Conversations Gallery As Peranakans re-examine their culture and identity in the face of modernity, this gallery serves as an introduction for the public by showcasing a myriad of Peranakan clothing, food, jewellery and artefacts. Nonya Gallery Domesticity has always been a prominent trait of the Nonyas. The importance of the sarong kebaya, the traditional Nonya attire thats exhibited in this gallery, will be revealed as it not only highlights the skill involved in beadwork and embroidery, its also a preoccupation of the traditional Peranakan woman.

entry.name: National Archives of Singapore Lobby Gallery

version.name: National Archives of Singapore Lobby Gallery

content.description: Verve has moved into the ground floor of the two-storey colonial building that used to house the Turquoise Room. The lush surroundings of Gillman Village that serve as its setting still lure, while the kitchen keeps things low-key with simple Italian bistro fare. Whether done aglio olio-style or tossed with hunks of plump slipper lobster in a white wine-reduced broth, the pastas are crowd-pleasers. The crowning glory, however, is the thin-crust pizza section. Our Barzoni (bacon, mushroom, garlic mascarpone and shredded basil) and Santino (pepperoni, chorizo, baby spinach and jalapeño) were outstanding.Main courses $24-$36.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Thu noon-11pm; Fri & Sat noon-midnight;Sun noon-10pm

content.description: What a delightful little bolthole this is, especially in the evening out on the verandah tables. The dual menu is French and Vietnamese and we suspect the pull is the latter option. Especially delightful is the wonderfully named cha ca la vong, a sizzling fried sea bass smothered with a paste of golden turmeric and fresh dill. Pair that with a superb pomelo salad studded with prawns and peanuts, and beef pho drenched in an earthy, rich broth. Gold wallpaper, timber panels and starched linen complete the muted IndoChine vibe, though service can be a little patchy.

This place is like a Carlsberg commercial. Open the innocuous sliding doors and you suddenly enter a raucous, buzzing world full of yelling chefs, handclapping service staff and customers shouting to be heard above the din. The chefs kneel on three raised timber platforms that catch a trough of fresh seafood, vegetables and meats. Pick what you want and its all grilled on the spot before being served on long wooden paddles. Since there is no seasoning or adornment, super-fresh ingredients are key (the grape ice cream is sensational). And it shows in the nightly crowds that sit packed together in rows around the platforms. Its all highly entertaining.

Right at the corner of two busy roads, Sum Kees homey zhi-char is worth braving the traffic fumes for. We love the har-jeong chicken coated in a crispy batter, and pork strips stir-fried with bitter gourds in a black bean sauce. Sensational too is the fu yu with sweet potato leaves, and the cubes of fried tofu embedded with a thin layer of cereal. Meanwhile, the glistening pork ribs and fried beef noodles never disappoint. The late opening hours are a bonus, especially after a night carousing at nearby clubs and bars. A home delivery service for the River Valley Road area is also available with a minimum order of $20.

The Lee clan has been making sar hor fun since its Ipoh days back in 1948. Tender loops of snow-white noodles are draped in a variety of sauces and toppings and theyre all worth trying, whether its prawns, mushrooms and bean sprouts; broiled chicken shreds; or just tangled with globes of wonton. The side dishes are equally good, including golden bricks of fried tofu, and piles of kai lan soaking in thick oyster sauce. Minus point: they charge for tap water.
