Take a bite of their super-healthy home-made vegetarian cookies in flavours like lemon pumpkin flaxseed and cashew nut made without butter, eggs, milk or margarine. We know its hard to believe anything can still taste good without any of those ingredients, but give it a try.Genesis was included in our Living on the Veg feature.

Like its next-door neighbours, Tangos has been in its spot for over a decade and hasnt changed much at all. Its swanky, clean-cut aesthetic doesnt deter customers from rocking up in shorts and Havaianas. Bar snacks and beers are tasty and refreshing however, the high price tag will sneak up on you. Youll be surprised at how quickly you can put away four beers and end up with a fat cheque.

Not to be confused with the capital city of the Malaysian state of Selangor, this is a popular, no-frills haunt on Circular Road for ravenous clubbers and night owls looking to satisfy their appetites. Serving up favourites like prata and mee goreng (topped with a sunny-side-up egg), this place has outdoor smoking seats kept cool by powerful fans. Well known for its piping hot teh tarik and prompt table service.

During the day, Orchard Towers looks like another mall, which has seen better days.After about 10pm, "The Four Floors of Whores" really gets busy. Although we have never been there ourselves (yeah right - Ed) we are told by others that FFW is an almost delightful parody of itself and well worth a visit if you have brought your sense of humour.In the quieter tower at the back there's a Harry's bar but even this has a higher ratio of ladies to men that you might usually expect in a pub. Ipanema is the most mainstream and is a pretty good bar - it is always busy and the live bands rock all night long.Other venues in the complex include Ba Li Ba, Bongo Bar, Club Romeo, Country Jamboree, Crazy Horse, Naughty Girl and Top 5.

Lau Kwong Fook, a freelance philosopher and editor, runs The Philosophy Café every third Wednesday of the month at the Gone Fishing Café.The issues discussed are more philosophy for a modern world, like poor artists versus rich bankers, abortion issues, whether religion is entertainment for the masses and the like, rather than the hard stuff, so anyone can jump right in and participate.

Cameras and other gadgets are still very good value in Singapore. UK visitors will find 30% discounts on UK prices and can reclaim GST - 7% sales tax - at the airport.Funan has a lot of cameras, more cameras and all the other electrical items that the gadget or IT fan really needs. Try several shops before you buy, vendors offer varying packages and add-ons for different products.Funan is also the venue for one of our Critics Choice Thai Restaurants, A-Roy Thai, so pop in there when you have finished haggling.

Not only the oldest Catholic church on the island, but also the home of Singapores Archbishop.The most interesting fact, though, is that the church houses the oldest working organ, which dates back to 1912 (no small feat, considering our humid weather). Organ builder Robert Navaratnam plays the instrument at some church masses. Corner him, buy him a kopi and hell gladly give you a most detailed history of his passion.
Offers delicious curries, meat dishes and homemade cakes. You can usually find the owner, Ivy Singh-Lim, on hand to greet guests and offer them free fruit.

Farmpreneur and Singaporean icon Ivy Singh-Lim runs Bollywood Veggies, one of the few local farms to raise organic fruits and vegetables. Advertising planet friendly fare grown without pesticides or fertilisers, they specialise in fruit vegetables like cucumbers, pumpkins and gourds. Though Bollywood Veggies is practically in Malaysia, no one said its convenient to be a trendsetter.Bollywood Veggies was included in our recent Organic appeal feature.

This top-notch attraction contains 8,000 birds from 600 species. Theres a multitude of exotic and endangered South-East Asian species, alongside pelicans, penguins, flamingoes, ibises, swans, toucans, birds of paradise and more. Key attractions include the largest walk-in aviary in the world, where youll find a 30m (98ft) man-made waterfall and 1,500 birds from Africa and South America flying freely within the huge compound. After a $10m revamp in 2006, the park now has a exhibit modelled on the Okvango River in Botswana, complete with storks, cranes, fish, frogs and African-style huts. Bird shows and feeding sessions take place throughout the day. Joint tickets for the BirdPark, Night Safari and Zoo ($40; $20 children) are available. What's on?African Waterfall Aviary
Daily; 9am-6pm
A more holistic African experience is now on offer within a simulated tropical rainforest. With a 35m-high net ceiling, 1,500 African birds have more space to roam, but theyre not the only animals reaping the benefits of a renovation. Enjoy a spanking new suspension bridge, observation posts and the new African hut for all your ornithological conquests.African Wetlands Exhibit
Daily; 9am-6pm
A simulation of the St Lucia Wetlands in South Africa, this replica reflects the balanced wildlife ecology at its original site, allowing African birds like shoebills, crowned cranes and saddle-billed storks to grow accustomed to living in this part of the world.Early Bird Breakfast Show
Daily; 8.30-11am (breakfast), 9.15-9.45am (show)
Various prices (breakfast), free (show).
They say the early bird gets the worm, and you just might want to let them have it at this interactive breakfast. Instead, you can choose from a variety of delectable dishes off the Bongo Burgers Terrace menu while you make new feathered friends like Big John, the parks oldest cockatoo, and Merlin, a yellow-naped Amazon who tells fortunes.Birds of Prey Show
Daily; 10am (Fuji World of Hawks), 4pm (Kings of the Skies)
Not only are they ferocious flying predators, these birds are also very disciplined. Watch the turkey vulture swoop past your ear, the Himalayan griffon vulture climb up a tree and the Brahminy kite eat from chopsticks (Fuji Hawk Walk).Feeding Frenzy
Daily; 10.30am & 2.30pm (Bee-Eater and Starlings), 10.30am & 3.30pm (Penguins), 2pm (Pelicans)
Birds (like Singaporeans) are at their happiest when eating. Time your visit to the park and youll get to see a variety of birds catching their meals literally (Waterfall Aviary, Penguin Expedition, Pelican Cove).

This wetland reserve of mangrove swamps, ponds and secondary forest is home to 140 species of birds. Thousands of egrets, sandpipers and plovers pass through in winter, but plenty of local species (kingfishers, herons, bitterns) are visible all year round. Early morning is the best time for birdwatching; there are observation hides, and you can rent binoculars. There are three nature trails (3-7km/2-4 miles long), and you can also spot mudskippers, monkeys and climbing crabs on the mangrove boardwalks. Free guided tours are available on Saturday (9.30am, 3.30pm). On Sundays the 925 bus stops at the entrance; the rest of the week you have to walk from Kranji Reservoir car park either via Kranji Way and Neo Tiew Crescent, or via the rugged and longer Kranji Nature Trail. Alternatively, you can catch the Kranji Express bus.
Spize, The Makan Place was included in our recent One Night Stand feature.
The Settlers Cafe was included in our recent One Night Stand feature.

Now with five outlets across the island, this popular Hong Kong foodie joint is really on a roll. The menu has over 300 items (really) including the fancy-looking 8 Treasures Soup, traditional Hong Kong street snacks (condensed milk on toast is just one of them) and double-boiled birds nest. Theres even Western fare like burgers and sandwiches. At the Zion Rd outlet, a giant plasma TV takes up most of the wall space so you can enjoy old Hong Kong action flicks over your meal.Tong Shui Cafe was included in our One Night Stand feature.

Take wining and dining to new heights at Mount Fabers crowner, jewel. Owned and operated by the Mount Faber Leisure Group, the award-winning Jewel Box is an F&B/entertainment complex that includes the stunning Glass Bar, Faber Rock, Altivo and the Faber Hill Bistro. In fine weather, Bistro patrons can supposedly catch a glimpse of neighbouring islands like Bintan and Batam, while Glass Bar customers can admire an unobstructed view of the harbour. Jewel Boxs other claim to fame? Its the only local fine-dining establishment accessible via cable car. Its even been credited as having the worlds best toilet, which should make you curious as to what the best toilet in the world looks like.Jewel Box was included in our One Night Stand feature.

Samar Cafe is an authentic piece of the Middle East in Singapore - the service can be bad, the food is not the main attraction and you cannot buy alcohol. If you do not want to sit on the floor then you should definitely mention that you want a table when you book. The music and atmosphere here is the u.s.p. - if you have never seen an authentic Middle Eastern band live then you must go to Samar soon.Samar Cafe was included in our recent One Night Stand feature.

Rev Distribution hosts different wine tastings every Friday (6.30-8pm) and Saturday (4-7pm). The $10 fee offsets any wine purchase made in its retail shop.Rev Distribution was included in our recent One Night Stand feature.
Va Va Voom Cafe was included in our recent One Night Stand feature.

If youre a sucker for old tomes and vintage magazines, this is the place for you. Theres a $1 clearance bin just begging for a good ransacking and classic literature going for prices as low as five bucks. You might have to spend a little more time going through the shelves and various discount piles to find what you want, but at such low rates, its worth the effort. Thankfully this place is not too old-school they accept credit cards, which is good news for big spenders.Knowledge Book Centre was included in our recent One Night Stand feature.

Geylang often gets dissed as a seedy red-light district, but many people forget that its actually a fascinating neighbourhood full of cheap, good food. Drop by Yong He to try its specialities: beancurd, and you tiao (deep-fried dough) with floss the latter can be eaten plain, dipped in soybean milk or vinegar (dont knock it before you try it). Since its open 24 hours, its a popular supper place for both people-watching and straight-up feasting.Yong He Eating House was included in our One Night Stand feature.
CMK Restaurant was included in our recent One Night Stand feature.

A Singapore institution, Mustafas is open round the clock, offering 75,000sq ft of bargains, not to mention a hotel, café and supermarket. Its a treasure trove of discount shopping, carrying everything from skincare and electronics to sports wear and luggage. Sumptuous sari fabrics can be found in basement 1, and beauty products and appliances at ground level. Mustafa Centre was included in our recent One Night Stand feature.

entry.name: Chinatown Complex Temporary Market & Food Centre

version.name: Chinatown Complex Temporary Market & Food Centre

content.description:
This temporary food complex will return to its original location (335 Smith St) at the end of the year (supposedly), but for now, swing by and feast on local delicacies like ah boleng (glutinous rice ball dessert) and its famous claypot chicken rice. Wander around the stalls and watch everything from home-made fishballs to red-bean soup prepared fresh right in front of you
Chinatown Complex Temporary Market & Food Centre was featured in our One Night Stand feature.

Running out of places to rent costumes? Check out this fun and made-to-measure service (perfect for the small people) that is available for special requests and even has an online reservation facility you can use to beat the crowds.

Set in lush secondary rainforest, this is a must-see. The worlds first night zoo (opened in 1991) allows you to see what over 900 nocturnal animals from 130 species get up to after dusk, in naturalistic habitats and without barriers, via the use of special lighting techniques. To see the zoo, take a 45-minute tram ride: observe majestic lions gnawing on their meat dinners, coy mountain deer striking poses and, if youre lucky, a noisy rhino taking a bath. You can get off the tram at designated points to follow three walking trails that let you get close to flying squirrels, dangling bats and a leopard or two. The hourly Creatures of the Night show is worth a look, but the ethnic performances are a bit lame. Dont use flash if youre taking photos as it may scare the animals. The Night Safari gets a million visitors a year, most of whom seem to turn up at the weekend; go late at night during the week to have a quieter time.

Everything you need to know about photography you will find here. This nondescript bookstore stocks obscure photography books by local and foreign practitioners. Most genres in photography,from photojournalism and landscapes to nudes and portraiture, are up for the taking. Shop owner Mr Ling has been on the circuit for most of his life, so if you need any advice, just ask.

"Location, location, location". Indochine Waterfront is the best example of this old cliche. The service is mixed, the food is consistent but the view is fantastic and so value for money is not so important. Dinner outside at Indochine Waterfront or at the next door Siem Reap Cafe (also owned by Indochine) is a must for visitors to Singapore and those wanting a reliable venue for a date or a romantic view over Boat Quay but with none of the noise and hassle.

entry.name: NYU Tisch School of the Arts Asia

version.name: NYU Tisch School of the Arts Asia

content.description: Commonly known as Tisch, this is the schools first campus outside of New York. Founded in 1965, Tisch has since become one of the leading arts schools in America.Tisch School of the Arts Asia will offer an MFA in film production, animation and dramatic writing.

A huge new Friday-night hit among Singapores three Ms (models, media types and the moneyed), restaurant-cum-bar Mimolette is tucked within the Turf Club off Bukit Timah (not far from Sixth Avenue). The colonial-house venue and its tropical-greenery surrounds make for an exotic and exclusive setting though one cant help feeling for the stabled horses nearby; the late-night outdoor discos pounding R&B numbers must interfere with their sleep. Visit the restaurant for brunch, lunch or dinner, and expect New American-meets-French fare. Executive chef Kelvin Lee has an impressive CV with stints at 3-star Michelin restaurants in France and top regional establishments, though initial reports from disgruntled diners to TOS staffers have pointed to cuisine being overpriced and ordinary.
Mimolette was featured in Biting Back - January 2008.

This bar and gallery occupies a converted art-deco building, where dusty grandeur and modern design combine to achieve a mix of style and warmth others can only aspire to. The upbeat soul tunes and kitsch snacks, including $1 bags of Twisties add to the personality of the place. A clipboard menu of drinks majors in cocktails (all $15), and features everything from salty dogs to your standard martinis.

Kick back and sample cocktail concoctions like Kampung Freeze and Gingerbread Man surrounded by wooden interiors, a stained-glass ceiling and avant-garde installations by local artist Donna Ong. Inspired by Enid Blyton's children's stories, the fairy-tale themed gastro-bar also serves enchantingly-named $12 shooters like Apple Pie, Gold Strike, and 3 Fairies, complemented by equally enchanting bar food such as xo-sauce squid ink spaghetti, Japanese-style grilled squid and wasabi prawns.

The drinks here pack a punch. We suggest the well-made blueberry mojito ($14.70) with its crushed ice, finely chopped mint leaves and, of course, generous shots of rum. Wednesdays and Fridays see the restaurant-bar packed with urbanites swigging their stress away and tucking into the exotic Middle-Eastern bar bites.

You never have to worry about your beer going lukewarm at Eski Bar because, as the name suggests, the place (a converted 750-square foot industrial freezer) is so cold, the staff go about their duties wearing thick overcoats. But when the novelty of having misty breath wears out, or when your skinny ass can no longer tolerate the coldness (whichever comes first), its the booze that will keep you going. The menu of Grey Goose vodka-based cocktails, such as Snowflakes and Eski Mojo, and vodka shots delivered straight from pistols by the Eski Angels will keep you feeling all warm and fuzzy.

Designed by IMPei, the legendary modernist architect, Swissotel The Stamford is a behemoth, comprising 72 storeys and over 1,261 rooms, along with 16 bars and restaurants, a helipad and its own entrance to City Hall MRT station. A popular choice with flight crews and big tour groups, it has an air of hustle and bustle. The rooms are nothing to write home about especially those on the lower levels though the upper floors provide spectacular views from the balconies. The Stamford is part of the same complex as sister hotel Fairmont Singapore, and shopping centre Raffles City. On a clear day, Swissôtel The Stamford offers a breathtaking of the Singapore's skylines. The views are reserved for paying patrons of the bars and restaurants on the 69th to 72nd floors but you can take the elevator up on the pretext of going to have a drink and see a portion of the view in the lobby area outside the lift. The best times to steal a glance are on weekday afternoons; any other time, and especially on Fridays and Saturdays, they usually put a cover-charge booth on the first floor. It is a painful $25 for entry and a drink at New Asia Bar on the 71st floor, so dont say we didnt warn you. Check out TOS's listing of City Space.

This quiet, leafy hideaway with handsome horses and swaggering riders on parade has dropped some cash recently to upgrade the facilities. We do like the cosmetic changes although menu prices have been upped a bit and some of our favourites have gone from the menu (hands-up who misses the vegetable curry with prata?). Still the menu offers a good variety, reasonably well executed the fish and chips are always a fresh treat and the nasi lemak is tasty. Avoid the chicken rice and laksa which are both bland disappointments.
A wide-open space for artists from Singapore and abroad dedicated to installation art to encourage interaction with their audiences and visitors.

Ketna Patel generously opens her studio to other fellow artists in Singapore to indulge in their passion. Artists use the space and, in return, offer a small fee or an original work for keeps. Visitors who are fascinated by the art of making art are welcomed for a behindthe- scenes glimpse at how artists immerse themselves in their work.

This exhibit allows you to interact with rays. Get up close and personal as you feed these sea creatures, affectionately known as birds of the sea. But be careful, as they have proven to be one of the oceans deadliest species.

entry.name: Kong Meng San Phor Kark See Monastery

version.name: Kong Meng San Phor Kark See Monastery

content.description: This hillside Buddhist complex, founded in the 1920s, contains classic Chinese temple structures, tranquil gardens, a tortoise pool, a crematorium and a majestic bell and drum tower. Housed in the Pagoda of 10,000 Buddhas are thousands of mini Buddhas (inside the main stupa) and one of the largest bronze Medicine Buddhas in South-east Asia. Bishan MRT stop is quite a distance away; you can catch a bus to the monastery, but the easiest option is to take a taxi.

If the scents of conventional perfumes are wearing you down, be sure to check out Jamal Kazura Aromatics. With glass shelves lined with jars of clear and coloured natural oils sourced from all across the globe, including the Middle- East, India and Europe this intimate fragrance boutique offers a wide range of attars (Arabic perfumes), Egyptian perfume vials, massage oils, scented body soaps and shower creams. First opened in the 1920s at North Bridge Road by the late Hinifa Kazura, Jamal Kazura Aromatics, with two other outlets, is now managed by his grandson Johari. Ask about customising your own signature scent Kazura will bring you a questionnaire asking after your favourite smells (citrus, floral, spicy, musky, etc), what type of occasion youre wearing the perfume for, and then proceed to select different scents to blend until youre satisfied. Bottled in 12ml vials ($30-$80), these are usually combinations of five or more oils mixed and shaken in a bottle. Custom-blended scents are also available ready-made; one popular choice is the Bella Rose, a long-lasting floral scent that starts off with citrus notes.

Shopping at IKEA is a guilty pleasure most of us wont normally fess up to. If its range of simple, chic and easy-to-mix and-match furniture pieces and knick knacks already put you into Martha mode, the new 2008 collection is going to have you in overdrive. Switch your dusty, tired curtains with some new, brightly coloured ones. Change your floral cushion covers to striped ones for that mod hipster look and get some colour (and cheer) into your home, just because you feel like it.

After being around for almost three years, hip lifestyle store EggThree is expanding its retail boutique and opening a new outlet in Joo Chiat. Its been designed as a boutique-cum-café space within a beautifully refurbished Peranakan shophouse. Expect bigger, one-of-a-kind furniture items borne out of EggThrees collaboration with local and international designers, and even an art gallery showcasing the works of Singaporean artists.

Moving beyond the wardrobe is Zone, a one-stop shop for house-proud owners who desire their living space to be stylishly decorated without having to take out a second mortage. Founded in Denmark, the store is supervised by an in-house team of 12 designers based in Denmark, Hong Kong and China. Their aim is to produce high-quality, functional Scandinavian design for the kitchen, bathroom, office and bedroom.

In a town where it feels like a new Italian joint opens every day, its easy to overlook the more established outlets. The seven-year-old Senso is one place that continues to impress with its contemporary menu and exemplary service. On a recent visit, we quickly forgot about the wrong order arriving at our table a roast balsamico cod instead of grilled pesto sea bass by the seamless way that, within seconds, the unwanted fish was whisked away and replaced with a complimentary glass of wine. The Sunday brunch spread ($78) is accompanied by free-flow Italian Prosecco.Senso expands its (delicious) horizons, opening a new outlet on Raffles Avenue in addition to its original home on Club Street. Before getting on the Flyer, try its margherita pizza a refreshingly simple take on an Italian classic and finish with a real latte. Pizza from $18, mains from $24.

The first thing that hits you as you enter Marios small space is the heady waft of yeast from freshly baked dough (though its a little unfortunate that the badly ventilated open kitchen also leaves you smelling of your dinner - to avoid this you can eat in the al fresco dining area). The thin-crust pizzas are made to order, while the pastas are handmade. Dont miss the chewy crumbed fried mozzarella sticks; creamy spaghetti carbonara; and wondrously fragrant thick pasta loops tangled with roughly torn chunks of pork sausages. Even the crème brûlée rises above the rest with a hit of lemon and toasted pine nuts. The regulars streaming in to pick up their takeaway boxes of pizzas tell the story.

Serangoon may be a bit of a hike for some, but well go far for authentic Indonesian chow, chai-beng style. Prima Rasa takes up a little corner of a block of HDB suburban shops, but behind its glassed-off counter is a treasure trove of brilliantly executed dishes, including sweet-and-sour fish thats neither soggy nor cloyingly sweet; curry chicken swathed in a turmeric-scented golden gravy; and sambal kangkong with just the right amount of bite and chilli heat. Even the humble omelette is especially fluffy and fragrant with caramelised onions. Bonus: if you dont do au naturel dining, theres an air conditioned room to the side.

Ma Maison all timber panelling and faux Tiffany table lamps is a hit among the new restaurants crowding The Central. The garlic bread is a thick slab of crisp baguette with just the right amount of butter and garlic, while the novel-sized cut of sirloin steak is cooked exactly as ordered (an unusual occurrence in this town). A highlight is the huge mound of garlicky, buttery rice blanketed by a lava flow of perfectly prepared omelette, the entire concoction sitting on a shallow pool of intensely beefy stroganoff. Bookings are essential on weekends.

At Seven, Mediterranean cuisine meets South America via a partnership with local stalwart Brazil Churrascaria. This translates into French, Italian and Spanish dishes, such as prosciutto and spicy poached pear, butternut squash and ricotta filled ravioli, roast rack of lamb, and sea bass with anchovies and dill pesto. Carnivores can fill up on lamb, beef, chicken and pork grilled on skewers, and cut straight on to the plate in slivers tableside.

One of the early tenants in the Wessex colonial lifestyle hub off Portsdown Road, Palate Sensations is a hands-on cooking school with instructors from famed local restaurants as well as ethnic cuisine experts. The types of cuisine taught here include French, Italian and Asian (such as Thai, Chinese and Japanese). Its pastry classes are popular and there are also basic mixology and drinks-making classes. Its 30-seater studio is available for booking, with and without chef services.

Its no surprise that the compact menu is almost exclusively meat-based. The steaks are cooked and served on fragrant oak planks a technique favoured by South Americans and apparently the first of its kind in Singapore and accompanied by grilled vegetables and fries. With the most expensive item on the menu being the filet mignon $36 for a 160g slab and $42 for the 220g cut expect a fairly substantial meal that wont have you thinking nervously of your wallet the way an outing to Mortons does. The mushroom linguine, of all things, is unexpectedly good.See our feature on Prime Society.

The cooking is complex but not showy, with every dish an example of the fabulous chemistry of spices and aromatic vegetables Indian meals are famed for. Plan your meal around a carb-based dish like a pile of darkhued naan, flecked with mint, or a biryani. Pair the carbs with a coconut-infused Keralan fish curry; Lucknawi Burra kebab meaty lamb chops, marinated and cooked in a thick crimson gravy of tomatoes and ginger; and Ajwaini Machli tikka thick fish cubes, spiced and lashed with lemon before being plunged into a hot tandoor oven.

You have to love a café that claims to serve honest to goodness home cooked food, healthy salads and plenty of smiles. The Nutella cupcakes and flourless almond cakes at the entrance are a good start, and the compact menu is warmed by dishes inspired by local ingredients. Theres slowroasted shredded pork, crisp pork crackle and a sweet potato sandwich drizzled with barbecue sauce; lychee and sage freeze; a Chinese Caesar salad of ginger poached chicken, sesame soy dressing and dark soya-braised eggs; and a silky shiitake mushroom fennel soup. No service charges or GST.
Main courses from $6.50

You may or may not choose to believe fans who claim this is one of the best Italian eateries in town, but theres no denying the calibre of the cooking. It begins with the fluffy, cheese-filled soufflé bread and continues through a menu of pastas, seafood and meats. Marquee attractions include pink salmon wrapped around a tian of sweet crabmeat, a nicely peppered and perfectly seared cod, and excellent basil-infused angel hair showered with chunks of lobster meat. The chocolate fondant is a lush, bittersweet foil for the rum ice cream.Main courses $26-52.

Expect Filipino staples at this joint, every dish cooked with fidelity for a clientele of expats. The inasal na manok is grilled to a mahogany char, its flesh sweetened by a marinade of garlic, lemongrass, calamansi, coconut vinegar and ginger, and its skin basted with annatto oil (a peppery, sweet infusion of annatto, a Filipino spice), bay leaves and garlic. The ensaladang talong is particularly outstanding: wondrously smoky strips of grilled eggplant, drenched with a mix of sharp coconut vinegar and raw, crushed garlic. Easily the next best thing to schlepping to Manila.

For a shop that calls itself Know ItNothing, the owners definitely know athing or two about the hottest labels fromaround the blogopshere. Those of you whoare familiar with NewDandyism.com willrecognise most of the designers this shopcarries. Located in the historic enclave ofKampong Glam, the first floor focuseson clothing and accessories. Art-fashionlabels including COLAB Eyewear, Cutlerand Gross, Surface 2 Air and Still Life NYCdecorate its stark interior. On the second storey, a gallery of shoes by Kim Jones,Nike, Reebok and New Balance tempts youto run away with more than just one pair.While youre browsing, strike up a conversationwith friendly owner Suraj. Hell be morethan happy to clue you in on the brands hecarries, as well as whats up-and-coming.

Get your fix of old-skool wallpaper fromPluck on Haji Lane. Sourced from Europeand priced between $60 to $100, most ofthe rolls are one-offs, so make sure that theone youve picked is enough to cover allyour wall requirements.

If youre bored with Orchard Road onthe weekends, its time you relive yourchildhood days and go kite flying. Contraryto the paper kites you fashioned as a kid,the rage these days are remote-controlledkites that dont need the wind. Purchaseone at GoFlyKite owner Michael Lim hascreated more than ten designs of remotecontrolledkites, each with a distinctcharacteristic and performance value.

Asias first indoor golf lounge provides a simulated round of golf on the worlds most famous courses. Try St Andrews or PebbleBeach, or just practise on the driving range with a PGA pro providing guidance. Your personal caddie will cater to your food and drink requirements. Throw in a TV screen for live sport and iPod facilities for your own musical selection and your session will fly by. Walk-in rates are priced from $125 per hour and personal memberships at $350 per month the venue is always privately booked for you. Individually or with a group of up to 30 people, just book in advance.

The largest unofficial centre of worship for local Muslims, but visitors are welcome to enter (except during prayer services, so avoid Fridays). Look for the curious features at the base of the dome, which is composed of many glass bottles.

The highlight of this privately owned orchid garden, established in 1951, is the stunning view of an orchid-filled hillside. Over 200 varieties, including the national flower Vanda Miss Joachim, are cultivated here, and its gift-wrapped orchids are cheaper than in the city centre. But its probably only worth a trip if youre a keen horticulturist or also visiting nearby Singapore Zoo.

Popular with photographers and wedding couples, this tranquil garden has a good bonsai collection, and various pavilions and pagodas in the northern Chinese imperial style. The best times to visit are during Chinese New Year (usually January or February) and the Mid-Autumn Festival (September or October), when cultural performances are held and the gardens are lit up at night like a fairyland by hundreds of beautiful and ornate paper lanterns. Dont miss the unusual Live Turtle & Tortoise Museum, containing 180 turtles and more than 3,000 turtle-related items collected by the museums owner and his daughter. The adjoining Japanese Gardens are currently undergoing renovation and should reopen some time in 2007.Turtle & Tortoise Museum $5. No credit cards.

Established in 1852, the Gardens are a tranquil respite from the city buzz. Highlights include the National Orchid Garden with the worlds largest collection of orchids some 1,000 species and 2,000 hybrids, including the national flower, Vanda Miss Joaquim. There is also a swan lake where visitors can feed the black Australian swans, and the Evolution Garden Walk, a well-landscaped plot containing the fossilised remains of ancient trees. During weekends, tours to its rainforest patch are available, while outdoor concerts are often held at Symphony Lake.Botanic Gardens were included in our recent One Night Stand feature. Things to Do Edible and Medicinal Plants Tour
Every first Sat; 9am & 10am
Let volunteer guides lead you to exquisite plants that you can place on your dinner table. Register 15 minutes before the tour at the Visitor Centre.
 Rainforest Tour
Every second Sat; 9am, 10am, 11am & 4pm
This guided tour will expose you to the islands expanses of luscious tropical rainforest. Register 15 minutes before the tour at the Visitor Centre.
 National Orchid Garden Tour
Every third Sat; 9am, 10am, 11am & 4pm (in Mandarin)
Find out facts that are every bit as colourful as the petals themselves on this guided walk through the garden. Register 15 minutes before the tour at the Visitor Centre.
 Evolution Garden Tour
Every fourth Sat; 9am
This tour tells the story of how plants evolve into the myriad and complex life forms we see today. Register 15 minutes before the tour at the Visitor Centre.Photo courtesy of the Singapore Tourism Board

Suns high ceilings, stonework, steel finishes and woodsy trims are a slick background for the unfussy, bang-for-your-buck Japanese menu. The restaurant is making a name for its unusual seasonal offerings, such as vegetables from Kyoto and seafood from Hokkaido, though these are usually available only at dinner. For lunch, set-menu favourites include the fried chicken nuggets and broiled salmon set, and the tempura, tofu and salad set. We're also partial to the maguro avocado maki, here presented in a translucent sheet of rice paper, and the delicious juice made from Kyoho grapes
Far East Square's newest pizzeria.
(Entrance via 16A Haji Lane)

Now class, put away your textbooks and make a beeline to Tuckshop. During the day, it opens its front doors to people who are looking for a good steak sandwich or a quick pick-me-up. In the evening, the back door beckons those who relish the underground club music scene. Music nerds are more than welcome, as the resident DJs play a raw mix of deep jazz, soul, funk, hip hop and electro house. As space is limited, you might find yourself with your back against the wall on a busy night. Devoid of formulas and clichéd riffs, Tuckshop is the perfect hangout for those tired of the masses.Tuckshop is also listed as a restaurant.

Located at the historic Istana Kampong Gelam, nine galleries trace the history of the Malay community from the days of the earliest settlers and the sea faring might of the Bugis villagers to the golden years of the Malay entertainment industry. Exhibits include regalia of Malay royaltyand artefacts. The centre also offers batik and pottery-making workshops ($10) and occasional cultural shows (adults $10, children $5).

This fascinating museum, locatedwithin the Chinese Garden, featuresmore than 200 live turtles and tortoisesfrom over 60 different species, includingthe snake-necked tortoise, the alligatorsnappingturtle and the extremely raretwo-headed, six-legged turtle. Managedby the collectors, a father-and-daughterteam who are often on hand to greetvisitors, the museum also displays morethan 3,000 turtle-related items such as toys,ornaments, tableware and even furniture.

Housed within three restored shop houses, 15 galleries feature the rich history and cultural heritage of Chinatown, including the story of Chinese immigrants who came to find work in Singapore during the colonial days. Highlights include rooms replicating coolies living quarters and clan associations activity halls prominent in those times.

This $59m, five-storeyBuddhist complex is a house of worshipand a few museums rolled into one. Locatedon the third storey is the Buddhist CulturalMuseum, that displays a selection of rareartefacts detailing the history of Buddhismand the different traditions practised inAsian countries. On the same floor, locatedat the rear of the hall, youll find the Sacred Buddha Relics Chamber. This houses whatare regarded as the Brains, Blood, Muscleand Flesh Relics of Buddha. Accordingto the religions beliefs, these items aresupposedly Buddhas body in eternal form.They generally come in three sizes akin toa mustard seed, rice grain or kidney bean and are usually in the colours of white(denoting bone), gold (flesh) and orangey-red(brain). A must-see is the 15-foot MaitreyaBuddha that sits on the ground floor of themain hall. Prayers are conducted at 8amdepending on a specific deitys birthday.

Nestled within the hillside close to Fort Canning Centre in Fort Canning Park, the Battle Box was the largest underground military operations complex on the island during World War II. Now you can walk through its 22 rooms, some of which still contain the original bunkers, and see the re-creation of the British surrender to the Japanese as told via wax figurines, video and audio effects.To help you feel like you were there, air-raid sirens and bomb blasts go off around you.

This impressive Gothic edifice was built by Indian convict labourers and consecrated in 1862. The original church (another of George Drumgoole Colemans creations) was replaced by a neo-classical building that was pulled down in 1855. In 1870, St Andrews became a cathedral, and has played a central role in Anglican mission work in the region ever since. Despite the flashy new glass Welcome Centre, its not really a showpiece. The transepts are more redolent of small-town English church halls than a grandiose cathedral, while the nave, with its ceiling fans and scattered supplicants, gives the sense that this is a working church. Brass wall plaques tell tales of personal suffering and professional sacrifice (it is striking how many of those commemorated died young), and guided tours highlight distinctive features, such as the Coventry Cross behind the pulpit (made from nails from the bombed ruins of Coventry Cathedral in 1940).
content.openingtimes: Guided tours 10.30am-4.30pm Mon, Tues, Thur-Sun; 2.30-4.30pm Wed

content.description: The first and still the largest regional library, the Woodlands Regional Library is located within a stones throw of Woodlands MRT Station. Occupying four levels of the Woodlands Civic Centre, it also houses a 250-seat auditorium in the basement, as well as a performance stage and 20-seat AV appreciation for public screening of TV programmes. The library is nature-themed and has a special focus on children with their own features-galore Reading Park. It has the largest collection of Chinese and Malay books.

This branch of The Coffee Connoissueur features an art gallery on the second floor with regularly changing exhibitions. The usual massive choice of coffee is available in the ground floor coffee shop or the gallery.
content.openingtimes: Sun-Thurs & PH - 11 to 12amFri, Sat & Eve of PH - 11 - 2am

content.description: This mammoth, Japanese-owned department store inside the huge Ngee Ann City mall carries all the chi-chi fashion labels that appeal to the rich tourists who frequent the place. Big fashion names Cartier, Gucci, Georg Jensen, Bulgari, Fendi and so on dot the shop with mini replicas of their larger flagship stores. Expect jostling for the latest Dior bag or Hermès scarf.
Stretch for free at Spaboutique - just show your copy of TOS (Apr 2010) and enjoy one complimentary KRYOGA or Tantra Yoga class all month.

The folks at Pelangi Pride Centre offer a neutral and friendly space to explore your sexuality. With regular talks, screenings and other group activities (we're not talking swinging parties here), they also operate a resource library devoted to HIV education and GLBTQ issues. Books may be borrowed for a small, returnable deposit. Newly relocated to DYMK!
For more information, email pelangipridecentre@yahoo.com.
LaSalle has the regions only integrated arts campus offering a wide range of BA (Hons) and MA degrees.

Jalan Bahar Clay Studios is not only a part of Singapores pottery heritage, but also home to a community of potters, ceramic artists and clay sculptors. Every first Sunday of the month, the JBCS artists welcome anyone with an interest in pottery to make or paint a piece and take it home for a minimal fee. Coffee, tea, cold drinks, cakes and snacks will be on the menu. Events are also held at the studios, check the website for details.

Gallery Eighty strives to provide a platform for contemporary art to thrive on a global level. Boasting a selection of paintings, sculptures, photography and installation art, this space is constantly aiming to reach audiences beyond the shores of Singapore by fostering international partnerships through collaborations with foreign galleries.
content.openingtimes: Tue-Fri 10am-6pm, Sat 1-4pm. After hours by appointment only.

content.description: Photo: Grace TanFOST lends itself as a space for showcasing some of the best photography and modern art exhibitions in Singapore, collaborating with various art bodies such as Timothy Yarger Fine Art from Beverly Hills.
content.openingtimes: Tue-Sat noon-7pm, Mon, public holidays & after hours by appointment only.

content.description: This gallery represents a number of contemporary artists from China, Indonesia and France.
See recognised international visual and new-media artists, as well as young artists from Singapore. This space is also affiliated with the Orita Sinclair Int'l Pte Ltd located next door.

entry.name: Art Space at the Royal Plaza on Scotts

version.name: Art Space at the Royal Plaza on Scotts

content.description: One of a few of Singapore's round-the-clock art spaces, this hotel venue is host to invited galleries showing a wide range of contemporary and more traditional art.
Get your fix of contemporary Chinese art at Art Seasons.

entry.name: Tan Tock Seng Hospital Heritage Museum

version.name: Tan Tock Seng Hospital Heritage Museum

content.description: Apart from telling thestory of the hospital, this space featuresPeranakan artefacts from the mid-1800s(including tiles from the original TTSHwards), medical equipment and hospitalartefacts, as well as the occasionalart exhibition. In the hospital atriumjust outside the museum, youll find acrystal installation, The Healing SkyGarden, part of TTSHs Art of Healingprogramme, which uses art to create aconducive environment for recuperation.

The Padang ('flat field' in Malay) was marked out in Raffles' original town plan as a recreation area, and so it remains, being the site of regular cricket matches and big public events. At the southern end in the Singapore Cricket Club, at the north, the Singapore Recreation Club.
Opened in 2002, Esplanade houses a number of theatre venues and hosts a very wide range of performances.

address.street: 583 Orchard Road, #02-03/04 Forum The Shopping Mall
583 Orchard Road, #02-03/04 Forum The Shopping Mall

entry.name: Centre Stage School of the Arts

version.name: Centre Stage School of the Arts

content.description: Every Sunday, the cafe transforms a room into a play area with PlayStation games, cartoon screenings, colouring tools and toys. Two adult minders watch the kids while grown-ups chill out.

address.street: 109 North Bridge Road #05-38 Funan DigitaLife Mall
109 North Bridge Road #05-38 Funan DigitaLife Mall

entry.name: New Mothers Support Group Gymboree Social

version.name: New Mothers Support Group Gymboree Social

content.description: Focusing mainly on food-based activities, kids engage in learning through baking, icecream- making and other delicious tasks. Enrichment programmes range from popular Kidz Can Bake workshops to Tshirt designing and the ambitious Little Entrepreneurs Camp, which allows kids to experience running a real business.
content.openingtimes: Opening times vary. Go to the website for more information.

content.description: Budding IT pros learn video-game design,robotics, animation and digital art at thisfive-day technology and creativity camp runby the Childrens Technology Workshop.Dont worry, its not all geeky fun. The kidswill also get to run around away from thecomputer. Hows that for mind-body balance?

By using something as apparently insignificant as the humble stamp as a springboard into Singapores past, the Philatelic Museum is more successful at recounting the history of the country than other more wide-ranging museums. The displays some permanent, others changing are well presented, and interactive enough to keep younger visitors engaged. Its also a working post office: where better to fire off a few postcards of your own?

The Singapore story is vividly brought to life in this centres five galleries of interactive and multi-sensory exhibits. Highlights include the Visionarium, the worlds first and largest interactive design studio with a 360-degree wrap-around screen,and the iWERKS Theatre, a flat-screen theatre that projects conventional and 3D giant screen movies. You can also take a bus tour from here to the SAFTI Military Institute, the training ground for Army, Navy and Air Force officers. Costs: $10; children $6
content.openingtimes: 9.00am-6.00pm (Closed on Mon, except public or school holidays)

content.description: This unique housemuseum focuses on the owners decades-oldcollection of personal memorabilia such asbooks, calendars, table lamps, tablewareand teapots, which display the richness ofSingapores diverse cultures and artefactswhich date back to the early twentieth century.

address.street: National Univer45 Science Drive 2, Block S6
National Univer45 Science Drive 2, Block S6

content.description: This descendant of the original RafflesMuseum established in 1849 by SirStamford Raffles (the founder ofSingapore and a renowned naturalist)contains the oldest and largest animalcollection from the South-East Asianregion, with more than 400,000 cataloguedspecimens. Key attractions include a 19thcenturyturtle from Siglap and a 4.4m kingcobra from the Central Catchment area.More than 20,000 plant specimens foundwithin the region are also on display.

Owner Marvin Chan shows off his personal collection, and hes often around to guide visitors through. The toys date back asfar as the 1910s and include a electric tin tramand a comic featuring the popular San Maocharacter from the 1930s.

Ten per cent of the owners 50,000-strong collection of toys is on display for your viewing pleasure.See our feature 'Toy's story'Costs: Various family packages (two adults and two children $36; three adults and one child $42

Situated in a two-storey shophouse, the upstairs screening room is equipped with 20 sofas, Blu-Ray projection and surround sound. Spending a minimum of $5 at the first-floor cafe gives you access to the films. Check the website for specific screening times.Pitch Black was included in our recent One Night Stand feature.

Not many places in Singapore offer you a chance to lie back on a deckchair (albeit a slightly flimsy plastic one) right by the river while you take swigs from a mug of cold beer. But at this very casual hangout you can do just that. Run by the Robertson Quay Hotel, this oddly named beach bar is exactly how an unpretentious, unfussy beach bar should be the only problem is that it doesnt quite have anything remotely resembling a beach next to it. But hey, who are we to complain? Its a relaxing spot away from the hustle and bustle of Clarke Quay, which is just a stones throw away, and a decent place to watch the sun set behind the condos around the neighbourhood. If beer is not your thing, try their surprisingly well-mixed Singapore Sling. But dont blame us if you get mistaken for a tourist.

Looked after by bookworms Kenny Leck and Karen Wai, BooksActually stocks both fiction and non-fiction titles. Narrative and theoretical books in the disciplines of philosophy, psychology, anthropology, political science, history, biography, mathematics, science, travel, food, art, photography and film.
For those who digests the likes of Murakami, Sweeney, Capote, Salinger and Nabokov, bring your appetites and dollars.
Theres also an assortment of desirably retro, non-literary oddities to peruse, including old-school film cameras and typewriters. Monthly exhibitions also take place so go to their website for regular updates.

This bookshop is a regular haunt for graphic designers and illustrators, stocking the best and newest in disciplines, from graphics and architecture to fashion and animation. There are regular discounts offered on specialised magazines and publications. And if you can’t find what you’re looking for, leave your name, number and desired title(s) and you’ll be notified once it arrives.
You wont find too many specialist titles, but there are newly released paperbacks on the weeks New York Times best-seller list.

Crammed with thousands of books, this tiny shop may seem daunting, but the well-read staff seem to have every title at their fingertips. Books from best-sellers to classics to romance come new or secondhand, and customers can rent or purchase. The fantasy selection is hard to beat.

address.street: 391 Orchard Road, Tower B, Ngee Ann City
391 Orchard Road, Tower B, Ngee Ann City

content.description: With so many titles across so many genres (in English,Japanese, Chinese, German and French), thisJapanese book giant’s computerised booksearch stations are a blessing. Get your doseof manga here, too.

content.vendor-category: Books | Good spots to read and eat
content.description: Coffee and a fine selection of Taiwanese tea lubricate walk-in pedestrians looking for respite in Pasir Ris. They may find enlightenment before leaving this friendly cafe is run by the Buddhist Tzu Chi Foundation to aid the spiritual development of society without preaching. Books for browsing and sale are by Still Thoughts Culture and other nondenominational spiritual publications.

entry.name: Singapore Association of the Visually Handicapped

version.name: Singapore Association of the Visually Handicapped

content.description:
Members of the Singapore Association of the Visually Handicapped (SAVH) have access to braille and audio books, music CDs and Infomag, a weekly audio newspaper. Volunteers how about narrating books and news articles for the Audio Production Unit? 
Visually handicapped members $5, sighted members $15 per year.

Designated as a national monument in 2006, the first auto assembly plant in South-East Asia was also the place where British Forces surrendered Singapore to the Japanese army in 1942. Its now a museum which, through pictorial exhibits and film documentaries, details just how residents in Singapore and Malaya lived during the Japanese Occupation.

Ever wondered how Singapore's Chinatown is different from, say, Cuba's? Find out through the pictorial and interactive exhibitions at this centre, which specialises in the studies of Chinese communities outside China. The building it's in - the structurally stunning Administration Building of the former Nanyang University - has been designated a national monument.

One of Singapore's largest and most impressive museums, ACM Empress Place has 11 galleries showcasing more than 1,300 artefacts from the civilisations of China, South-East Asia, South Asia and West Asia. ACM Armenian Street, currently under renovation, will reopen as a Peranakan Museum in 2008.

Youll find popcorn at the Screening Rooms movie theatre truffle salsa popcorn, to be exact. But dont expect any finger food at the posh bistro, a ground-floor dining room decked out with chandeliers and a central bar.The restaurant is a Mediterranean sequel to owner Samia Ahads blockbuster Persian-Asian original, Coriander Leaf in Clarke Quay. Try the escabeche of red mullet; the fish is flash-fried and marinated in lemon, making for a deliciously tart, tender white fillet on salad greens. Also recommended is the chicken tagine with whole preserved lemons and olives, richly infusing the slow-cooked stew with a piquant after taste.

Warm salad of roasted pigeon breast and leg with candied walnut, julienne of green apples and lamb salad ($38).Low-temperature-roasted Guinea fowl with braised chicory leaf, Parma ham, roasted pear puree and white wine reduction ($48).
Roast venison striploin with spices and cassis sauce, country vegetables and mushrooms ($60 as a main or $138 for five-course tasting menu).

Char-grilled kangaroo loin on sautéed garlic flower, mushroom and potatoes with a miso-plum sauce ($38).Spatchcock broiled mustard marinated baby chicken on a mushroom ragu with roasted potato, roasted Japanese pumpkin, haricot vert and vine-ripened tomatoes ($28).

Our recent Friday night visit to a packed dining room told the story, and the robust Italian chefs dashing about behind the glassed-off kitchen were a reassuring sight. Now that La Braceria has closed (while looking for new premises), Borgo is our new favourite spot for home-made pastas (including the rarely seen, ear-shaped orecchiette) and sausages. The menu is cheap, classic and no-frills, and served in hearty portions, like parpadelle with a rich wild boar sauce streaked with basil, a zesty eggplant parmigiana and wonderful thin-crust pizza topped with meaty discs of sausages. Round it all off with a perfectly done chocolate almond cake.

Sure the wines are youngish at Wine Connection, but they come at bargain-basement prices (did someone say $25 a bottle?). Take one along to any of the nearby restaurants to wash down your dinner, the small corkage fee with Wine Connections low prices are still a lot less than forking out for a bottle off the menu.Wine Connection was included in our recent Hitting the bottle - Three undiscovered gems feature.
content.openingtimes: Sun - Thurs 10am-12mn; Fri, Sat & PH eve 10am 2am

content.description: Tucked away at the back of Holland Village is Indochines Siem Reap, otherwise known as Siem Reap I (not to be confused with Siem Reap II, which is on the waterfront). This cosy drinking nook has a dark interior perfect for unwinding away from the more bustling section of Lorong Mambong. Of course, thats only when its not soccer season, when the bar turns into a roaring madhouse. It houses Singapores first water bar offering customers a range of natural, sparkling and flavoured agua which strikes us as a little pretentious, considering itswell, water. One more strike against the planet.

This well-kept secret is a gold mine, with its stock of more than 100 sake labels (by the bottle or decanter). Its good for the connoisseur, as well as for those who just need an excuse to shout kanpei! unself- consciously every now and then.

The tasty frozen concoctions at Margaritas are available with premium tequila labels such as Gran Patrón Platinum, and are served in a funky cactus-shaped glass complete with a little Mexican hombre lounging against the stem.

Great for a casual dining or brunch either in the small-ish air conditioned inside area or at one of the shaded tables overlooking the river.At the reservations-only wine-and-cheese nights, held every second Thursday of the month, you pay just $30 for four full glasses or eight half glasses, plus cheese and antipasti.Epicurious was featured in our recent Morning Glory - Best Western Breakfasts feature.Epicurious won Best Breakfast in our Who is top of the Table? feature.
At eM by The River it’s easy to chill out, as you lounge in plush, sink-in couches.
Barely legal heartlanders converge at Dbl 0 for three things: cheap premium booze (housepours as low as $3 a pop), thumping dance tunes and lots of weekend action.

Tiki torches light the entrance to Dempsey’s Hut, where tables sprawl out on a wooden deck under a canopy of intertwined branches. Fans and the loud hum of crickets provide a more natural breeze than your run-of-the-mill, air-conditioned joints.Dempsey's Hut was included in our recent Eye on the ball feature.

Coffee Bar K glows golden from the number of whisky bottles stocked on its bar shelves, covering the greatest labels from Scotland, Japan, Ireland, Canada and the US, served over handshaved ice cubes in Baccarat glasses.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Fri 6pm-3am; Sat & holiday eve 6pm-4am; Sun & holidays 6pm-2am.

content.description: The specialty here is charcoal barbeque, Korean-style and the Korean regulars vouch for the authenticity of the place. The orders of meats (try the prime rib) arrive at the table in neat trays. Diners then cook meat on the wells of hotplates at the table. It can get rather smoky, so dont wear your best Chanel to lunch. If all that sounds like too much hard work, opt for the à la carte menu, including tender chunks of pork cooked in a spicy, vinegarish kim-chi stew.

entry.name: Cha Cha Cha Mexican Restaurant & Bar

version.name: Cha Cha Cha Mexican Restaurant & Bar

content.description: Seekers of all that is good and Mexican should tread lightly at Cha Cha Cha while the margaritas are deliciously potent and mixed with fine Sauza tequila, the food isnt quite as authentic as youd hope. The portions are by no means stingy, but theres something about the combination and proportions of cheese and spices (like cumin and ancho chili powder) that doesnt do the trick. Not to mention that Mexican food is traditionally cooked in good old-fashioned lard a no-no in the increasingly health-conscious F&B industry which might be one reason the Cha Cha Cha fare isnt as good as it could be.

address.street: 211 Holland Avenue, #04-01 Holland Road Shopping Centre
211 Holland Avenue, #04-01 Holland Road Shopping Centre

content.description: Even the most regular visitors to Holland Village may not know Café 211 exists its hidden atop the Holland Road Shopping Centre. The fare is considered Australian with an Italian touch think mushroom ravioli, risotto, and lamb chops. A scenic rooftop location is almost always an asset for a restaurant, but unfortunately the inconsistent service and inexperienced staff put a damper on things. On the upside, Café 211 offers a range of credit-card specials from AMEX to Citibank.

BQ Bar is the post-work bolthole for boozing English banker boys, which in turn attracts an assortment of underdressed, giggly chicks who love that sort of thing.Dharma's Kebabs at BQ Bar were included in our recent Menu Updates feature.

Despite its low profile, Archipelago bears the distinction of being Singapores first commercial brewery, established back in 1931. The company now channels its efforts into making freshly brewed craft beers for the discerning drinker. With a roster of six signature ales including the dark, creamy Java and refreshing Straits Pale, award-winning brewmaster Fal Allen has raised the bar for local beer standards. Patrons are encouraged to appreciate the subtleties of each brew rather than the standard chug-a-jug approach. And with daily happy hours until 8pm, theres no time for sulking.

We all know how therapeutic art can be to some people. Glenns Studio wants to share that same benefit and blessing to one and all. It functions mainly as a therapy centre, using art as a medium with yoga classes and motivational talks on the side, but its gallery displays expressive works by some of the regions up-and-coming as well as established artists.

Settle back for some of the best Thai food in Singapore at crazy, cheap prices. The food here is of restaurant standard, but at cafe costs. The menu is small, yet crammed with delicious green curries; tart tom yam made not from bottled paste, but with fresh herbs and seafood stock; crisp pork chops; mango salad and a really good belachan fried rice.

Its hard not to feel like one of the good ol boys when you walk into Mortons, a raucous haunt tucked away on the fourth floor of the Mandarin Oriental. This is where men come to loosen their ties, get drunk on wine and stuff themselves with oversized portions of meat and potatoes. If it sounds distinctly American, thats because it is this is one of five international branches of an awardwinning chain that originated in Chicago 30 years ago. Mortons boasts the best steak anywhere, which seems a hard tagline to live up to. The Chicago-style bone-in ribeye steak, cooked medium rare, made me think this may be true. The cut had the most flavour and was so tender it practically liquefied in your mouth. Also notable was the legendary hot chocolate cake, topped with fresh raspberries and powdered sugar, and oozing melted chocolate fudge.

Marutamas specialty is the thin Japanese noodle ramen in one of four soup bases (chicken, spicy chicken, prawn or nuts). The soups are mildly flavoured and almost caramelin tone, an ideal template for the wheaty flavour of the ramen. Be sure to order side dishes, like Kakuni (thick glistening wedges of pork belly stewed in a mellow soy sauce) and dashimaki tamago (a thick roll of omelette, seared briefly on the pan and collapsing on the tongue like a puff of golden air).

address.street: 25 Scotts Road, Royal Plaza on Scotts
25 Scotts Road, Royal Plaza on Scotts

content.description: Anotherround-the-clock gallery, showing South-EastAsian contemporary and abstract art.
Raffles Amrita Spa tackles fatigue and weariness with its Garden of Love package designed to rejuvenate and recharge your senses.

This Chinese-themed foot reflexology retreat is a welcome alternative to the usual back-to-basics parlours dotted about Singapore. The extra-roomy massage chairs come specially imported from China and even have mini television sets attached. Nice. Before you begin your massage, your feet will be treated to a soak (instead of just a wipe down) and afterwards, youll receive a thorough neck and shoulder massage ($69).

Best known for its Traditional Chinese Medicine techniques, chromatherapy (holistic healing through colour therapy) and Swiss herbology, this cosy haven has recently acquired the right to utilise the award-winning Comfort Zone brand of products and treatments. One recommendation is the Aromascrub ($150), which lets you choose the grain that fits your skin type, followed by a body massage. Bliss.

The first and only wine-themed spa in Singapore allows customers unlimited glasses of red before, during and after treatment. Based on vinotherapy, the different remedies are designed around grape seeds, grape-seed oil, skin, stalks and wine extracts. Its signature Vintage Spa Retreat ($108) starts off with a wine-infused bath soak, then includes a body scrub and massage. Along with the uplifting citrus scent, this package facilitates lymphatic circulation, aids detoxification and stimulates skins natural collagen production. After your treatment, youre encouraged to take advantage of the wireless network and surf away, while unwinding to yet another glass of red (hic!). Respecting its location in the Arab quarter, non-alcoholic treatments are also available.

Indulge in the ginger and tangerine scrub and the signature Egyptian sports massage combination for $128 (usual price $160) per person, or $238 for a couple.Otherwise, get prepped for the summer season with a back facial, where your back will be given a deep clean with a Dead Sea salt scrub, green clay mask and yes, even some extraction. Ouch! $68 (usual price $80).

Whats the best view when working out? We say hot guys. But the newly opened Body Club, the only beach-front gym in Singapore, seems to think sandy shores and blue waters (with oil tankers in the distance) offer the ultimate inspiration. We guess that could be nice too. The well-equipped gym has Kinesis cable system machines, aerobics, yoga, Pilates, kickboxing, martial-arts classes, and water-skiing and kayaking activities.

Instead of memorising dance routines, try Chakradance, a form of self-expression where you surrender to the music, dance in any manner and focus on how each chakra (energy centre) makes you feel. According to teacher David Cheah the only certified instructor in Singapore and Malaysia Chakradance is said to balance ones natural energy flows and help redis-cover unique body rhythms that have been suppressed or unexplored.

Skip the gym and pedal your way to work. The boutique offers a bike-lodging service with shower facilities, personal lockers and towels, so youll reach your office looking all clean and fresh. While youre at work, your two-wheeled beauty will be washed, de-greased and lubricated. The boutique also offers rentals and maintenance services and sells a range of related accessories and apparel.

Fans of high street brand River Island need not troop down to VivoCity to get their shopping done. The UK import has recently opened a store in Raffles City. With the same comfortable format as the VivoCity outlet (with strong emphasis on visual merchandising), River Island brings in new stocks of casual, yet stylish, skirts, pants, tops, dresses and shirts, chic accessories and a variety of footwear embellished open-toe sandals, trendy sneakers and platform wedges every two weeks. Giving in to runway copies has never been so easy.

Unlike skinny jeans, leggings or boho anything, vintage will never go out of style. So Dulcetfig are in the right business.The racks are filled with swing dresses, leather clutches and Glomesh bags that hail from the US, Australia and Europe and date back to the 1950s. The best part is that the selections are replenished every two to three weeks. Prices for accessories start from $20, handbags from $35 and clothes from $20. In addition, Dulcetfig also stocks the US-based label Anonymous Apparel, handbags from Australias OSK, and local accessories labels Tribe and Wicked Wax.
Erdos provides space in his furniture shop for up-and-coming artists.

Weve got so many orchids in this city, theres even one named after Ricky Shake Your Bon-Bon Martin.Its true! Pop down to the Singapore Botanic Gardens to check out theRenachilus Ricky Martin, along with the worlds largest orchid display(of course), with more than 1,000 species and 2,000 hybrids, includingour national fl ower the showy Vanda Miss Joaquim.

Located next to Takashimaya SC, Wisma Atria commands quite a bit of human traffic, mainly for the Topshop flagship, local jewellery boutiques Aspial and Lee Hwa, and a lively food court on the top level called Food Republic.

Though recently dethroned by VivoCity as the largest mall in Singapore, Suntec City is still so massive that shoppers are given pencil and paper to record the number of their parking space. Divided into four themed zones (Galleria, Tropics, Entertainment Centre and Fountain Terrace), it has over 350 shops and a barrage of eateries.

Surrounded by babbling birdbaths and pristine courtyards, well-heeled shoppers drop thousands at this semi-outdoor arcade at the iconic Raffles Hotel. Bespoke tailors, art galleries, rare antiques and luxury labels (Louis Vuitton, Tiffany) match the grandeur of the setting.

An East Coast institution for more than 20 years, Parkway Parade contains 250 shops spread over six levels. The boutiques are varied, charming and surprisingly urban. Rent a Kiddy Cab to appease the tots while you check out Katong Cuty, a quirky, old-school lingerie shop.

Upmarket Paragon is Singapores sleek epicentre of fashion. The new wing houses Gucci, Prada and Yves Saint Laurent boutiques, among others, while fine watch shops dot the old wing alongside younger fashion labels such as G-Star and Miss Sixty. Theres also a large Marks & Spencer, spas and beauty parlours, a gourmet supermarket (in the basement) and a couple of famous restaurants.

The choice venue for fashion shows and roadshows, this massive red granite building with two towers (A and B) is the lifeblood of Orchard Road, drawing throngs of locals and tourists. Its also known as Takashimaya Shopping Centre (aka Taka) after anchor tenant Takashimaya department store. It contains more than 130 shops, including Japanese giants Kinokuniya (books) and Best Denki (electronics), and over 30 food and drink outlets (from Indonesian to Korean). A branch of the National Library offers tomes for browsing, and a quiet café for rejuvenation.

Not too long ago, Marina Square was a dowdy mall, favoured by errant teenagers for its game arcades and middle-aged shoppers for its middle-aged offerings. After a makeover, its practically unrecognisable, with hip new boutiques, an array of eateries and a plush new cineplex.
Great World City is currently making a move upmarket with more fashion stores joining the numerous eateries and Golden Village cinema.

When it comes to street fashion, this grubby five-level mall just off Orchard Road is the spot, offering everything from common Korean imports to rare cult items such as $2,000 sneakers. Basically, the more decrepit the shop, the cooler it is. Sub-culture types flock here to stock up on clothes, scoff cheap but delicious food and get tattooed and pierced Far East Plaza has the largest concentration of tattoo parlours in Singapore.

So named because of its proximity to the bridge that links Singapore to Malaysia, Causeway Point is a typical suburban shopping mall. Expect the usual formula: cineplex, gaming arcade and a sprinkling of clothes and knick-knack shops that drive the heartlanders wild. Local department stores Metro and John Little, and supermarket chain Cold Storage, are anchor tenants.

Formerly Singapores red-light district, Bugis has been cleaned up and redeveloped. Straits-Chinese shophouses were glassed in to form part of this mall (also called Parco Bugis Junction), which contains Japanese department store Seiyu and plenty of teen-friendly shops. Of particular interest is the Edge, a collection of Japanese-inspired streetwear boutiques; purists dismiss it as a poor imitation of popular youth fashion destinations the Heeren Shops or Far East Plaza, but there are bargains. Bugis Junction's outdoor fountain is where you will often see drenched, screaming kids having a whale of a time. As the water comes from the floor and in various shapes and patterns, guessing where the next sprout will spurt from is half the fun.

Where?
Up a cobbled path, behind the boutique Berjaya Duxton Hotel, in a conservation shophouse area, tucked away off  Chinatown.
History?
This space used to be an architects office, but now its a wine bar one that shares a name with a bar in  the owners native South Australia. Otherwise there are no similarities between the two. The people behind the scenes are the same people behind the Denise Wine Shops sprouting like mushrooms all over Singapore, which explains the prominence of  Kaesler and Two Hands wines on the list, as they are the importers for them.Whats it like?
A place where you can finish the latest Patricia Cornwell while enjoying a glass of  wine its that brightly lit. The window side of  this long, narrow space is taken up by hard, white formica-like  banquettes hardly conducive to hunkering down for the night and ordering that second, third or fourth bottle. The bar is really the focal point of  the space with its mosaic-like back wall with prominent liquor-bottle display. The wines are stored in a glass unit towards the back of  the bar, but its much easier to just choose from the list. Unless you stare at the diners across at Broth, theres not much people-watching to do. Or any other kind of  distraction either. Other than filling our glasses, the staff  pretty much left us alone, spending more time at the modern French restaurant upstairs.
Who are the regulars?
While the Universal has yet to be discovered by the masses we were the only table on a Saturday night the set-up seems to target professionals who are interested in the quality of  the drinks and the company.
The drinks?
The 500 selections (including 20 by the glass) cover a large part of  the wine-producing world Australia, New Zealand, France, Spain and range from a heart-racing $8,200 for the 89 Petrus to $45 (a steal) for the 06 Rolf  Binder Semillon Hellions. The best deals here are the Aussie wines the list has 105 to choose from, with Rolf  Binder and Kaesler wines leading the pack, and though the flavours are big and bold, the prices arent. If  cocktails are more your scene, the Universal probably isnt. However, you will find the general managers own creation on the menu: the Bennetini ($25), a concoction of  Absolut Blue, Citron, Mandarin, Bombay gin, Bacardi rum with lychee liqueur, lemon juice, lime cordial and lychee syrup. Sweet.

Wine by the glass $13-$24; bottles $45-$8,200; cocktails $12-$25.

entry.name: The Gallery of Gnani Arts (Fortune Centre)

version.name: The Gallery of Gnani Arts (Fortune Centre)

content.description: This gallery is not only an exhibition space but also an establishment that specialises in curating and marketing art as well as actively participating in research and development on contemporary South Indian art.
Shaw Cinema at Jurong has six screens.
Golden Village Yishun has 10 screens.
Has 3D Digital halls.
Golden Village - The Grand has 6 screens and 3D Digital halls. It includes the fantastic Gold Class with reclining 'business class' seats, service and lounge. Located in Great World City.
Golden Village Bishan has 6 screens and 3D Digital halls.

entry.name: Eng Wah Toa Payoh Entertainment Centre

version.name: Eng Wah Toa Payoh Entertainment Centre

content.description: Eng Wah Cinema Toa Payoh features the new Director's Club seating.
Eng Wah Cinema Suntec City features the new Director's Club seating.
Eng Wah Cinema Sun Plaza features the new Director's Club seating.
Eng Wah Empress Cinema is currently being refurbished.

Jacobs has a local, village feel to it. You can seethat the regulars are part of the furniture here.But the trip is worth it because of the hearty,rustic soups ($4.20 for soup of the day, withfresh crusty rolls). Opt for the tomatoand basil soup its fragrant taste and thickconsistency make it a delicious, filling choice.

This filmmaking and photography hub was established in 2003 and has already garnered a huge following of enthusiasts wanting to further their knowledge in either craft. Besides holding regular courses and workshops, they also create awareness by organising photography exhibitions, film screenings and talks. And if thats not enough, this establishment spearheads Objectif Films in partnership with Infinite Frameworks and Shooting Gallery Asia. Together, they distribute the largest number of short films in South-East Asia and represent award-winning short films from our region.Go to the website for more information on courses and events.

An institute built for the cultivation of everything scientific. Features regular exhibitions promoting physical, life, applied, technology and industry sciences. The centre also has Singapores only dome-shaped theatre. The Omni-Theatre, is equipped with state-of-the-art IMAX dome technology. It is Singapores only dome-shaped, five-storey theatre with a capacity of 276 seats.Things to See at the Science CentreAmazing Electron
Electrons may be the things inside an atom with a negative charge, but their impact on our world has been hugely positive. Come find out how the humble particle has helped to create our first television set, telephone, radio and much more.Human Body
We use our body every day, but few of us know how it functions. This exhibition educates visitors on the complexities of our body structure, from the way the brain works to how the heart beats. While our intricate biology may be overwhelming to understand, you can make use of the interactive, audio and visual presentations for an engaging and comprehensive experience.Space Science
Intrigued by space, the universe and all things celestial? Journey through a galaxy of graphical representations of our solar system, as it provides you with an in-depth understanding of the world, outside the one we live in.The Minds Eye
Test your eyesight at this exhibition featuring a collection of optical illusions to see is to believe.Climate Change Exhibition
Visit the icy poles of the Earth, calculate your own carbon footprint, learn about eco-cities, discover the ingredients in the weather, and find out how our changing climate impacts farming, health and ecology at this exhibit.Living with Viruses
Through 3-D galleries, video documentaries and information panels, this exhibition fills you in on Singapores most notorious and potentially lethal viral afflictions of the last decade such as HIV, AIDS and SARS.Waterworks
Learn all you need to know about H2O in this fun-filled, open-air exhibition featuring 11 hands-on displays.iSpace
See what the world of tomorrow looks like today. This exhibition offers you the chance to see how hi-tech the home and office of the future will be.

entry.name: Sun Yat Sen Nanyang Memorial Hall

version.name: Sun Yat Sen Nanyang Memorial Hall

content.description: A pioneer of Chinas revolutionary struggle in the early 20th century, Dr Sun Yat Sen made numerous trips to South-east Asia; a sympathiser, Teo Eng Hock, turned over this villa to the cause. It was here in 1906 that Dr Sun formed the Singapore branch of the Chinese Revolutionary Alliance, and he would return several more times before his success in deposing the emperor in 1911 whereupon a new battle for the future of China began. The story told here fleshes out the political history of the Singapore Chinese, and makes a change from the more usual focus on migrant labour and World War II. While there are a few videos, replica objects and waxworks, the spacious halls and galleries are overwhelmingly reliant on captioned black and white archive photos. Next door is the Burmese Buddhist Temple, containing a 3m (11ft) marble Buddha, the largest Burmese Buddha image outside Burma.

Located within Haw Par Villa, this museum pays tribute to Chinese migrants who set up communities around the world. Using pictorial exhibits and multi-media displays, highlights include the From China to Chinatown section, which depicts how Chinese migrants adapted to foreign lands; the Grand Food Hall, which features realistic wax replicas of various Chinese cuisines; and En Ens Kitchen, a mock-up of a traditional Chinese kitchen where visitors can interact with the displays.

The most iconic of Singapores World War II sites, even though the museum is housed in a purpose-built venue, and the chapel is a reconstruction (the original was shipped to Australia after the war). The main interest lies in the stories of industry and ingenuity within the POW camp. The civilian and military internees essentially established an alternative, if somewhat surreal, society, catering for everything from entertainments to the manufacture of thousands of everyday items. Contact with the outside world was maintained through handmade and carefully disguised radios. The chapel, located in the courtyard of the museum, encourages quiet reflection. It also houses copies of the kitschy but affecting Changi murals, recreated by the original artist, Stanley Warren, after a widely publicised international effort to find him; the preponderance of blue and white is because of his reliance on billiard cue chalk. The $8 audio guide is pricey, but it is comprehensive and complements the displays well.

In an attempt to promote artistic ingenuity, the gallery which also acts as a consultant and supplier of fine art to government and corporate entities boasts collections by renowned Singaporean and Asian artists such as Chua Mia Tee, Goh Beng Kwan and Wan Soon Kam.
