Sculpture Square is a quaint, charming courtyard stuck in an impossibly noisy traffic junction. Nonetheless, its proven to be an ideal spot to be quietly inspired by unique sculptures.
Translated from Malay as window, this space does indeed provide a glimpse into attractive art from Singapore and across the shores.

The home of TheatreWorks, this former rice warehouse wears different masks to accommodate and play host to various arts events, be it a gallery, a cinema or a theatre. Through the International Centre of Asian Art (ICAA) and the Singapore Creative Arts Nucleus (SCAN), 72-13 is a space to encourage partnerships and residencies, and spark creativity by Singaporeans.

Sunjin exhibits a diverse mix of classicaland modern art by established and emerging artists. Sourced from across South-EastAsia and China, work includes figurative painting, abstract sculpture, mixed media installation and conceptual art.
Soobin features principally contemporary Singaporean and Chinese art including many of the big names of Chinas post-Tiananmen avant-garde.

Housing a wealth of pieces by some of the worlds most popular and revered artists, Opera Gallery is constantly presenting bigger pieces and shows to meet demand for the globally recognised. The new space will showcase a combination of contemporary art and masterworks from yesteryear by artists like Picasso.

With the increasing demand for, and interest in, contemporary Asian art, Linda Gallery, an active player in the industry for more than a decade, strives to regularly showcase works by China and South-East Asia's sought-after creative individuals.

A contemporary fine arts gallery that represents some of the most prominent and promising artists in Asia. They've showcased artists include Taiwanese Sculptor Ju Ming, Nobel Laureate Gao Xingjian and Cheung Yee, reputedly the pioneer of the modern art movement in Hong Kong.
This Jakarta-basedauctioneer works in tandem with Glerumauctioneers of the Netherlands. Severalsales held in Singapore and Jakarta eachyear feature South-East Asian, Chinese andIndian painting.
Established in 2004, this gallery provides Singapore artists an alternative and affordable art space.
An institute in its own league, the STPI is a expansive art space housing printing equipment and facilities, and has exhibited some of the biggest names in the print industry.

Established in 2004, this gallery serves as a platform for contemporary Indian art. Regular exhibitions are held featuring an extensive collection of paintings, drawings, prints, sculptures and even books.
content.openingtimes: Outram Park. Mon-Fri 11am-5pm, Sat, 4 & 11 Mar noon-4pm.

content.description: South-East Asian and international modern andcontemporary art; representing Singaporeanartist Ong Kim Seng.

Yisulangs rostercovers artists from all over China. Works ofart here embrace various genres, includingtraditionalism, modernism and postmodernism.Mo Tan Works by the Paris-basedSingaporean landscape painter. 13-27 Mar.

Since 1996, the gallery has been an active supporter of contemporary Asian art. Its collections and exhibitions by established artists from the region speak volumes of their expertise and knowledge of the area. Present works include those by Singaporean Jason Lim, and Indonesians Yunizar, Putu Sutawijaya and I Nyoman Sukari.
The top names of contemporary Indian art are shown in a vast white-cube gallery; additional branches in New York, Mumbai and New Delhi.

Vera Ong and Seah Tzi-Yan have represented some of South-East Asias best artists since 1991. They focus on contemporary sculpture, ceramics andpaintings, and are one of the few galleries to specialise in public sculpture.

This space showcases contemporary Indian art in as many new and different angles as possible. Its aim is to be an avenue for emerging artists to hone their craft while also supporting and promoting established veterans of Indian art. The gallery doubles or perhaps quadruples as a space to host art-related launches, discussions, workshops and other art-appreciation programmes to generate and develop the perception of modern Indian art.

Singapores oldest gallery is run by one of the industrys most colourful characters, Marjorie Chu. She has been instrumental in the art scenes development, helping to found the Art Galleries Association of Singapore and the ARTSingapore fair. The work is by predominantly regional artists.
The Pan Pacific has always been a supporter of the arts and it starts right outside the building with a sculpture entitled ‘Deva’ by Lin Emery.

This former Catholic boys school, a striking white building with two wings and long verandas, was revamped in the early 1990s when there was a policy of converting old colonial buildings into public museums. Because of its small, unusual and hidden gallery spaces, it has never held blockbuster shows. Instead, it specialises in smaller exhibitions, mostly 20th-century Asian visual art, often drawn from its own collection of South-east Asian pioneer art.

This two-storey shophouse space is filledto the brim with delicately designedvases and other glassware items thatmake perfect housewarming gifts andare sure to smarten up any mantlepiece orbar counter. The new summer collectionwill be available in eye-popping turquoiseand emerald green hues

This homewares and furniture shop isknown to stock bespoke pieces like handcutcrystal from David Redman, printedandmirrored-glass furniture by Knowlesand Christou, and Limoges porcelainfrom Harlequin. And it recently startedselling a range of Claus Porto soaps,which have been made in Portugal forover 117 years. Also new to the store arephotographs by famed lensmen RusselWong. A fi rst for the photographer whohas snapped Asias biggest celebrities,Zhang Ziyi, Ken Watanabe and JackyChan to name a few, were sure this will beone more reason to pop down to the store.

As well as stocking Scandinavian fashion labels like Nudie Jeans, Pour and Rodebjer, Style: Nordic has just recently opened its top floor to home-made HAG Seating Solutions and slick, oh-so-modern AlvarAalto stools. Showcased in a beautifully mocked-up offi ce space, complete with desks and all sorts of office paraphernalia, itll serve as inspiration for anyone looking to makeover a living space in chic, minimalist style. Also, keep an eye out for the collection of funky wallpaper with graphic prints, colourful candle holders and other miscellaneous decorations for the home.

While the striking plywood display shelfat the entrance of the newly opened Objetis not for sale, their unusual light fi xturesare. The shop can custom-make almostany other piece of furniture. So yes, owningan extra-long pony hair couch withsuede panels is entirely possible

Stocked with designer kitchen-accessorybrands like Chilewich from the USA andEisch from Italy, the store hawks simpleyet stylish items that clearly cater toindividuals whose aesthetic tastes runto unfussy silhouettes. A notable mentionare the Alussi cabinets, which havedoors that open up instead of out a niftyfeature that will surely work well in shoebox-size apartments

Cleverly lit dark-coloured walls beckonpassers-by to pop inside and sink into oneof the many handsome sofas on show.And if you think pieces like a grey couchwith stylish metal accoutrements lookmore at home in a swanky watering holethan a comfy lounge room, the boutiquesin-house designers can offer you a varietyof alternatives.

Specialising in furniture manufacturedin a distinct baroque style or classical-modern, as they like to call it thisis where to go if youre after burgundyhuedvelvet quilted sofas and gothic-lookingarmchairs. Other home accessoriesinclude crystal candlestick holders,quirky red acrylic goblets and moderncrystal chandeliers that have beensourced from around the region, whichmeans wallet-friendly prices.

ActuallyWeve already registered Actually asthe place to go for quality street chicfashion in Singapore. Since mid-April,four more brands have found a cosycorner in the boutique: Elvis Jesussfunky Ts flown in from the UK; streetlabel Headquarter by three Thai designers;18th Amendment from Australia;and RVCA, a collection of uniquelydesigned casual wear from the USA.Founded by a pair of brothers in 1993, Freitag creates cult bags made from tarpaulin. Not only is each item unique, the line is also selectively distributed: the boutique Actually is one of just three exclusive retailers of Freitag in Asia. The bags have inspired many copies like Demano and Kultbag (see below), but thats a good thing it signals that more people are recycling. A word of warning about the burned-rubber odour. Its unlikely that youll ever get rid of the smell, says Paul Khor, owner of Actually. Prices from $129 to $379.

Named after one of the best tennis players of the twentieth century, the Fred Perry clothing label is enjoying a revival of sorts. Inside the store on Ann Siang Road, youll find everything except its Comme des Garçons collaborative line. While the labels polo shirts have long been considered a wardrobe staple, the question is why they became so popular in the first place. The answer lies in its signature laurel logo based on the Wimbledon symbol which is stitched rather than ironed on; after all, beauty is in the small details. And, of course, its tennis gear is matchless.

Quirky and at times downright unbelievable, Rustic Nirvana has somehow found a following with its unusual chopstick-wielding spa techniques. Theres also a range of body massages that use semi-precious stones like smoky quartz and agate. But thats not their oddest offering: the Aventurine Green Claypot Prata therapy claims to lock in the heat using prata (yes, the crispy dough bread), while jamu herbs work on the body to reduce aches and pains. There are [fb01] ve locations, including one at Gleneagles Hospital, but the original at Cantonment road is still the best.

Sccube The Apothecary offers two special rejuvenating treatments for your body the organic facial ($128) which uses organic plant and fruit extracts, and the Rodion body spa treatment ($240) which features a Javanese massage followed by a radio frequency treatment.

Tucked in the suburbs of the Redhill housing estate and loved by the artsy and fashionable folks, this small boutique currently stocks pieces from both the mens and womens spring/summer 2007 collection. Check out the contrasting textured jackets, colour combinations of red, pink and mauve, and items sporting hardware details like studs and chains.

Following in the same vein, indie boutique Epitome stocks Kultbag. The German-made totes are fashioned out of used banners, truck tarpaulins, mail sacks, army blankets, car-tyre inner tubes and soft tops from convertibles. Predictably, no two of the 25-plus models are alike, and theres even a range of exclusives made specifically for the hipsters in Japan.

Australian designer Rachel Bending has been producing her ecological products since 2002. Her first label, SlingFlings, has bags, beach and home wares, and her new fashion label, Bird, is constructed out of cotton, linen and bengaline (a silk and cotton corded fabric) printed with water-based dyes. Even cooler, all her sewing machines in Byron Bay are solar-powered.

When Chris Lee first started The Asylum back in 1999, it was a design studio specialising in commercial graphics tints and branding packaging projects. By 2005, The Asylum had morphed into a retail shop where local designers went to display their wares. Today, The Asylum sells everything from limited edition Fred Perry sneakers, quirky Kubrick toys and Kwodrents hand-sewn pieces to monthly issues of Nylon and Surface and music CDs from obscure, experimental indie folk bands. In short, they dont quite fit into any conventional retail genre. Up next, we hear there are plans for a music label called Asylum Sounds, a potential in-house magazine and maybe even a book. Is there nothing they wont do?

Func DekoFar East Plaza may be made up ofinnumerable retail stores that seemto resemble one another, but FuncDecko stands out with its treasuretrove of whimsical offerings. Some ofour favourite fi nds: a toothpick holderreminiscent of a set of dentures andvintage wallpaper, which can no longerbe found anywhere else in Singapore.

The suit-wearing crowd should rejoicenow that Dotted Line is available at Swirl.Designer Dorothy Loh, an ex-bankerherself, is clearly clued in to the day-todayfashion needs of the offi ce workerand specifi cally turns out a limitedquantity of smart business attire so thatno one needs to look like theyre wearinga common company uniform.

For the bride who wants a gown witha slightly indie edge, theres Blu Mesh.Located on Bali Lane for more than fi veyears, owner and designer Corinna Kekprides herself on customising bridalwearat reasonable prices. In the past two yearsshes also started dabbling in makingone-off dresses ($90 to $180) with vintagefabric the results, delectable.

Reminiscing, nostalgia and familiarity are the underlying themes of Déjà Vu Vintage. Almost three years old, the store boasts the vibe of a (glass)house on the prairie with its collection of handpicked clothing and accessories redolent of the era between the 1940s and 1980s. The policy here is exclusivity only one of each piece exists. Luckily, the store carries everything from quirky sun dresses to chic cocktail numbers, psychedelic patterns to intricately woven details. Designer brands such as YSL, Gucci, Oscar de la Renta and Halston feature, as well as reworked pieces by local designers.

On Wednesdays, make like a mad thing at the dance phenomenon that is Mambo Jambo. At weekends, let yourself go to the music of international DJs like Sven Väth, Âme and Infected Mushroom. And if youre into music by the likes of The Rapture, Justice and Boys Noize, paint the town glow-in-the-dark with Zouks bi-monthly party, ReadySet Glo.See also Phuture at Zouk, Velvet Underground at Zouk and Winebar at Zouk.
Wed: men $25, includes two drinks, women free. Fri & Sat (before 10pm): $15, includes two drinks. Fri & Sat (after 10pm): men $28, women $23, includes two drinks. Prices vary for special events.

Going back to its roots, Velvet keeps it smooth with its new Balearic Thursdays. Back in the day, the decks of this intimate and exclusive club sampled the lovin touch of luminaries like Paul Oakenfold. Since its refurb last year, soul man Norman Jay and father of the Balearic beat DJ Alfredo have resurrected this style made popular in the late 80s and early 90s. And while youre grooving, take time to appreciate the works by pop-culture icons like Andy Warhol, Keith Haring and Takashi Murakami.See also Zouk Club, Phuture at Zouk and Winebar at Zouk.Tue-Sat: men $35, women $25, includes two drinks. Prices vary for special events.

This joint is an unabashed meat market on weekends. Sweaty bodies dominate the dance floor, gyrating to Top 40 remixes. Dont assume all the men here love Dorothy though, because plenty of women bring their boyfriends along for a boogie.

The name Phuture means everything experimental and quirky, and that it is. The most avant-garde of the three outlets in Zouk Club, this spaces unique music policy sees everything from break beats and hip hop to nu jazz. Original artwork by the likes of Massimo Iosa Ghini and Roy Lichtenstein decorates the wall of the long, undulating bar, not that many of its 18-25 year-old patrons would notice; theyre too busy bumpin and grindin.See also Zouk, Velvet Underground at Zouk and Winebar at Zouk. Wed: men $25, includes two drinks, women free. Fri & Sat (before 10pm): $15, includes one drink. (after 10pm): men $30, women $25, includes two drinks. Prices vary for special events.

A century ago, Telok Ayer Street was right up against the sea. And this temple, known as the Temple of Heavenly Happiness, was popular with newly arrived immigrants, who came here to burn incense in thanks to Ma Cho Po (a Taoist deity and protector of seafarers) for their safe arrival. Some of the materials used in the temple were taken from the boats, including the rooftop mosaic. Inside, the main altar features a statue of Ma Cho Po, and other deities of luck, war and punishment

entry.name: Conservatory Concert Hall, Yong Siew Toh Conservatory of Music

version.name: Conservatory Concert Hall, Yong Siew Toh Conservatory of Music

content.description: If you like live music performances (10pm until late), you can join the hordes of people packing this place. Practically bursting at the seams on weekends, youll be hard-pressed to even find a decent spot to stand in. But if you can manage the discomfort of feeling like a sardine in a can, start filling yourself up with some of the brews (five bottles of Erdinger, Corona Extra or Tiger go for $50, all night long) and youll be partaking in the rowdiness in no time. While the performers differ nightly, its songbird Michaela who always rouses the folk with her throaty vocals and mature deliveries of both crowd favourites and current chart-toppers. On quieter nights, when you can actually find a stool to rest your bum, kick back and bob along to the jazzy house tunes, at the same time appreciating the lovely and understated Peranakan-style decor.

Singapores largest museum re-opened in December 2006 after a $118 million makeover and comprises two main galleries: the Singapore History Gallery,which traces the history of Singapore from its beginnings in the 14th century to the present day, and the Singapore Living Galleries, which focus on four life-style themes food, fashion, film & wayang, and photography. They also have occasional film showings.
Image copyright National Museum of Singapore
content.openingtimes: Singapore History Gallery daily10am-6pm, Singapore Living Galleries daily10am-8pm.

content.description: As its name implies, this venue is quite rightly suited for those who stay up all night. It practically never sleeps and youll love the fact that the happy hour lasts from 11am to 9pm. Serving food in the day, it turns into a live music bar at night and appears to be very popular with the expatriate crowd. And thats probably thanks to the regular house bands (there are currently two, Chill Factor and Batteries Not Included, otherwise known as BNI) that crank up the entertainment factor by churning out contemporary and rock music. Lest you get bored of hearing the same stuff, Insomnia changes the bands every three months or so, so dont get too attached. And if you belong to the fly the friendly skies pack, theres a bonus: you automatically get 30 per cent off food and drink.Insomnia was featured in our recent Morning Glory - Best Western Breakfasts feature.

entry.name: Dragonfly at St James Power Station

version.name: Dragonfly at St James Power Station

content.description:
Oft-described as the bar where ah lians and ah bengs gather, this assumption is only half-true. The performers at this live-music room actually play a good mix of English and Mandarin favourites until the end of happy hour. Then dancers, aerialists and guest performers throng the stage and transform the place into something resembling a getai, albeit classier.
Sun-Thu: men $12, women $10; includes one drink. Fri & Sat: men $20, women $15; includes one drink. 
Happy hour: 8pm-9.30pm; minimum age: 18 for women, 23 for men. Dragonfly was included in our  Canto fight this feeling article.

This nondescript pub in the basement of Novena Square has been bringing in beers from all over the world long before it was fashionable. The pub also serves German food - try their pork knuckle and sausages.
Brauhaus Restaurant & Pub was featured in Convival Pursuit: Up North Pubs.

Holland Village has had quite a makeover over the past few years, but its old-faithful watering hole Wala Wala affectionately known as Walas to locals remains ensconced on Lorong Mambong. On the ground floor, enjoy a cold one at the distinctive yellow-lit bar and catch the game on one of several flat-screen TVs. The bar upstairs hosts a variety of local music and comedy acts, with an acoustic happy hour from 7 to 8.30pm. The only annoying change at Walas is the new smoking policy only a limited number of seats are available for smokers outdoors, so the remaining cigarette-puffing patrons have to hang around the adjoining alley like delinquent teenagers.

Here, big portions (washed down by beer, of course) are the order of the day. The thickly cut fish burger stands out with some really good fat chips, while the smoked salmon wrap is kept interesting with avocado and chive cream. The steak and kidney pie is a wonderful dome of puff pastry floating over a stew cut with sweet, fragrant dark ale. Or just come, after the movies, for the pavlova or sticky date pudding.
content.openingtimes:
Clarke Quay: Mon-Thu noon-3am, Fri & Sun noon-5am, Sun 11.30-3am
Great World: Mon-Sun 10-1am, Fri & Sat 10-2am

content.description: Hard Rock Cafe won Best Burger on our Who is top of the Table? feature.
The 1600 seat Concert Hall is the jewel-in-the-crown of The Esplanade.

Its a universally acknowledged fact that a sure-fire way to get your date in a romantic mood is to take him/her to a lovely seaside locale, loosen things up with good booze and a whole lot of atmosphere, and voila youre set for the night. Essentially, that sums up this classy joint. With views over the lolling greens of Sentosa Golf Club and the stunning seascape south of the island, the restaurant-bar exudes a contemporary vibe with its interesting glassware and brightly coloured seats. Kudos to the attentive wait-staff, who know exactly when to blend into the background, and when to zip over and speed up your bill before your date loses the mood. 
Il Lido is also listed as a restaurant, click for information.Il Lido was included in our recent One Night Stand feature.And was also was featured in our recent Honey, we need to talk - Best bars to make up in feature.

It is likely that by the time you end up at Rav, it is past 2am and you are already half-pissed, if not more. And thats just a conservative guess. Most of the folks who come here are the same ones refusing to go home even after all the other clubs have shut their doors. Luckily, theres Rav and its playlist of unadulterated fun dance and house grooves, which is the best kind of music when you are all liquored up. Attracting a mix of trendy types, yuppies and gay men, this is the place where everyone lets their hair down and their inner dance-demon out. There are often drink promotions by the pitchers not to mention a happy-hour deal that gives you your second housepour for just ten cents (Mon-Fri, 6pm-midnight) so theres no need to worry about losing your buzz. If you really want to have fun, go late; get there too early and youll be standing around waiting for the night owls to arrive.
$20, includes one drink.

Singapores largest alfresco dining space has expanded, upwards: Oosh now has a modern European restaurant on the second level. The French-influenced menu offers extravagances like seared frog legs ($19) and a thick but well-cooked hunk of grilled Australian tenderloin topped with seared foie gras and a slice of black truffle ($48).

Regarded by its many regulars as the only true Irish pub in town, the playfully monikered Sods has been paying homage to the Emerald Isles most famous liquid export for over five years. Guinness memorabilia abounds and, for novelty value, theres a real Irishman behind the bar (love him or loathe him: go, youll find out why). If youre looking for a plastic Paddy theme bar, youll walk away disappointed. However, if youre looking for the genuine craic, this Dublin-style city pub provides in abundance. Pints go for $12 during happy hour (until 8pm) and around $14 thereafter.

This unpretentious, yellow-painted pub and backpacker hostel is a slice of Down Under. The sunny decor features touches of red gum timber; Aussie draught beers include Gippsland Gold and Brewers Pilsener. Outside, find wooden benches, barbecues and revelry.More information for travellers on a budget and backpackers in Singapore.

One of Singapores few microbreweries, Brewerkz offers beers concocted on site by a Canadian brewmaster. Sit outside along the river or in the airy atrium, done up like a factory with exposed copper pipes. Choose from 12 handcrafted ales, lagers and stouts. The American-slanted food (pizza burgers, steaks, jambalaya) isnt bad either.See also Brewerkz @ Indoor Stadium and Brewerkz Bukit Timah.Brewerkz won Best Beer Bar in our Who is top of the Table? feature.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Thu noon-midnight, Fri & Sat noon-1am, Sun 11am-midnight.

content.description: Before he moved to Privé, New York-import Wayne Nish was brought in to revitalise the Screening Room and his bold, overhauled menu is wonderfully done. The mixed platters of sashimi and sushi are a delightful rainbow with salmon cured with coriander or kanpachi hit with citrus. Mains tend to lean towards seafood (we loved the slabs of tuna nestling on mesclun, roast peppers and beans) but the fat chunks of lamb rack coated with coriander seeds and tamarind are textbook-perfect. Unusually, Nish has curated a section of raw milk cheeses, which is reason enough for a return visit.

Stacks of wine bottles from more than 100 labels line the dark wood-panelled walls of this shophouse-turned-Spanish provisions store. Ambience is a major player here, with dusty wooden barrels crowding the corners, a casual lounge room with armchairs upstairs, and a front deck thats ideal for enjoying something from the cigar menu. The wine-by-the-glass selection is decent (about a dozen on offer), while oenophiles may be more interested in the library collection an exclusive selection of bottles acquired from private collections (although charged at exclusive prices). The tapas menu is superb marinated olives, cheeses and mushrooms are must-tries, along with the paper-thin-crust pizzas.
Drinks $12-16.
content.openingtimes: Sun-Thu 5.30pm-2am; Fri, Sat and holiday eve5.30pm-3am.

content.description: This smoking yet non-smoky bar serves up some of the best happy hour deals in Chinatown. (The name means Chinatown in Spanish, by the way.) And after nagging from punters, its now open during the day. Whereas you used to have to rely on other restaurants for sustenance, Barrio has now opened up its own kitchen. Try the bruschetta ($10 for a dozen), which will more than keep the hunger pangs at bay until dinner. A happy-hour glass of wine is $6, rising to $12 during regular hours.Barrio Chino was included in our recent Eye on the ball feature.

Theres a reason why this place is packed every night of the week with English bankers: its right in the heart of the Boat Quay end of the CBD, and is more British than tea and scones with the Queen. Owners Gaelic Inns, whose stable also includes Muddy Murphys, have decided to dispense with such fripperies as ambience and comfortable, ample seating; with a plum location right next to the river, they couldnt fail even if they pulped durians to make fruit juice. If youre visiting from the UK, a trip to this mock-Victorian tavern is about as adventurous as pulling a beer can from the fridge, and approximately ten times more expensive. In every possible sense this is a facsimile of a night out in London (in fact the humidity and local bar-staff are the only reminder that youre still in Asia); and just like the Big Smoke itself, a Friday-night stint here will wage war on your wallet. Inflated prices, stentorian patrons and cramped environs can take the shine off the Penny Black experience, and you cant escape the feeling that youre part of a blatantly profiteering enterprise, but for convenience and location alone (not to mention a happy hour lasting eight and a half hours) it still gets our, ahem, stamp of approval.
Mel's Place Bar & Bistro was featured in Convival Pursuit: Lazy East Pubs.

The imaginative minds at Imaginings (owners of KPO, Wala Wala and Balaclava) are good at creating bars with personality and they havent disappointed fans with Bar-Stop, a blink-and-youll-miss-it, three-in-one restaurant, bar and live jazz venue tucked away on Devonshire Road. This deceptively spacious two-storey spot is home to an outdoor restaurant and indoor bar, as well as an upstairs lounge filled with funky furniture. For those looking to dine, the quiet garden-like seating outside should be your choice for the night. Those with an eye for a well-stocked bar and an ear for live jazz can sit up close to the stage and take in all the (very loud) action. The polished cement floor, exposed brick walls, floor-to-ceiling windows and exceptional service make this space one of the coolest spots in town. It is indeed a bar to stop at.
Drinks price range from $6 to $17.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Thu 5pm-1am; Fri, Sat & public holidays 5pm-2am.Happy hour 5pm-8pm.

content.description: Top 40 hits fill the room and a Filipino acoustic musician belts out standards by 70s soft-rockers James Taylor and Bread. Some Saturday nights see the occasional band performance where local blues musicians gather and play surprisingly decent 50s and 60s American blues, but the infrequency of the blues nights makes you wonder if they even get paid for getting on stage to play.

Moved to a new location and now
known as Southbridge Jazz@7atenine
If you havent come down for a spell, Jazz is now downstairs from its original home and is twice its former size. Dont worry; its still cosy and intimate, and remains one of the most authentic dives in the city. Owner Eddie Chan wants to educate his audience, to open their eyes to jazz. The croons of resident vocalist Alemay Fernandez can be enjoyed over a tapas-centric dinner, or over martinis on the tango seats upfront. Visiting musicians are frequent look out for international names like Dale Barlow, Marcus Printup and Aaron Goldberg even Pat Metheny played a spontaneous set here. If Eddie is propping up the bar (which reveals a hundred or so malt whiskies) the night you visit, beg him to tell his story. A former architect, Eddie only discovered jazz in his fifties; his love of the genre soon became his lifes preoccupation a journey that led him to open the club in 2002, picking up the vibraphone along the way, on which he performs with the band on Tuesdays and Sundays.
This venue has recently closed.

This place has the honour of being designed and built in Ireland, then shipped to Singapore and re-assembled at Circular Road. So no wonder you feel immediately transported from the humdrum of Singapore life the moment you step through its doors. Youll appreciate how everything is so straightforward and simple, from its draughts to its Irish stews no gimmicks to distract you from having a truly Irish experience and resident musican Gerry Cox, who performs live acoustic renditions of Irish folk songs and contemporary hits Monday to Friday, from 8.30pm onwards.
See also The Brasserie.
content.openingtimes: Mon & Tues 11am-1am, Weds, Thurs and Sat 11am-2am, Fri & Eve of PH 11am-3am, Sunday 11am-12am, Food Served 7/7 11am - 10:30pm (11pm on Fri)

content.description: Apart from the name, which means in touch with me in Spanish, not much has changed about the former Club 95. Theyve moved some furniture and the walls now sport a few new paintings as part of a monthly showcase of creative talent (when we went it was Peenut and Pat Lawsartwork). Relaxing lounge tunes make this a popular spot to chill with the girls or to romance your latest love.

This karaoke pub has been around since the early 1990s and has always proudly bared the rainbow flag. Contrary to its name, you wont find cows or coolies here. Instead, youll get a queer mix of women in their early twenties and thirties, with men in office-wear singing Mando-pop tunes. The men and women may not sing in the same choir, but everyone gets along famously. The guys know full well they wont have girls harassing them to buy drinks, so the unspoken arrangement works for everyone the ladies can enjoy their cocktails and conversation, and the lads can sing to their hearts content. Bar owner Joey knows most of her regulars by name and is often seen mingling with the happy campers. Its all fun and merry-making here with good conversation and often not-so-good singing.

Living up to its name, this gem of a bar can be a tough one to find. Once youve nailed down the location Circular Road is the parallel street behind Boat Quay and made it up the three flights of stairs without running out of breath, youll be delighted by what you find. Inside, the mismatched furniture, low lighting,and oddly soothing pink and burgundy walls strip the bar of any airs. Hideouts patrons are not there to be seen or make PC small talk all they want is to sit back, relax and shoot the breeze with their friends.Indie bands play on Wednesdays, DJs spin house beats on Fridays,and on all other nights the DJ rotates between hip hop, funk and jazz.

While taxi uncles are still rather clueless when you mention its multi-syllabic name, One Rochester does not stop drawing stressed-out individuals eager to attain a sense of peace in the bars very green, very snug surroundings. Although it is situated close to the busy North Buona Vista Road, the gastro bar remains surprisingly impervious to the sounds of traffic. With mosquito-repelling citronella and animpressive 200-something wine list, One Rochesters best kept secret status is only moments away from being revealed. Email info@onerochester.com for enquiries

You cant miss this bar with the rainbow flag noticeably perched above its entrance. Regulars come here forthe strong Long Island Iced Teas (just like at its sister bar, Tantric), double-shot drinks and also for the kitsch paraphernalia of semi-nude male pictures and musical-theatre posters that decorate the walls. The staff are friendly, personable and flirtatious, as is the crowd a mix of older Caucasian men and younger locals, tourists and expats. 
Happy hour: Daily from 7-9pm with drinks discounted by 20 per cent.

Home is probably one of the more underground clubs in our otherwise mainstream entertainment scene. With regular album launches for local bands and a host of international DJs (ie Goldie, Black Sun Empire) the club invites you into its living room for a round of hip hop, deep house, techno, indie, electro and drum n bass.
content.openingtimes: Tue-Thu 9pm-3am; Fri & Sat 10pm-6am; Sun closed except for the last Sun of every month.

content.description: The spanking new venue at One Fullerton played host to Time Out Singapores second-anniversary bash and features 8,000 sq ft of floorspace double the size of its old digs at Robertson Quay. The space is split into two rooms: Fash, a larger extension of the alternative, electro-friendly Art Bar of old, and the main room Bump, which caters to Butters faithful core of R&B/hip-hop fans.
content.openingtimes: Wed 10pm-3am, Thu 9pm-2am, Fri & Sat 10pm-4am, Eve of public holidays and nights w international DJs: 10pm-5am

address.street: 392 Havelock Road, Grand Copthorne Waterfront Hotel
392 Havelock Road, Grand Copthorne Waterfront Hotel

content.description: Imagine a restaurant business model where, at the end of lunch, diners pay what they think the meal was worth. A risky proposition, to be sure, but one that has been put into practice at Annalakshmi and seems to have done them no harm. The buffet counter is entirely vegetarian dhals, soups, cauliflower curry, yoghurt dips, papadums with everything cooked daily. Its low-fuss, home-spun cooking that wins our vote for its earnestness and complete lack of pretension. At the end, payment amounts to a donation to the restaurant (and its support for sister organisation, the Temple of Fine Arts), but really, anything less than $5 per head would be a disgrace.

A mid-sized hawkers centre on the corner of Telok Ayer and Boon Tat roads, 121 is a favourite lunchtime haunt for Chinatown workers from all walks of life, from the well-groomed expatriate to the motorbike courier. The biggest queue emanates from Nur Nasi Padang, known as the finest purveyor of Indonesian food in the vicinity. Expect a generous portion of melt-in-the-mouth beef rendang, addictively garnished chicken drumsticks and a colourful range of meat curries and spicy vegetable dishes. Other food-stall highlights include the omnivorous Kingsland Vegetarian stand which proudly proclaims, No pork or lard, and serves a mean duck laksa and Paratha Treat, for the last word in chepati, daal and samosas. For pudding, make a beeline for Frankies Peanut Pancake, a winner of the Green Book of Food Awards 07/08.

The stars of the show here are the slabs of sizzling hot (400 degrees!) volcanic stone from Australia on which the steaks, seafood and veggies are cooked by customers at the table to their liking. No oil or other cooking fat is used so its all good. But if that sounds too messy for you, theres also an excellent value $10.99++ ($9.99++ for students, $8.99++ if you are 55 years and above) set lunch comprising soup of the day, main course, and dessert or hot drink.

THIS VENUE HAS RECENTLY CLOSED. IT IS NOW KAISEKI GOTO JAPANESE RESTAURANT.
You would never guess from thenondescript façade that this tiny boutiqueis home to wonderful Japanese fare.Store manager and chef Kayoko Arimadisarmingly describes her food asordinary home cooking, but there is nothingremotely everyday about her dishes. Thelunch and dinner set courses are filling,and the small à la carte menu is worthinvestigation. The innocuously namedavocado fritters arrived in a sailing boatlikecontraption, the nuggets of jade-greenfritters perfectly crisp and creamy, and theaccompanying dip of green-tea powder andsalt a revelation for its subtle pungency.

Everything at Pho House makesus feel all warm and fuzzy inside.The friendly and bubbly service is top-notch,stemming from Saigon-born owner and chefTrent Thai. Then theres the food so good thatVietnam sends cooking students to be trainedhere. The pho bo beef noodles with a fullbodied soup stock ($9) is the main reason tovisit, though the grilled pork chop ($9) isnt halfbad either. One enduring regret is that wevenever made it to dessert, were always so fullafter the main course and coffee.

In keeping with the tradition ofthe famous Shilin Night Marketin Taipei, this stall sells nothing but snacks.But dont make the mistake of thinking this isfinger food: items like the XXL Chicken ($3),a large, breaded, deep-fried cutlet of chickenabout the size of a DVD box, and the Oyster MeeSua ($3.50), vermicelli noodles in a thick brownsauce with liberal amounts of oysters, are not tobe ordered lightly.

The restaurant is tricked out inPeranakan furniture and decorations,which can be a tad garish, but the menu,which is personally planned by executive chefPatricia Lee, more than makes up for it. Manyregulars swear by the ayam bua keluak (small$7.80, big $10.80), the essential Peranakanstew made from chicken and Indonesianblack nut in a thick, spicy gravy that combinesall the different taste sensations: sweet,salty, bitter and sour. But we say try the kepetinbak wan ($8.80), a rich broth which comeswith generous helping of juicy balls of crabmeat,tofu and minced pork, sprinkled withgrated bamboo shoots.

Hearty, warm fare served by ahearty, warm woman thatswhat we want from Russian food. EvgeniaPolesnaya, more affectionately known tolocal patrons as Jane, delivers both. Theplace is staffed by Russkie natives (Polesnyais from Belarus herself) and doles out perfectpirozhki (appetiser bun with cabbage)for just 70 cents. Other fi lling fare includesdraniki (potato pancakes, $5.50), blinchiki(pancakes stuffed with snow apple, icecreamor honey; $6), kotleta kartofelnaya(mashed potato pie with mushrooms, $7)and kvas (sparkling bread drink made withyeast, $3).

Featuring an al fresco diningspace, this restaurant offers hugeportions of Moroccan specialities at a tinyprice. A fusion of European and African food,the cuisine is known for its extensive use ofNorth African spices (such as cumin, coriander,saffron, chillis and cinnamon) in tandemwith almond and pistachio nuts. The mostexpensive dish is just $6.50, and most can behad for less than $5. Run by a local Malay ladyand her Moroccan husband, the Deli offersfriendly and prompt service and piping hotfood served in a traditional earthenware tagine(the name for both pot and dish). Dont miss theMoroccan apple drink a sweet, cold, blendedshake with milk and cinnamon and the traditionalhot apple tea, which is consideredan art form in Morocco. Pair either withKoofta tagin (beef stewed in an earthenwarepot, $5.50) or the Moroccanbeef kebab ($4). 30

This Mexican spot is proof that concept restaurants can be fun as hell, so long as you have good food and good booze. The dish to try is the carnede puerco en chile verde ($7.99) served with sourcream, soft tortillas and rice. The stew is surprisinglyrich and bold and clearly made from goodstock. And because the food comes in generousportions, this appetiser makes for a great lightmeal. Or, since this is Mexico, you could skip solidfood altogether and go right for the liquid lunch.Iguana has a bar full of 100 per cent blue agavetequilas, so fill up on a potent shot of the Cabrito Blanco or Cabrito Reposado ($9.99 each). Evenbetter, house pours are half price from openinguntil 9pm and midnight till closing

The nondescript faade belies therich Penang fare offered here, someof the best this side of the Malaysian border. Pluspoint: friendly and helpful staff who will evengive you a drink as you wait for your takeaway.The flavourful hor fun duck soup($8.50), with its huge braised duckleg, can actually feed two light eaters.

Kuriya Fish Market sets itself apart from the masses with just one small twist, its chilli salmon don. What appears to be a normal salmon don is given a little Singaporean lift with the help of crunchy spring onions and a zing of chilli, moulded together with some sesame oil. At $10.80, it is a little over the budget, but in return youll taste a truly original (and tasty) dish that you wont be able to find elsewhere in or out of Singapore. We say pay the damn 80 cents.

Try the mou hin ga ($5.50), a ubiquitousnoodle soup served as a light meal.The version here is richly curried in thickorange fi sh gravy, fi lled with thin ricenoodles and a hard-boiled egg, and pungentwith lemongrass and lime.

address.street: 252 North Bridge Road, #B1-58 Raffles City Shopping Centre
252 North Bridge Road, #B1-58 Raffles City Shopping Centre

content.description: The reason to come to thisBritish take-away is its Scottishoffering: the deep-fried Mars bar. At Chippy,four pieces of the gooey candy bar are just$2.95. If you feel you must balance that withsomething healthy, you can always orderthe fi sh and chips

address.street: 252 North Bridge Road, #B1-59 Raffles City Shopping Centre
252 North Bridge Road, #B1-59 Raffles City Shopping Centre

content.description: At Pipers, the pies are handmadedaily and baked on the premises. Gofor the hefty Pipers Special made of 100 percent lean Aussie beef encased in a fl aky pieshell ($6), and the classic coconut-fl eckedchocolate lamington ($2.80).

The decor (complete with wooden stools and mood lighting) is a little kitsch, prompting flashbacks to ‘Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon’, but the menu is faultless. The roast Peking duck is a standout, the skin crisp and the doughy wraps just-so. It’s also hard to pass up the onion-flecked pancakes, fried noodles and luminous cubes of tofu braised in a black bean sauce and finely minced pork.

The shelves of organic goodies may be gone, but the former Yogi Hub still brings in a mixed crowd of aunties, Buddhist nuns and the arty set all smacking their collective lips at the eclectic vegetarian menu and organic fruit juices (try the red cabbage and grapes). The petai fried rice is an unexpectedly wonderful blend of bitter nuts, carrots, brown rice and sambal, while the tofu claypot filled with gingko nuts, bamboo shoots and asparagus is the best kind of comfort food. As is the walnut cheesecake.

Everything about Ka Soh Cantonese formother-in-law shrieks 1950s. But the daily crowds dont come to this Chinatown eatery for the dcor. The bustling, motherly staffdish out stern love and terrifically homeyCanto-classics in equal measure. Bestsellersinclude deep-fried chicken marinated inprawn paste, deep-fried cubes of salted tofuand a milky, fish-head beehoon noodle soup.

Singapores Arab quarter is a peek into another world: a little community jammed with crumbling architecture, carpet sellers and little eateries like Alaturka where the air moves lazily and you cant shake the feeling that youre not in Singapore anymore, Toto. Share the karisik kebab, a large copper platter of combination kebabs including charcoal-grilled lamb chops and served with tender chunks of grilled chili, pilaf and rich buttery vegetables. For a postprandial treat, sit outside and puff a strawberry-flavoured shisha.

A-roy Thais nondescript interior (in the middle of Funan electronics mall) belies the superb quality of its kitchen. The flavours ring true, the high notes of sour, sweet, salty and chili heat recalling all that is good in Thai cuisine. House specials include a nasal-clearing tom yam, jade-green curries perfumed with lemongrass, delicately stuffed chicken wings, rice crackers topped with a coconutty pork mince, and fish steamed in chilis.

The breakfast experience doesnt get any more authentic than this. For 60 years, generations of loyal, local residents have been turning up at Chin Mee Chin for their morning kick-start of jet-black coffee (served in the traditional porcelain cups, thank you) and soft-boiled eggs. Dont miss the thick slabs of toast that are slathered with butter and a side slathering of kaya. Take a taxi.

The platinum blond and ever-smiling Belgium chef Emmanuel Stroobant is the closest thing Singapore has to a celebrity chef. The restaurant made its name with an astonishing foie gras menu, but these days its aggressively French tastes are tempered with Asian inflections, such as lobster with yuzu-green tarts, scallops and seaweed oil, wild kiniko mushroom soup, and a sailboat of filo and wasabi-scented wild barramundi served with grilled aubergines and pine nuts.

With its new and more visible location, its business as usual at Sage. The dining rooms grey palette and small but well thought-out mod French/Italian menu attract a mix of suits and ladies who lunch, though the rather uncomfortable chairs dont encourage lingering. The crab salad sits in a pool of gazpacho and is made of avocado, olives, firm and chunks of meat, cut with the crunch of celeriac and onion. Though the prawn carbonara is more a prawn mee thickened with egg and prawn oil than a carbonara, its a nice twist to the usual version. Especially good is the veal cheek braised in a thick and rich porcini sauce. The set lunch starts from $38.

Outside Hotel 1929 lies the notorious red-light district of Keong Saik Road; inside, the mood is more serene as diners peruse the eclectic Mod Euro menu from the talented Sebastian Ng. The food is consistently good and imaginative, including pan-seared scallops with parma ham in an orange and tarragon vinaigrette; and sea bass with smoked bacon ragout and truffleyuzu butter sauce. Like the food, the decor is neither fussy nor pretentious.

Its hard to believe that behind such an unimposing façade lies an eatery with such a fierce following. The fare here is redolent of a different time and place; of rustic villages and hand-pounded herbs and spices, and recipes passed from mother to daughter. There are tender chunks of beef braised in a creamy coconut sauce, chicken curries, grilled meats and a technicolour spread of puddings.

With a name like this, its unsettling to walk into a space so distinctly mod-Japanese. There are comfy couches, and walls lined with floor-to-ceiling anime books and Japanese magazines. But its the little caf to the side that holds the attention. There are curries (Japanese-style, which is to say not a hint of heat), tonkatsu sets and lovely bricks of tofu and soya sauce. The Japanese regulars tell the story.

Diego Chiarinis short menu changes monthly. Its strengths lie in its variety and authenticity, with soft accents from the Tuscan and Piedmonte regions. There is much that delights, not least the attentive service. The pasta dishes are a triumph; standouts include robust rigatoni bathed in a deep red sauce of thyme, black olives and tender rabbit.

Deep in the suburbs, Valentinos is a family-run trattoria where the squid-ink pasta, golden carbonara and paper-thin slices of pork loin braised in a stock of white wine, garlic and bay leaves are served up with brio. The Milan-born chef spent many years cooking in Tuscany and something of the Tuscan penchant for food with sunny colours, dense with flavours and simply prepared vegetables obviously wore off. That said, the dessert trolley, while looking temptingly luscious, is usually a let-down.

Rijsttafel is a Dutch-Indonesian hybrid of a buffet, but served to guests at the table all at once. Rice Table loads up on a never-ending flow of little plates filled with an astonishing range of meats, vegetables and flavours: satay, tahu telor, turmeric-tinged chicken curry, otah-otah, fried potato dumplings, thick rust-coloured beef rendang and more. At lunch, expect around 14 dishes, and a gut-busting 20 at dinner. The service is fast and furious, and its easily one of the best value meals in town. 
Lunch buffet $14.80++, dinner buffet $23.80++.Rice Table won Best Food for value under $25 in our Who is top of the Table? feature.

Ignore the drab setting: the bowels of a shopping centre, surrounded by hair salons and reflexologists. What appeals is the decent, cheap food. The Javanese street food menu is, for such a small restaurant, surprisingly comprehensive. There is sunny curry chicken, fried fish in tart assam sauce, and mounds of gadogado blanketed by crisp prawn crackers and a mild Surabayan peanut gravy. Service can be absent-minded, but at these prices, who cares?

Chef Milind Sovani has created a show-stopping pan-Indian meal in a charming Scotts Road black-and-white bungalow. On the menu, which criss-crosses the subcontinents regional cuisines, youll find melt-in-the-mouth Keralan-spiced lamb shanks, tandoori prawns bathed in a pomegranate marinade, and the Lucknavi classic of Gilawat kebabs pan-seared ground lamb patties perfumed by cardamom, ground rose petals and raw papaya.

This family-run restaurant has been rattling around since 1929 and is still going strong. Classical and comfortingly familiar, it takes few wrong turns: the suckling pig, Peking duck, chili Sri Lankan crabs and crisp roast chicken all fly from the kitchen at a dizzying pace. A must-try are the golden cereal prawns: huge, sweetly salty crustaceans encrusted with oatmeal flakes.

Long Beach has been there since anyone can remember, and judging from the weekend crowds of multi-generational families, it will be around for the long haul. Dont be distracted by the other goodies piled high on surrounding tables. Just concentrate on the huge Sri Lankan crabs doused with a molten, eggy, tart, tongue-singeing gravy. The other favourite is the black pepper crab, here doused with jet-black gravy. Mop it all up with crisply fried mantou dumplings.
content.openingtimes: Daily 11am-3pm, 5pm-12.15am; Sat and eve of holidays 11am-1.15am.

content.description: If you dont have a reservation on the weekend, forget about getting a table here after noon. The menu can be intimidating, so let the staff guide you. Scrumptious dim sum includes deep-fried yam pastries, sautéed snake beans and rice-flour rolls stuffed with prawns. On the à la carte menu, the steamed fish is excellent. Ask for a booth seat; the other tables are exposed to heavy traffic. Imperial Treasure (a rival to the Crystal Jade group) has four other restaurants around town, each specialising in a different Chinese cuisine.

Purists insist that the original Taipei location is superior to the Singaporean outpost. But it is hard to find fault with the fab xiao long bao: tiny rounds of pleated pastry filled with sweet minced pork and fragrant soup. Each silken mouthful is an explosion of flavours sweet, salty and sour, gingery and vinegary. Before you know it, a whole basket has been consumed. The braised beef noodles are also superb.Other locations throughout the city.
TOS March 2010 menu update:   This food chain from Taiwan celebrates its seventh local outlet with a steamy selection of new dishes, including the can they get any smaller? steamed mini pork dumplings with soup ($10.80), which burst with juicy flavour, and the delicate, coconut-dusted fragrant peanut dumplings ($6.80). $2.50-$10.80.#B2-01-03 313@ Somerset, 313 Orchard Rd (6509 6696, www.dintaifung.com.sg). MRT: Somerset

Make believe youre Somerset Maugham (once a regular at the Raffles Hotel) strolling in for a meal at one of the hotels best eateries. The high ceilings conspire with the Old-World furniture to create a casually nostalgic vibe just right for the menu of Asian classics such as nasi goreng, rojak salads, huge bowls of laksa noodles and chicken rice. Though pricier than the hawker-stall version, the experience is nevertheless captivating.

Chef Jean-Charles Dubois makes the most of the awkwardly narrow dining room, uncomfortable banquette seats and even tinier kitchen. The menu is, like the space, small, but the dishes are executed with Gallic finesse. Try the dainty vol au vent, encasing fragrant sweetbreads, for example. Or the high, clear notes of a consommé, or the delicately wrought lamb chops seared with rosemary. Sometimes, though, this finesse is carried to extremes, as with the cod bouillabaisse; while perfectly flavoured and crisp, this main course was so small, the $35 price tag was a recessionary slap in the face.Main courses $35-$45. Five-course dégustation menu $88++.

If youve got money to burn ($198 per head) and an adventurous palate, dive into the seven-course dinner at Fifty- Three. The use of molecular gastronomy in the cooking is superb and can be tasted from beginning to end. How about this for a menu: start with the crispy chicken skin chip with oyster emulsion, move on to pan-seared lobster served alongside apples garlanded with pieces of chopped duck tongue, and finish with chocolate mousse sprinkled with Jerusalem artichoke shavings. Youre left completely satisfied. After signing the enormous bill they surprise you with a gin and tonic sweet that dissolves after a minute or two on your tongue into a G&T at which point youre finally convinced it was money well spent. Costs: lunch $48-$78, dinner $198.

If you think a restaurant committed to serving no meat, no seafood, no eggs, no onion, no garlic and no MSG would be a no-go, youd be wrong. Somehow despite all thats not used, Naïve dishes up intense flavours and textures. Much of the magic is accomplished through the copious use of monkey head mushrooms that taste more like meat than vegetables. Youll find them soaking up flavours such as sweet and sizzling kongpo sauce; braised in an aromatic five-spice broth; or sliced and sautéed thin and crispy. Of course, tofu makes an appearance, but the plain old curd is transformed into a star with a tangy barbecue baste worthy of a pork rib, or sharp tamarind, lemongrass and chilli sauce. The warm pumpkin and sago soup was a dessert highlight. And the blessing of the sesame seeds (BLOSS) is a surprise youll have to ask the helpful staff about.Costs: Lunch sets from $9.90, dinner sets from $14.90.
Get Punjabi suits, Salwar kameez and all sorts of Indian fashion at Meenu Fashion House.

This is the latest addition to the Timbre franchise, known for its laidback vibe and showcase of local bands. While the other two outlets feature livelier music, Timbre @ Old School is home to acoustic sounds. Fittingly, the venue keeps a chilled ambience. Value-for-money happy-hour promotions two Erdinger pints and an order of buffalo wings for $28++, or one bottle of house wine and a pizza for $38++ make this venue a great hangout for a quiet evening among friends. If you are looking for an intimate location for a casual date, or just to spend some time listening to fantastic vocals.

Despite its far-flung location requiring a few bus transfers, a patient taxi driver or GPS to get there Buckaroo is packing them in and youre advised to book ahead (be wary of the smoking tables). Serving Western staples such as salads, steak and finger-lickin ribs, by far the biggest pull for the uninitiated is the famous hotter-than-hot buffalo wings. Ranging from a mild level one, through to a suicidal level ten, these secret-recipe wings will have you sculling beer or lime margaritas before even contemplating the main event. Douse the flames with towers of crispy onion rings or creamily delicious coconut gelato. With no service charge or GST, it means the only thing not burning will be your pocket.

This 41-year-old Teochew restaurant is one of the last of its kind in Singapore; think fluorescent-lit dining room, bright-pink foldable chairs and faded wood-panelled walls. Occupying three units of shophouses, Lee Kui is also known as Ah Hoi or crab in Teochew. As the name implies, people flock here for one thing the famous cold crabs. But if the hefty price tag of about $70 per kg hurts, consider wallet-friendly alternatives from the extensive menu of stir-fries, stews, deep-fried and steamed dishes. We highly recommend the crisp and moist oyster omelette, served with refreshing sprigs of coriander; savoury eight-treasure vegetarian stew that includes melt-in-the-mouth cabbage and moss in a oyster-sauce laced gravy; and the braised duck wings served in a claypot bubbling with a dark and rich brew. Complete your meal on a high note with the sweet and unctuous ambrosia of or nee (yam paste), crowned with gingko nuts and creamy mashed pumpkins.

Bontás new stablemate gushes in its web-blurb about its beautiful surroundings, a setting which embraces nature and exudes serenity. The self-proclaimed laid-back and rustic atmosphere has you expecting something resembling Raw Kitchen Bars middle-of-nowhere foodie cabin, or PS. Café on Dempsey. In reality, co-owner and chef Luca Pezzeras latest venture shares little in common with these other two restaurants. For starters, District 10 is only a stones throw from a busy road junction, next to a flashy electronics showroom. Occupying the site of a former school, the outdoor dining area sits bang next to a rough brick wall, as if you were eating in a student union canteen.On the soggy Friday night we visited, our first impressions were compounded by an insanely noisy radio blasting bland pop directly overhead, latticework roofing leaking raindrops on our chairs, plates and heads, and a hideous dripping affair next to us like some sort of inverted well, better suited to Underwater World than a restaurant.As my companions drink arrived (but not mine), the laughable starter came too: five pieces of crunchy crostini a couple of millimetres thick, topped with a blancmange-like fishy paste. Devouring rocket leaves to keep ourselves going, we watched in amusement as the wait-staff bustled around us like headless chickens, two of them having a blazing row in a service area ornately decorated with a saggy black bin bag. Our chairs vibrated every time someone dashed across the decking, so the entire meal felt like we were on a particularly uncomfortable funfair ride, sans the fun.The vino may be imported from boutique wineries, and indeed the Zonin prosecco tasted delicious, but it lasted two sips. Our mains suffered from the opposite syndrome: the sirloin steak was more than generous, but not cooked to order, while the fish and chips order was copious but anaemic. I asked for some salt to jazz it up, but the seemingly esoteric request was lost in translation, and it took a second go before the elusive condiment arrived. You cant fault their efficiency; my partners plate was whisked away before Id finished, and while my Stella Artois had taken 15 minutes to be delivered, the bill arrived in seconds flat.So although I was reluctant to return, I was extremely glad I did. In almost every respect our second visit, this time indoors, was a superior experience. The staff led us into the light-filled, spacious dining room dominated by teak tables and chairs, and a huge wine cellar. Things were looking up already, especially with the arrival of two exemplary drinks. A virgin mojito at just $5.20 was so good my companion didnt miss the alcohol at all; a smoky, deeply mellow Fredda Barolo house red ($12) set me up perfectly for the main course.But I should have known from the non-Italian spelling of lasagne bolognaise (its bolognese, fact fans) this wasnt the genuine article, and so it proved. The inside was crumbly instead of meaty and cheesy, and lukewarm rather than piping hot. It tasted like a ready meal from Mustafa Centres frozen section, shoved in the microwave, but not for long enough. They didnt have any trouble drumming up a regional dish, however: the crayfish noodle was well presented and infused with delicately sweet Thai flavours. Although on the small side, the crayfish was compensated by a generous portion of prawns and noodles. If previous courses had their faults, the chefs redeemed themselves with a remarkable crème brûlée, textured to perfection, whose generous lashings of rum packed a seriously heady wallop.Shared between two, this was enough to end the meal on a very high (and ever-so-slightly inebriated) note. The staff are well-intentioned, but essentially clueless, and their hurried style lends the whole set-up an amateurish air. Sport fiends on a beered-up weekender will fit in perfectly at the imposing bar, with its huge TV screen showing football. And theres no doubt that for many, both local and foreign, this is a winning formula; at weekends it does a roaring trade. But choosier diners seeking quiet surrounds and cordon bleu cuisine could find District 10 a costly disappointment.Main courses $12-$24.By Jonathan Evans
content.openingtimes: Sun-Thu 10am-11pm; Fri, Sat, public holiday eve 8.30am-1am; brunch Sat & Sun 8.30am-3pm.

content.description: Making that first visit to Good Old Frog Porridge on Outram Road may very well be a life-changing decision. Once youve savoured these tender appendages, there is no turning back. Served piping hot, the succulent meat comes out in an earthen clay pot with heaps of sliced ginger and spring onions in a thick, fragrant pool of dark soysauce gravy blistering dried chillis are optional. This utterly addictive brew is best slurped down with silky smooth congee and a plate of shallot-topped chye sim on the side. Wash it all down with a glass of iced herbal tea. Note: if you purchase four frogs you get one free.

content.vendor-category: Well & Good | Deals of the month

content.description: Young families seem to have earmarked this spot for casual weekend dining. Why theyve picked it is open for debate, but certainly the spacious alfresco area, a ready supply of high chairs and ample parking serve as contributing factors. The menu of Eurocentric dishes doesnt hurt either. The rich seafood bisque is hearty in taste with just a hint of spice; the duck salad makes for a delicious mouthful of bitter, sweet and sour, its slices of duck on crisp rocket leaves dressed with a raspberry- and dill-infused citrus sauce. A bowl of carbonara, with a generous serving of bacon, prompted the suggestion of a lazy afternoon nap before the dessert sampler a divine combination of sticky date pudding, panna cotta, crème brûlée and apple cobbler with cinnamon ice cream made it a dead cert.

The bakers are true artists, crafting cakes with flair and creativity that makes them look too good to eat (almost). Owner Jeffrey Galistan says his most popular cake is the Chocolate Etoile, a sinful cocoa creation sprinkled with a half-moon of powdered sugar and crowned with a bouquet of chocolate bark, leaves and flowers.
Spahaven, primely located at Amoy Street, caters to working professionals for appointments during lunch-breaks. Treatments offered include waxes, hair removal, and facials.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Fri 11am-9pm; Sat 11am-7pm.Closed on Sun & Public Holidays.

content.description: From the reassuring presence of the tall French maître d at the entrance to the French-accented English floating through the kitchens peek-a-boo service window, Les Artistes got everything right. The bread basket arrived with warm, chewy homemade bread alongside a rich, earthy duck rillette. Theres not much on the regularly changing menu for vegetarians, but thats the French for you. Why settle for sautéed greens when you could hoe into beef cheeks that have been braised for five hours? The portions themselves were on the small side and, for a bistro, a little too prettily plated. The upside is that everything was cooked with seasoned aplomb.The meaty, rosemary-laced rack of lamb arrived with a shot glass of garlicky, truffled purée that sparkled with the low crunch of sea salt. The gelatinous beef cheek, stained a deep red by wine, is defenceless against the slight prod of the fork. Even the desserts cleaved close to chef Nicolas Joannys less-is-more approach, exemplified by a sweet pear poached and served with a mere scattering of shaved almonds. Simple, but not insultingly so.Costs: Dinner set meals from $48 for three courses, $58 for three courses.

Fairy lights festoon the trees flanking the front lawn, while jazz music plays softly, making La Villa ideal for the first date youll have to be playing your cards rather badly if you havent got to first base by the time dessert is served. Owned by the Senso group, the menu of expertly prepared Italian cuisine does not disappoint. A starter comprising bufala mozzarella, avocado and ripe tomato delights with its fresh and simple taste. The pappardelle with roasted pork leg ragout and black olives, and the spinach fettuccine with braised duck in red wine, both arrived a smidgen less al dente than we would have liked, but the forktender pork and nuggets of flavourful duck more than made up for this one shortcoming. After drooling over our neighbouring tables pizza and sizeable platter of grilled prawns, our menu for the following visit was set. And since no romantic meal should end on a savoury note, the apple tart with cinnamon served as the sweet finale to a more than satisfactory meal.

This little art school off Bukit Timah Road lets kids scratch their creative itch with clay-making, mosaic, acrylic and oil painting, and food art classes. They're meaningful gifts for kiddie birthdays, think of these classes as grooming the next Picasso. Costs Registration: $30 Drop-in Session: $35 Trial session for Canvass Doodler: $20 Trial session for other Canvass classes: $35 Term Fees (13 weeks): $390

8Q is the Singapore Art Museum's newest contemporary art extension. Housed in the former Catholic High School, this space is set to become a place for artists and the public to engage in a lively art exchange.Free admission: Mon-Thu 12pm2pm; Fri 6pm9pm.

One of a long string of hotels along Orchard Road, the Orchard has a few distinguishing features: a putting green, a 25m pool and a lifesize poolside chess set. Inside, the aesthetic is East meets West; luxuries include an extensive pillow menu and an IT butler service. For a birds-eye view of Orchard Road, ask for an upper floor in the Orchard Wing. Signature Club rooms are sumptous oriental extravaganzas featuring green, red or blue colour schemes, and lots of extras including evening cocktails and a hydro-massage rain shower.
Good for inline skating gear. They've conduct skating classes and speed-skating expeditions as well.

Eat this: The crunchy and tender puu nim phriktal dum. Black pepper soft-shell crab with kaffir lime leaves and garlic.Take a pass: The usually complex but delicate Thai stalwarts yum talay (seafood salad), tom yum kung and gang paa kung sub (eastern woodland-style red curry) were fresh, but doused so heavily in chillis that they were hard to stomach.Tip: Avoid entering through the fifth floor entrance; the fourth floor is much more welcoming.Fun fact: The translation of the name Soht & Baay doubles up as its motto: Fresh & Good.

The Indian-Chinese dishes that are heating up the kitchen across the street from Mustafa Centre are not part of some new trend. The fusion of cuisines dates back centuries to the first Chinese migrations to India, when a new lands seductive spices were applied to the traditional cooking of the old. The relocation is displayed over Indian Woks 15-page menu and, when served, the gastronomic results exceeded my expectations with flying colours and fiery flavours.The interior is not shabby by any means, but the red-carpeted stairs leading up to the restaurant will have you wondering if youve made a wrong turn and into a shady massage parlour. But the door opens to a surprisingly attractive establishment, and gracious waiters offer a warm welcome. Exactly what kind of look they are going for is hard to pin down, though; it seems as though the designers were trying too hard with the painted gold ceiling, white tablecloths and embossed wallpaper.My attention quickly turned from the embellished decor to spicy pickles (placed on the table upon arrival) and a long list of dishes that were crying out for my tasting. A mountain of crunchy deep-fried spinach was the first appetiser to arrive. The Sichuan chilli sauce that decorated the darkgreen cubes comparable to croutons got my mouth tingling. The spring rolls were leaning a bit more towards the Chinese border, and helped cleanse the palate with a subtle ginger flavour and a little less heat.
Deviled PrawnsIf the mains were more hit and miss, at least each dish was executed with an element of surprise. Described on the menu as a wonderful Indian creation, there was little information as to what should be expected with The Vegetable Manchurian. This dish is made from a batter thats flavoured with red chilli oil, Sichuan pepper, minced garlic and green onions, and moulded into great balls of fire. Eager to try new dishes upon my second visit, this was one I just had to order again. The panfried noodles with cabbage, mushrooms and carrot lost their appeal when shortly after arriving, the once-crispy noodles became soggy and resembled something that came out of a can.Leaving the border-crossing flavours aside, the sizzling brownie had to be tasted. Someone had already been feasting on the chocolate goodness when we arrived, so it was imperative for us to try this dish. Served on a hotplate, the waiter pours the molten chocolate sauce right in front of your eyes and a scoop of vanilla ice cream made a perfect accompaniment. The burning desire to unbuckle my jeans soon after devouring this sweet piece of heaven didnt bother me; it was that good.The portions are generous and the staff courteous. Read: youll be thankful that your water glass is constantly being refilled and that the air-conditioning is going strong when these dishes have you perspiring and your mouth burning. Even after wolfing down the chilli-smothered devil prawns, shredded chicken with soy garlic sauce and braised beancurd with black mushrooms, it felt as though I had only scratched this woks surface.

Whether you want to maintain a healthy lifestyle or kick-start a healthier new you in the New Year, Saladstop! is tossing up just the right mix. Sure, a plate of greens is guaranteed to be good for you, but to make sure its tasty too, Saladstop! serves up big bamboo bowls of vibrant veggies with a range of recommended dressings to create favourites like the Oh Crab Lah salad. You can pick and choose your own perfect concoction from 42 assorted ingredients.

Halal Swedish food on Arab Street is a rare sight, and modern, whitewashed Fika certainly stands out in the mostly traditional area dominated by shophouses. The desserts are the clear winner here, while the mains are only so-so; tea-lovers will appreciate the personal pot service and eclectic selection of Gryphon teas. Avoid the unwieldy, open-faced sandwiches and stick with the sweet stuff: a just-right chocolate cake and Swedish pancakes with preserves go down a treat.

Tucked away at the end of a quiet road, this cake shop is a hood favourite thanks to its rich chocolate fudge cake made from Belgian chocolate. Customised creations are also on offer fashion a cake complete with cream or fondant finishing in the form of a jeep, poker table, pink garden or whatever you fancy. These cakes (from $38 per kg) and cupcakes (from $2.50 each), and pre-orders, take a minimum of three days, while wedding cakes (from $38 per kg) take a week to whip up.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Sat 11am-8pm; Sun 11am-6pm. Closed every last Monday of the month.

content.description: How do you know a neighbourhood is becoming more gentrified? When a gourmet deli/butcher sets up shop. Open since July 2008, Hubers is more than just a meat seller, theyve styled this outlet along a more gourmet angle, selling imported dairy products, frozen seafood, salads, fresh breads and even fondue pots. Beyond being the purveyors of prime cuts of meat popular items include the Australian Stockyard Angus grain-fed beef, lamb chops and sausages the staff can also attend to any of your portion cutting, marinating, roasting, vacuum packing needs. And as all the butchers are former cooks and chefs, you know your grub is safe in their hands.Free home delivery for orders over $75.
Email brnd_low@yahoo.com.sg for more information

entry.name: Xu Jun Sheng (Long Ji) Chao Zhou Mei Shi

version.name: Xu Jun Sheng (Long Ji) Chao Zhou Mei Shi

content.description: With its myriad buzzing KTV lounges and sleazy nightclubs, Joo Chiat seems to be anchored as Singapores alternative red-light precinct, but the foodies among us know that its distinctive dining culture is part of its inimitable charm. Take the Teochew tze char (stir fry) stall Xu Jun Sheng Chao Zhou Mei Shi, a fluorescent-lit pre-war coffee shop. For 60 years it has been dishing out piping hot Teochew porridge from an unembellished kopitiam at Joo Chiat (incidentally, they recently moved across the street to another unit). On offer are heartwarming classics arranged on a glass counter including slow-braised pork knuckles in a thick, dark brew, and fried-to-order ngoh hiang (meat rolls). But what really steals the show is the star seafood cast: a whole pomfret fish steamed simply with salted vegetables in a light consommé; chunks of cold crab brimming with creamy golden roe; and a crispy wok-fried oyster omelette. Their not too sweet or nee (yam paste) crowned with chunks of golden pumpkin is the best weve had in a long time.Main courses $4-$35.

There was a time when foodies assumed the torpid neighbourhood of Macpherson would never make it on to their must eat radar screen, but it did. Thanks to Ming Kee, which opened five years ago, Macpherson has been drawing a steady stream of food bloggers and gourmets; even a well-known dignitary has graced this eatery, as evidenced by the pictures that neatly adorn the curtain-lined walls. The lure? Rustic, non-denominational Chinese food seasoned with aplomb. As the name implies, the star attraction here is the live seafood displayed discreetly in tanks at the back of the air-conditioned restaurant. The crème de la crème of the seafood is the luscious steamed mussels which look more like giant clams in an addictive, fried garlic-streaked sauce. The claypot Sri Lankan crab tossed with crab roe-studded bee hoon, another popular dish here, was pleasant but slightly overdone. Other items that shine from the extensive menu include the tender fried spare ribs flavoured with a Guinness sauce and the bubbling-hot claypot bean curd with seasonal vegetables.Main courses from $18.

Have it your way is BKs motto, but what they really meant was: have it your way as long as its on our menu. Thats all changed with the launch of its Whopper Bar, where carnivorous customers can customise their burgers with one to three beef patties and 24 topping choices.
Embraced by nature. SAFRA Yishun Country Club is a place where family and friends can relax, dine or play.

content.vendor-category: Well & Good | Deals of the month

content.description: Just as oysters are rough on the outside but hold polished pearls within their clutches, Le Perle Noir is a pleasant surprise among the dark-windowed sports bars and massage parlours that surround it. Diners can sit on the leafy outdoor patio, or step inside to the much more civilised, wood-bedecked interior. The scallop entrée was perfectly seared and paired with a tuft of bacon-infused arugula and drizzled with an orange whisky sauce. The prosciuttowrapped cod was a real palate-dazzler, resting regally on its bed of mustardy Puy lentils and finished with a brushstroke of macadamia nut pesto. As fusion-filled as the menu is, some of the true delights here are the simplest a mouthwatering grilled pork chop, mussels in your choice of broth, or super-fresh oysters. A bit pricey, but arent all pearls?
content.openingtimes: Daily noon-3pm, 6-10pm; Sun noon-3pm, 4-10pm; closed Tue.

content.description: This 60-year-old casual eatery is jam-packed with plastic tables, the walls are peeling and the detritus left behind by enthusiastic diners on curry-stained bowls may offer nothing more than a sordid sight. But this still does not detract from the lush and homey Malay fare on offer. Standout dishes include the wickedly dense and extravagantly spiced beef rendang; the light but no less spicy tamarind-laced ikan penggang in black sweet sauce with a fresh toss of onions and chillis; the mild-on-heat but rich-in-flavour ayam bakar; and the crisp, moist and onion-streaked fried omelette. Dont miss their house soup, a savoury beef consommé with caramelised shallots and chunks of potatoes and carrots.Costs: Main courses $5
Zhenghua Park is linked to the Western Adventure Park Connector Network by Bukit Panjang and Pang Sua Park Connectors.

Your body is a temple, but sometimes that temple needs a little janitorial maintenance. Body with Soul a sanctuary of wellbeing is opening its doors for just that health services that emphasise a holistic approach to get your body back into tip-top temple shape. Located in the new, posh Rochester Park @ one-north area, the healing facility feels more like a spa than a doctors office its services include consultations with general practitioners, counsellors, physiotherapists and speech therapists, among others. But here health in the whole isnt limited to appointments with a medical degree; it also includes exercise and nutrition. Choose from yoga, pilates, a nutritional café or getting your hands dirty in holistic gardening classes.

Singapores love of Italian fare has proved a double-edged sword. While there are many options to choose from, finding a good one without a $$$$ price tag remains a challenge. Enter Donna Carmela, a neighbourhood eatery that is turning heads and whetting appetites. Run by the same Sicilian family who opened Mamma Lucia, the pasta menu is the size of a novella, and you will need a few visits to do it justice. Hard to resist are the parcels of ravioli, dressed a myriad of ways, and wine from the familys own vineyards in Verona and Sicily, passionately extolled by manager Simone. For favoloso fare that fills the belly but doesnt drain the wallet, try dinner at Donnas. Costs: Main courses $15-$25
