The Action Theatre is housed within a pre-war two-storey bungalow house consisting of: One intimate 100-seat studio theatre Two outdoor performance spaces One classroom One book & CD shop

This tiny jewel box of a store is filled with precious gems of chocolate in flavours such as banana split, orange lemongrass, vodka orange and white rose. Owner Brendan Chin not only imports the finest chocolates from Switzerland, he makes several of his own. A box of chocolate gold will cost you $17 for 100g (eight to 12 pieces).

The durian puffs here are famous island-wide spongy golden cake surrounding generous portions of creamy puréed durian that doesnt shy away from delivering full-force flavour. Youll pay only $11 for a box of 20.

Linger over café tables flanked by clear Lucite chairs and jazzy, loungy sounds that slink out of the speakers, and pick from an impressive variety of cheesecakes, verrines (desserts served in a glass) and individually sized dome cakes.

This is the source of magical-tasting cookies, mooncakes and pineapple tarts. The shop has a generous tasting policy so you can sample the rich, buttery cookies that literally melt in your mouth, or buy sample packs for $2.50 (full boxes run between $14 and $27).

Coffee lovers can experience coffee in the form of quality coffee education, freshly-roasted coffee beans, and coffee machines or accessories to make that perfect cup of java. If you're just too lazy, then grab a cuppa of coffee at their coffee bar.
Highlander Coffee barristers

Here's what you'll get at Orchard Central: Cluster-concept shopping divvied up into unimaginatively named sections like The Runway and Indulge, just so you can zone in directly on what seduces you most whether it is youth-appeal street cult labels, or extravagant, eye-popping timepieces and jewellery along the 140m Discovery Walk that links the mall to Somerset MRT station Whats a wall for, if not for climbing? Orchard Central boasts Singapores first indoor, five-storey rock-climbing wall The Med at basement 2, a complete level that showcases all things Mediterranean-themed, from sharp apparel to spicy slices of pepperoni pizza. Charming Italian men not included Speed is of the essence when it comes to snagging best buys. Thats why theyve installed three superescalators and six express lifts moving between 500 and 2,000ft/min not that youll notice thanks to the cabin pressure. Still, it does bring shoppers to their floor of choice in double-quick time. And with 12 floors to peruse, swooshing devices like these really help bring in the shopping haul.

Here's what you'll get at ION Orchard: ION Sky, a double-storey observation deck on the top two floors of this 56-storey building (sorry folks, the other 48 floors are dedicated to a luxury living complex), allows you to cast your bargain-trained eye along the axis of retail that is Scotts Road, Orchard Road and beyond. This free view will be a welcome respite after eight floors worth of frenzied shopping (opens in late 2010). A media membrane, a 117m skin that wraps round the complex, will broadcast telecasts of events and shows, while ION2, the largest sheltered area on Orchard Road, will play host to national parties and the all-important weekend roadshow. This is about a lot more than just shopping. Art, and lots of it at the 5,300 sq ft ION Art level, where Opera Gallery has been confirmed as a tenant. 330 shops and restaurants that sell designer brands such as Cartier, Dior, Dolce & Gabbana, Giorgio Armani, Louis Vuitton, and Prada, as well as the dependable staples from Topshop/ Topman, Uniqlo and Zara.
Clothes for children up to the age of 14. From France.
It's all about ties at Ben Sherman.
This global fashion brand from the USA is synonymous with the soft home furnishings and products.
content.openingtimes: Depends on shop location. Generally opens Daily 11am-9.30pm

content.description: Suburban Spanish fare is something youd expect to find in the back streets of Barcelona, not a shophouse bordering Bukit Batok. But in just nine months, Don Quijote has become the casa of choice for lovers of Spains lip-smacking food and wine. The blink-and-youll-miss-it establishment off Jalan Jurong Kechil boasts a bountiful array of delicioso classics, like the sizzling seafood paella Valenciana with its rice in a pan, pinchos morunos (beef on the spit), rollitos de espárragos y beicon (asparagus and bacon rolls) and the pastel de chocolate caliente (hot chocolate cake). Complement it all with a glass or three of sangria and youll be rolling your rs before the bill arrives.

If youre cutting back on eating out but need something delicious to munch, La Noce (The Walnut) is just what youre looking for. Set amid a housing estate in Hillview between two Bukits (Timah and Gombak), this off-the-beatentrack boutique eatery serves up home-style Italian favourites with a Sicilian flair. After running busy kitchens both here and abroad, chef/owner Salvatore Catalano adds the personal touch to his flavoursome, albeit small selection of dishes: savour the home-made gnocchi in walnut cream sauce, and the aptly named Salvatore pizza with artichokes and zesty buffalo mozzarella layered on a perfectly crispy crust. With its quaint, personable feel, and a seating capacity of just 40, La Noce is ideal for a catch-up with friends or a quiet romantic twosome.

Hotel Re! takes a huge page from Bruce Lee's past and decks out its 140 rooms in psychedelic disco hues and vintage furniture such as the Bubble chair by Finnish designer Eero Aarnio. Just because it harkens back to the days of Saturday Night Fever, it doesn't mean that you'll have to skimp on modern business comforts. Every room comes with: Complimentary 24-hours WIFI Room Service Complimentary Cable TV LCD TV Digital In-Room Safe Mini-Bar Iron & Board / Baby Cot (Upon request) Laundry & Dry Cleaning ServicesIt's also situated close to old Chinatown and architectural icon Pearls Bank Apartment.

Upscale and downtown, Pawtobello gives the competition something to bark about with its beautifully coiffed premises a French chandelier, damask chairs and imported tassel lampshades cast a spell over owners and pets. Fourlegged princesses dine on doggie crêpes, chicken roulade and muttloaf, while doting owners look forward to schnitzel, steaks and Sachertorte in this proper European restaurant.

Despite being wedged away on the top floor of Far East Plazas rabbit warren, this tiny hole in the wall has been packing them in for years. The main attraction is the yakitori. Prices start from a reasonable $4 for two sticks, while the range is yummy: potato wedges wrapped with bacon and dabbed with butter, bishops noses, and curls of chicken skin. Pair with one of the very reasonable set meals like the tenju (tempura vegetables and prawns), while the Obento set comes with its own yakitori sticks.
El Barrio was featured in Convival Pursuit: Wild West Pubs.
Beaver's The American Pub was featured in Convival Pursuit: Centered & Down South Pubs.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Thu noon-1am; Fri noon-2am; Sat noon-1am; Sun 5pm-midnight.

content.description: O-Bar & Restaurantwas featured in Convival Pursuit: Up North Pubs.

Meaning little boat in French, the over-a-century-old European label has made its first inroads in the South- East Asian market by securing prime retail space in Tanglin Mall. Already a global name with 180 boutiques internationally, the charming shop is surrounded by floors of educational toys, organic food, pricey footwear and clothing for kids at this family-centric mall. Petit Bateau has kept its prices reasonable, yet not shirked quality 12 kilometres of cotton thread are used for just one T-shirt, which has the smoothest feel and is sure to keep your little one cool. Catering to kids, from babies all the way up to 12-year-olds, as well as stocking loungewear for adults, Petit Bateaus unisex styles in fun colours easily complement an existing wardrobe, and are very practical for the humid climate in Singapore. Besides breathable cotton, silk knits and bamboo jersey are also used to clothe mummys rack.

It takes a special kind of bravado to successfully decorate a restaurant like Myras Beach Club. As you prop your sandy self up at their spacious bar and survey Myras interior, the odd mix of the small live-music stage decorated with a bullfighting poster, surfboard adorned with flashing fairy lights and zombie-shooting arcade game will have you wondering what misguided delights await you on their menu. Somehow, the eclectic decor works well and the food does not disappoint. The quesadillas are moist without being greasy, and livened up with mixed cheese, jalapeños and fresh cilantro. The burritos offer a more hearty feed, though the beef variety tastes a little low-grade in quality. Mexican natives may get a little hot under the poncho with the absence of guacamole as a side, but on the whole, Myras whips up an impressively authentic menu.

Nestled in a row of shophouses off Tanjong Pagar Road, this no-frills pub used to go under the moniker Shamus ODonnells. Mixing it up a tad, new owners Aidan and Andrew have carried on some traditions (affordable booze) while adding their own (Guitar Hero, anyone)? What the pub lacks in aesthetics, the well-stocked bar makes up for; true to form, Guinness is on tap. For the more daring, the politically incorrect Irish Car Bomb ($20) will get your pistons pumping. Free of the pretensions of other bars in the hood, at OBamas you can park your carcass and have a good chinwag, while chowing down on a Guinness-brewed Irish stew.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Wed noon-midnight, Thu-Frinoon-2am, Sat noon-4am, Sun 4pm-midnight.

content.description: Indonesian chef Gunawan Wibisono, a former protégé of American Iron Chef Morimoto Masaharu, has attempted to create another one of those modern Japanese restaurants with never-seen-before dishes at Dempsey Hills Zento. His creative efforts have not, unlike many rival eateries, been put completely to shame.Any waiter who starts off your meal with a free cup of sake is okay in my books. This turned out to be a smart move on his part, as my good first impressions gradually decreased throughout the night. First off, when ordering the carpaccio topped with ginger garlic yozu sauce, he enquired whether we would like that served with yellowtail or Wagyu beef conveniently failing to mention that the Wagyu choice would double the price listed on the menu. It was a good thing that the razor-thin slices of meat, drizzled with hot grapeseed oil used to sear the top, turned out to be a favourite dish of both myself and my companion; it helped, too, that we were not aware of the add-on at the time.In addition, all the waiters had a habit of hovering like vultures, and while my dining partner was lucky to be facing the wall, I was eating nervously, feeling that the second I put down my chopsticks, my dish would be scooped up before I could savour the last remaining bites. Having said that, we appreciated the over-attentiveness when, upon arriving on a rainy afternoon for our second visit, an umbrella-equipped waiter ran outside to the taxi to provide cover for the walk to the restaurant. Service aside, lets get back to the food. The innovative Wagyu Beef Roll is stuffed with shrimp tempura and topped with thin slices of gruyèredrizzled beef, and Im delighted to say that it was not just the cheese but the entire roll which melted in my mouth. With sushi, its never bad to go the old-school route (read: 40 years after the inception of the California roll, this seems like a fair classification) to see how some of the more traditional rolls compare. This proved to be a wise decision when it came to the Volcano Roll, whose copious lashings of spicy mayo were perfectly cut with sweet eel sauce.During our second visit, we decided to go with a standard lunch sushi set ($35) this one being served straight up, no frills attached. With no sauces or surprise ingredients left to mask the quality of the fish, our eight-nigiri, five-sushi selection did not match up to the high standard set by the more imaginative rolls. Standing on its own, the rice lacked that sticky sweetness needed when creating a bed for the fish. The thick cuts of average fish were also not helping matters. It seems as though its best for chef Wibisono to keep thinking outside the box, since the final result is much more enjoyable to unpack.Its probably best to skip on dessert; the undistinguished green-tea crème brûlée presented a curdled centre and the chocolate lava cake while delicious was not anything new. And its just as well: the bill adds up quickly without, and after discovering how our carpaccio had mischievously doubled in price, we were eager to head out of the door.Costs: Lunch sets $18-$65; dinner sets $58-$120.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Fri 3-6pm; Sun-Sat noon-3pm; Sun-Thu 6-10pm; Fri & Sat 6-11pm.

content.description: In this age of email and social networking sites, one might say stationery store Kikki.K is stuck in the past. But take one look at its decorative letterheads and personalised pieces of parchment, and suddenly you feel the urge to write grandma a lovely handwritten note. Now open at ION Orchard, the store also sells other packaging accessories like Christmas to/from sticker labels, colourful wrapping, snowflake-dotted ribbons and next years must-have, the 2010 Planner with sections for you to note down your favourite shops and restaurants.

French swimwear label JOG has launched its latest line for ladies just in time for the year-end beach holiday. Bikinis, sexy one-pieces and several cut-pieces (somewhere between a oneand two-piece) have been detailed with feminine French florals and bows. Chic cuts channelling Marilyn Monroe (all white with a thick halter tie) are also ready for this seasons beach or pool party.
Serves American Southwest cuisine in an colonial-style, black and white bungalow with a tropical garden to boot.

Patrons stake out this brightly-coloured shop for its ever-changing roster of gelato flavours. With a rotating cast of 24 to choose from, top favourites include durian, frutti di bosco (a mixture of three berries), bacio (nuts and chocolate) and passionfruit. If you’re hungry for more than a scoop (from $3.30 per scoop to $9.80 for a palette of six), take home a tub of 500g ($12.90) or go all out with the one kilo pack ($23.90).

Every neighbourhood needs a local, and Maple Pub has been filling this niche for some time now. It attracts a regular crowd of thirty-somethings who chow down on yakitori sticks, washing it all back with mugs of ice-cold beer. On Tuesdays and Saturdays, free snacks such as chicken wings and fishcakes are served, while Wednesdays and Saturdays see special beer promotions pushed during the happy hour period (4-9pm). Tapping into Singapores love for anything free, the pub also holds a regular lucky draw. For every $100 spent, patrons can win booze goodies ranging from a mug of beer to a bottle of Martell.

*SPECIAL OFFER FOR APRIL 2010*
All-first time visitors to Bliss Spa Singapore who book a Best of Skintentions facial ($125) will receive a free upgrade to their five-star (yep, we gave it full marks) Triple Oxygen Facial ($185). To take advantage of this deal, mention 'Time Out' when booking. Valid throughout the month of April. Upgrade must take place on the same day as the facial.
Bliss Spa has finally arrived in Singapore. Setting up shop within the Sephora ION Orchard store, the Bliss set-up will feature a nail lounge, four recliners for on-the-spot minitreatments (try the oxygen blasts and seaweed masks) and four cosy (we think they mean small) capsule rooms for such treatments as the triple oxygen energising mask, or the hot milk and almond pedicure. Services aside, what sets Bliss apart are the cute extras a spa buffet with brownies, olives, crackers and cheese, and if you book any two treatments in a 30-minute time slot, or any three within 45 minutes, youll be distracted with a classic movie.

The nondescript location, tucked away behind Orchard Parade Hotel, hasnt stopped regulars from coming back. Grandmas was opened in late 2008 by the same folk who run the popular Akashi Japanese Restaurant. Boldly flavoured Malaysian and Singaporean favourites are whipped up by chef Yong Shang Hoo, formerly of KLs Madam Kwan, and famous for his nasi lemak speciality. Yongs version here is equally well executed. Youll find chicken curry perfumed with rich coconut milk, sambal ikan bilis (fried dried anchovies), shrimp floss, egg and achar (pickles), all sharing the plate with the coconut-infused rice. Other standout dishes include juicy assam prawns, bound with a punchy sauce and heaps of onions and chilli; beyond-tender beef rendang balanced with aromatic spices; and wokfragrant char kway teow. You can round off the meal with chendol or sago gula melaka. Both treats were laced with the thick home-made palm sugar syrup and freshly squeezed coconut milk.Main courses $3.80-$28.80

One of ION Orchards new hotspots, this Hong Kong transplant is a good place to scoff down comfort Cantonese fare before hitting the stores. If you are there for lunch, try some of the more unusual dim sum selections, such as fish maw stuffed with minced pork and prawns, or bouncy crystal coriander dumplings. Moving along to the mains, we found a good range of perfect-for-sharing dishes. The foil-baked garoupa fillet, crisp on the outside and succulent inside, is matched with a boldly flavoured barbecue sauce. Equally impressive is the beef tenderloin and brisket stewed with daikon slices until incredibly tender. The wok-tossed fried rice is a must-have, speckled with egg, dried scallops and seafood, it is served in a stone bowl to keep the ingredients warm. Tip: if you dont scoop it up fast enough the last grains will dry up. The service is lacking, but keep in mind that the restaurant is new and still smoothing out a few kinks.

Some people hate Dempsey Village, complaining that its too pretentious, expensive and full of expats. True, true and true. But for many it provides a much-needed escape from the overdose of mall culture that many of us suffer from. Its also about time Dempsey veterans such as Jones the Grocer and PS Café had a new café to give them a run for their money, as they can often be unbearably packed and overpriced.
Healthy combo at unbeatable value!: hardly a catchy slogan, but we shall see.

All hail the latest, and potentially greatest thing in town between two bits of bread, courtesy of the people behind the popular Soup Spoon franchise. Boasting the juiciest patties on the island, The Hand Burger also does a mean Nutella shake (warning: its sinful), and our favourite $3 mint iced lychee refresher. They also bake their own bread and sell it to go. Check out their brand new branch at 313@Somerset. Were not so sure about the name, though

Contrary to its name, this little cocktail bar is overflowing neither with people nor with staff. Tucked away on an odd little side street in the depths of Robertson Walk, Flows dark exterior and tinted windows would actually make for a perfect brothel. Open the large glass doors, and youll find that the interior makes the same impression. But this little dark bar is a hidden gem, and were quite reticent to share it, because here youll find a drinkers dream come true. The menu offers lists of whiskies, scotches, gins and cocktails as long as your arm, and its bar staff know what theyre doing. The Long Island iced tea lives up to its name it is long indeed and incredibly strong. Hurrah! And the dry martini deserves a medal as well. Please promise that you wont run around town spreading the word.

What do you get when you cross tom yum soup with a German lager? Tawandang Microbrewery. Yet another
addition to the perennially hip enclave of Dempsey Hill, this Thai-owned restaurant offers an unusual pairing. Three signature German beers are brewed on-site and can be paired with dishes like flaming tom yum goong with river prawns, and papaya salad with salted crab. Those looking to follow a more traditional route can opt for melt-inyour- mouth deep-fried pork knuckle and sausages, topped up with sauerkraut. From Tuesday through Saturday the cavernous restaurant reverberates with the innately nasal but endearing sounds of an authentic Thai band, delivering local ballads and English covers. While its sheer size makes it hard to attract waiting staff, Tawandang has the type of atmosphere you cannot beer to pass up.Main course $10-$25

Pinched from a Michelinstarred restaurant in London, chef Paul Longworth now presides over a blackswathed, glass-encased dining room wherehe performs his culinary nips, tucks and chops behind a U-shaped marble-topped table. The result? A part-French, part-Swiss vino-incarnated gastrobar the restaurant offers 200 bottles of Swiss wine. We love the caviar-flecked mussel velouté, tender slowbraised ox cheeks laced with caramelised shallots and snapper in a heavenly, red pepper-reduced sauce crowned with green olive pearls. To top up the Swiss theme, raclette and fondue also find their way onto the menu.

Cant get enough of trendy clothes at low prices? Sprint over to the latest Brit high-street import, New Look. While it isnt Primark or H&M (why arent you in Singapore?), the brand is known for stocking shoes, clothing and accessories at bargain prices. With racks replenished every week and a shelf-life of not more than five weeks, youd be mad to pass up togs that start from $9.90 and generally hover under $80. A haven for the fashion-fickle who like to frequently update their wardrobe.

In the mood for threads that are exuberant and daring? Custo Barcelona is adding flamboyance to Spanish fashion offerings here with its collections of bright colours, funky prints and fabrics. Their clothes have been spotted on A-listers Julia Roberts, Jennifer Aniston, Pénelope Cruz, Beyoncé and Antonio Banderas, so you might want to check out for yourself what the hype is all about.

New blood is always a good thing. Spanish newbie label Bershka offers funky fashion for teens, young women and men. The womens department has two lines, Bershka and BSK, with the latter for younger shoppers (think under-18s). The icing on the cake: new stocks arrive twice a week. In line with the labels strong association with urban culture in particular electronic music they have set up Club Bershka, made up of the DJ Academy and DJ Playground. The Academy will have popular DJ Hasnor and DJ KoFlow giving classes, while the Playground will pick talented young music enthusiasts to spin at the store.

Heading to this new bookstore/stationery shop on the top floor of ION, I was prepared for the usual suspects: $6 ballpoint pens and chic city guides. What I did not expect was one of the neatest, most impressive graphic novel/comics sections outside of Kinokuniya, with a focus on independent publications sorted by author.
So this is where all the elusive copies of Strangehaven are, along with obscure treats from indie publishers like Oni Press and writers like Matt Fraction.
Besides an overwhelming flood of nerdish joy, the initial, most noticeable pro was that I didnt have to jostle for space with whiny children or surly comic fans. The new kid on the biblio-block is run by (surprise, surprise) book and stationery titan Popular, but its classier sibling isnt for kids looking for study guides.
For one thing, its not strategically placed in an accessible, traffic-heavy location like Borders, and the in-store café, JAMS, serves the sort of organic-coffee-and-profiteroles selection thatll burn a hole in the average wallet.
Browsers at Popular suffer under cruel fluorescent lighting, while {prologue} has a little more ambience just beware of the relentless soft-rock soundtrack. The rest of the shop sections offer typical big-bookstore titles, but looking out of the windows at Orchards leafy green treetops, the difference between here and say, a Page One, is that I dont want to leave. Alexis Ong

Carved out of a Peranakan shophouse, Speakeasys seating capacity amounts to just four outdoor tables, but theres not the merest whiff of exclusivity that such minimal provision might suggest. As you saunter into the bar area, a roaring twenties soundtrack floats above chic panelling and glass-filled cabinets. Ask your friendly host to pour you a wine or beer, or mix you a Prohibition-era cocktail, and settle on a comfy bench next to a friendly tortoiseshell cat. Even the opening hours seem somehow cool: just four nights a week, with $8 cocktails on a Wednesday. Evocatively blending modern pizzazz with retro-chic yet not a mite pretentious, Speakeasy amounts to the ultimate date venue. Were almost loath to mention this tiny treasure; wed love it to remain bar-worlds best-kept secret.

There are two things you must bear in mind: one, the name refers neither to body parts, nor to the plumage on roosters. Two, there are almost 40 cocktails shaken, stirred, mixed and foamed on the menu. You can stick to the standards but whats the fun in that? Try the Chocolate Indulgence ($16), a dessert cocktail that uses Hersheys chocolate spiked with alcohol and garnished with vanilla flakes. Several of Cocks Feathers cocktails cater to those with a sweet tooth, so if youre looking for something dry, go with wine. Skip their molecular cocktails: the Foamy Bellini ($20) looks like a golden Guinness, but the champagne and peach do not integrate at all. Drop by between 8pm and 10pm to buy one cocktail and get one free. They state firmly that both cocktails must be the same, but rules are meant to be brokenif you ask nicely.

This sprawling local eatery spanning three shophouses and a canalside patio area is fast becoming a one-stop-shop for connoisseurs of flavourful crab and everything else the sea has to offer. Delivered fast and fresh, Big Eater serves up crab cooked 14 ways, including house specialities with salted egg, black pepper and stewed with beehoon. This is complemented by eight styles of succulent king prawns, lobster and more than 20 other chefs musttries. Ice-cold jugs of beer are available and the staff is more than willing to help you net the best selections. Of course if you reach your quota, you can always da bao (takeaway) and tackle it again when the appetite allows. Shelling out close to 200 crabs daily on weekends, youd be wise to book your big catch ahead of time.

Situated at the far north-east of Singapore, Compass Point has Metro, Best Denki, Cold Storage, Kopitiam Spectrum food court, Kiddy Palace and POPULAR Bookstore as its anchor tenants. The shopping centre is also Singapores first Learning Mall where you can glean nuggets of information while shopping.

Conveniently located, but confused as a frog in a sock, Deli-Vege provides a 7-Eleven atmosphere masquerading as urban chic. Sitting gingerly among your new surroundings, enjoy the murals on the wall that offer appetite-suppressing statements about animals pathetic bodies suffering electric shocks while their families are slaughtered. We couldnt help but feel that the decors message was preaching to the choir. While the menu offers a wide range, navigating the menus layout and grammar was an arduous task. The saving grace was in the food and delicious juices, both of which were fresh and reasonably priced. Sceptics can head straight to the black-pepper steak or impressively authentic mock prawns for a hit of guilt-free carcass, while the tempura got a thumbs-up from both judges and the animal kingdom. With better-sized portions than most and a waiter who arrives and departs from your table in eerie silence (okay, terrifying), well be back. Only beware of the spring rolls: they were the only thing left on our plates at the end of the meal.

Fans of Japanese fashion line Uniqlo must be quivering with anticipation at the prospect of its 10,000 sq ft duplex opening at ION Orchard later this month. Just to add extra spice to the occasion, selected autumn/winter 09 items will be unveiled. Make sure to book a winter holiday so you can stock up on all of the cold-weather gear. Theres the Neo Leather range, a collection of luxury synthetic leather jackets; the Flannel range of clothing, available here before it hits Japan; and a free collectable tote bag for purchases of $100 and up. The hip quotient is given an extra boost with a dedicated corner featuring the brands cult T-shirt label, UT, which taps into the talents of renowned artists Gareth Pugh, Terry Richardson and Nobuyoshi Araki for its designs.

Taking up residence at the old Bukit Timah Fire Station, this gastrobar has set alight a once sleepy part of the island. Making use of the quaint barracks, first built in the 50s, and bordering Bukit Timah Hill, the café/bar draws an eclectic blend of local and expat customers. While the mains dont break any new ground, the sizeable gourmet pizzas and ample selection of tapas, imported beers and cocktails are sure to arouse an appetite in most. Though the young, less experienced wait-staff has yet to find its feet, the Firestation is a decent locale to chow down with the gang before the night really begins to smoulder.Costs: Main courses $18-$30

If you dont mind smelling like smoky, meaty goodness, this is a great new lunch spot for getting over the Monday blues (or a hangover). We recommend their double patty burgers for that extra juice and the generous helping of thickcut fries; sadly the wasabi mayo is toned down for non-local tastes and doesnt have the zing we expected, but the place serves beer so you can get your lunchtime pint if you have space left these burgers are seriously filling. Costs: Main courses $11

Perhaps its the rich, cloudy pork bone collagen broth or maybe its the plump slices of tender roast pork that attracts an almost permanent lunchtime queue of Japanese families outside this tucked-away ramen hotspot. Either way, theyre hankering for a taste of Santoukas outstanding Toroniku (roasted pork cheek) ramen in salt, soy sauce, miso and kara-miso (a spicier soybean paste) flavours. As the hottest item on the menu, only 60 portions are available daily. Another item you should not skip out on is a side order of komi tamago (boiled soya flavoured egg), its egg-cellent.Main course $4-$19.50
This restaurant was featured in 'The High Five: Bowls or Ramen' (TOS Feb 2010)
Fun theatre space that focuses on kid-centric activities and drama.
A watering hole attached to The White Rabbit. Read also: Nightlife preview on The White Rabbit.

Brasserie Les Saveurs at the St Regis will certainly satisfy your buffet cravings. Theyre offering international buffets at lunch and dinner throughout the entire week. If youre a seafood fan, then go on Fridays when youll get to pick from a smorgasbord of shellfish and fresh fish. Their Sunday brunch might be on the extravagant side, but it's worth it for the quality of food and champagne.Costs: Mon-Thu: lunch $48, dinner $58 Fri: lunch $58, dinner $68 Sun: lunch $128-$338Call 6506 6866 or email dining.singapore@stregis.com to make a reservation.
This restaurant boasts classy décor and modern European-styled dishes. Go for their Wagyu beef carpaccio ($28).

Forgive its location, wedged in the foyer of a boutique hotel and situated on a street full of karaoke bars. The food is fantastic, the wine list well priced, the service warm and attentive, and the ambience perfectly pleasant. The starter of Parma ham with spinach leaves and porcini mushrooms was a perfect example of the simple, rustic fare on offer at Saraceno; the beef carpaccio was similarly delicious with its clean, well-balanced flavours; and the beef cheek braised in red wine, the chef told us, takes him two days to cook now thats commitment. A dessert of chocolate fondant with vanilla ice cream made the perfect ending to the meal, with warm chocolate oozing from a surprisingly light sponge. Other touches such as complimentary olives, home-made breads with punchy olive oil and an after-dinner limoncello liqueur just added to the overall experience.Main courses $18-$38.

This exercise lab provides specialist workout programmes and testing to anyone who's interested in losing weight or performing better at their sport. Costs: fatMELT: $250 Body composition: $100 Fuel efficiency: $250 Lactate: $275 VO2max: $250

This boutique bakery lets your choose a cake flavour Nutella, cinnamon walnut or raspberry chocolate, just to name a few and match it with your favourite butter-cream icing (say banana, mandarin orange, or even durian). While the number of possible combinations is intimidating, they have a more manageable list of recommended pairings to help you decide. Try the Healthy Bunny (carrot cake with cream-cheese icing), the Nuts About You (Nutella base topped with Nutella cream), or the Peek a Boo (peanut butter brownie cake topped with banana butter cream).
Sells practical and fashionable clothing for breastfeeding mothers.

Originating from Denmark, ZONE Denmark is a leading homeware brand within and outside of Europe. You'll get Scandinavian homeware and interior design products with a focus on classical minimalism, functionality and quality.

In troubled economic times like these, value-for-money dining concepts go down especially well. Offering over 50 choices for Singapores global diner, there are safe options such as fragrant lemongrass pork, tender scallops with spiced butter and sticks of chicken stuffed with creamy ricotta. The more adventurous can pick and choose from succulent prawns with finger-licking good walnut pesto, grilled quail with five-spice powder (not recommended for game-meat virgins) and a surprisingly tasty Mongolian ostrich skewer. Those worried about consuming an all-protein meal can hit up the unlimited salad bar (add on $8), while the dessert bar (add on $6) will fulfil all your sugar cravings.

No, we dont mean the character from the Brothers Grimm tale, were talking about The Hansel Shop, which is the newest addition to Stamford House. This season, designer Jo Sohs creations centre on Robot Girl, a fem-bot chic collection, all about block shapes and cutesy pieces that can be dressed up for the boardroom. Look for simple shift dresses jazzed up with big bow details, block colours given pizzazz with yellow, red or polka dots and Hansels collaboration with accessories brand t43 Jewellery.Photos by Paula Sgarbi

The ibis hotel on Bencoolen Street is Singapores first internationally branded economy hotel. The ibis boasts contemporary, stylish furnishings complete with Wi-Fi internet access and cable channels on flat-screen TVs. Located within the proximity of the Bugis, Orchard Road, and CBD areas, travellers can easily access the cultural, shopping, and business hubs of Singapore.Cost: Rooms start from $148++

Better suited to long-term guests, this serviced apartment was awarded the URA Architectural Heritage Award in 2002. Its filled with delightful Peranakan details like wooden floors, carved screens, furnishings and airy courtyards. Besides offering guests a slice of Straits Chinese culture, a quick walk round this neighbourhood, littered with convenience stores, pubs and dozens of small restaurants, gives an instant home-away-from-home feeling. Cost: from $1,260 per week

Converted from a set of former stables, this tucked away spot just off Dunearn Road has a placid rural landscape. The two-storey lodge has 40 spacious rooms, a lawn for sun-tanning/picnicking purposes, Wi-Fi and conference rooms for companies looking to take their AGMs off-site. Pony rides for kids, horseback riding lessons and a nearby golf course make this a great weekend getaway. The shops arent too far off either; Turf City is just a quick gallop round the corner.

The best seats in the house are by the balcony overlooking the horses paddock and training circle. The small menu is imaginative and executed with such panache you have to wonder how long it will be before the chef is poached. Thick, gooey buffalo wings and a firm round of Portobello topped with blue cheese set the stage for the best fish and chips in town. The chocolate cake is blanketed in a velvet chocolate sauce, while the deconstructed strawberry shortcake hums with cream so light its practically foam. Everything here shows up the inferiority of the neighbouring Mimolette.

Dont worry this isnt some seedy pick-up joint. My Type simply serves food specially made for people under each specific blood group. The jury may be out on the medical front, but it still makes for an interesting meal. Besides, the menu is free of processed or GMO ingredients, or trans fat. The O meal includes a generously portioned row of sweet ocean trout sashimi on a thicket of rocket, a moist brick of grilled sea bass and a yummy blueberry smoothie. The A meal, on the other hand, includes snowy scallop discs, roast chicken and jasmine tea jelly.Main courses $26-$38.

Another month, another Harry's. The Sail @ Marina Bay is the chain's 27th outlet across the island, hoping to cater to the business crowd working nearby with added bonuses such as free Wi-Fi and Bluetooth and a 'gastronomic food menu'.
content.openingtimes: Mon - Thurs 11am - 1am; Fri, Sat, Sun and Eve of PH 11am - 2am

content.description: Swanky hair salon Next has just opened its newest venue downtown at McCallum street meaning that you don't have to make the trek to Holland Village anymore.

This mid-priced local street label is hot in both the fashion and club scenes. Several DJs are walking models for the brand, as are a few local party animals. Occasional collaborations with American graffiti artists, such as the San Francisco-based Sam Flores, gives Flesh Imp added street cred.
'Temple of Thanksgiving' is Singapore's first ecologically green temple, rebuilt in 2003.

Making the best of a bad situation, Chia Sek Hoong closed up his unprofitable chicken farm on Clementi Road and, with a secret recipe acquired from a famous Chinese opera singer, launched a restaurant in its place in 1962. Nearly 50 years on, the Chias are still pulling in punters wanting to savour their renowned zi bao ji a chicken dish that was once served wrapped in newspaper. These small parcels of steamed chicken, rice wine, ginger and undisclosed secret herbs and sauces have intoxicated many a food reviewer over the years (their articles line the eaterys walls), and continue to do so now. The tender morsels wrapped in old newspaper come in batches of six, to a towering 60. Other local temptations include the crispy home-made cuttlefish balls and ginsenginfused chicken soup.

entry.name: The Gallery of Gnani Arts (The Regent)

version.name: The Gallery of Gnani Arts (The Regent)

content.description: In the Tamil language, the word 'Gnani' (pronounced as 'Niyani') refers to one who is enlightened, spiritually or intellectually. Founded in early 2003, The Gallery of Gnani Arts has been a local and regional trend-setter within its area of research and collection expertise - South Indian contemporary art by masters and international artists. The curated collection includes charismatic sculptures (granite, bronze, copper), elucidating paintings, lithographs and thematic drawings.

SAFRA's latest family-orientated club, designed like a giant canpoy, boasts of a three-storey playground that has the tallest Foamball Arena, one of the highest indoor spiral slides in Asia, a swimming pool with interactive water features, and a gymnastics school for kids. Open to the public except for facilities such as tennis court, BBQ pits, slot machines and mahjong/card rooms.
Approx. S$46 56 per pax
Approx. S$37 – 47 per pax
Approx. S$58 – 68 per pax
Approx. S$20 30 per pax

Tippling Club Shaking things up a bit, Tippling has added new drinks to its menu. The latest creations include The Importance of Being Ernest, a cocktail inspired by Hemingway, which mixes Don Julio reposado, citrus, maraschino, orange juice, finished with an Ardbeg rinse; and Velvet Fog (gin, Crème de Violette, champagne, citrus and a floral violet fog), which pays tribute to velvet-voiced jazz vocalist Mel Tormés sobriquet.

Any Europhile tired of faltering takes on Western hospitality will find their pot of gold here: a speciality restaurant and alfresco bar co-managed by a Sicilian and a Neapolitan. If you think the seafood menus impressive, wait till you see the cocktail list. The 41 choices seemed daunting, but we got diligently to work on this tough journalistic assignment, uncovering a host of deceptively strong doozies in varying shades of pink. Sailors dont do a happy hour, but happy day thats the kind of bar we frequent. At the milder end, the margarita felt a tad mixer-like; the Cranberry Cooler resembles an experiment with bubble bath, and tastes less like amaretto than kids cough medicine. Speaking of cranberries, the rumladen Zombie has a lovely lemony aftertaste; but if youre after a real quick fix, sip on a near-perfect Long Island iced tea, or the Boston Beach Party: a gin-, Cointreau-, vodkaand rum-enhanced humdinger that unsurprisingly packs a major punch. Theyre all sweet, sometimes cloyingly so, but you wont need to stay long before you find your tongue loosening: in fact only our innate sense of modesty prevented us from requesting a Quick Screw. The wait-staff are an accommodating bunch, and attentive almost to a fault. Downers? Were not all Toto and James Blunt fans, thanks and is it really necessary to broadcast footie on TV at every riverside bar? But you wont get a more congenial setting than this and considering the swanky hood, the drinks price tags are as generous as their alcohol content.Jonathan Evans  Cocktails $7-$12; house wine by the glass $7.

Here youll spy some truly esoteric French cognac hidden among a wide range of non-alcoholic drinks. This spots worth a peek just for the completely random juxtaposition of liquor with hawker facilities. Kopi with your whiskey, sir?

This was the fi rst shop of its kind on Serangoon Road, and has the biggest range of drinkables and medicinal spirits around. The bottle-stocked façade of this liquor/medicinal shop may spark some curiosity and lure you in, but beware of the less than warm welcome youre likely to receive as well as what appears to be a no-fi xed-price policy.

Overlooking the green sanctuary of the Botanic Gardens from the top floor of a restored bungalow, the latest addition to the chain plays the sophisticated older sister to its more casual counterpart on Orchard Road. Black Angus succulent cuts of meat and refi ned service take Singapores steakhouses to a whole new level, adding up to an experience worthy of its idyllic setting. Sink your teeth into the complimentary peppery steak soup a meal in itself before tucking into the slow-roasted beef ribs or the 300g tenderfoot filet mignon seared over an open flame. With the only grouse being a hefty bill at the end, you may want to save your visit for special occasions of a refi ned carnivorous nature.Main courses $26-$60. By Marc Checkley

HDB estates are the last place youd expect to find a decent pizzeria. Butbelow a block of fl ats off Farrer Road, Indian chef Sunda prepares more than 150 traditional pizzas on his own every weekend, and knows the 30 varieties like the back of his fl oury hand. With not a shred of Italiano in him, Sunda only discovered his inner crust after taking a culinary sabbatical in Sicily. You wont fi nd Hawaiian or meat lovers cooking in this oven; instead there are signature specialities like the Grosseto, with crispy bacon, porcini mushrooms and tomatoes drizzled in the warm yolk of a poached egg. Equally inspired is the Perugia, with eggplant, zucchini, artichokes, sundried tomatoes and capers. The crusts are thin and crispy, and generously embellished with fresh toppings. Those dining in can bring their own wine; corkage is not charged.Marc Checkley Main courses $15-$22.

What can $6 buy you these days? At Lams Abalone Noodles (also affectionately called Ah Lam), it buys you a bowl of bak chor mee-style noodles served with minced pork, crunchy bits of deep-fried pork lard, pungent slabs of pork liver and a sliver of fragrant grilled tee po (dried fl at fi sh) topped with braised and skewered abalone cubes. For $8, you get a robust helping of herbed-up abalone broth double-boiled in a vast, glazed ceramic cauldron. When it comes to affordable abalone for the masses, Ah Lam is an institution. A word of warning: its located in a narrow kopitiam at a busy intersection, so dust and car fumes come as standard when dining here.Main courses $3-$78.

Its usually a good sign if the house wine listed is not Jacobs Creek, has a lively bouquet and is affordably priced: of Mags three house whites, St Claire is a refreshing New Zealand sauvignon blanc ($13/glass) with wafts of grapefruit and lemon a worthy representative for its worldly cellar of over 200 labels. Also notable is its evenly cooked main of ovenroasted lamb, served with a buttery, cheesetopped potato gratin. The starter of duck breast, smoked with tea leaves and coffee, is too small a portion to be entirely comforting, but the flavour was spot-on. The chocolate fondant cake is more like fudge wrapped in a crêpe fine for those ready to indulge in whatever oozes.Two-course set lunch $38++; dinner $48++.

While Pasta Incs affordable prices shouldnt go unnoticed, its the Little India location that caught our attention. Located in a shophouse along Jalan Besar, this Italian hideaways cosy booths are covered with white tablecloths, and the restaurant glows under the understated light of a chandelier. Lightly battered and thinly sliced, the Veal Scaloppine di Vitello is pan-fried with butter-sage and topped with Parma ham, all resting underneath a blanket of melted mozzarella. The classic fettuccine alla carbonara brings nothing new to the table, but the chopped pieces of bacon and onion and the creamy white wine sauce do not disappoint. Best part? The meal can be finished off with a mango lassi from down the street.Main courses $16-$28.

Heritage recently moved from its road-front location off Sixth Avenue to a dimly lit, black-and-white dining chamber in the touristy Copthorne Orchid hotel. While the suburban location may not appeal to the hip dinner crowd, the North Indian cuisine is first rate. The chicken makhani, boneless tandoori-baked chicken, is served in a dense tomato- and spice-accented sauce; and a rarely seen crab biryani, fluffy grains of basmati rice tossed with vegetables and crab pieces and served with a side condiment of raita (yoghurt dip) both grace the menus pages. Vegetarians can indulge in the simple yet profoundly flavoursome lentils in cumin seed-flecked thick gravy, or the refreshing chopped and spinach-coated paneer chunks. With the lure of generous servings, wallet-friendly price tag, graceful staff and a solid kitchen, it wont be long before discerning foodies sniff their way to our favourite North Indian restaurant of the moment.

To sin or not to sin? Eileen Tay and her devilishly delicious, sugar-filled creations, crafted in an out-of-sight pâtisserie off Holland Road, provide the answer. Essentially a café attached to her culinary workshop, you can watch the trained artisan at work, while downing a mug of hot Illy coffee and sampling the freshly made goodies. Youll be besotted by the delicately moist cupcakes ($3.50), like Lamour Rose, Rocky Mountain and the name-says-it-all Chocolate Overload. For seconds, try the almond croissants, morsel-sized cream puffs or zesty cheese scones. Transgressions dont end there; the French macarons ($2 each) in avant-garde flavours like lemon raspberry, passion jivara and oozing molten salty caramel will require a confessional or two.

A café in Balestiers hostel-central is an appropriate choice for students, especially when the establishment offers cups of strong Italian coffee (from $3.20). A fluffy foccaccia sandwich with plump home-made meatballs and a tropical fruit tea (made with bagged black tea, a tinge of passion-fruit syrup and very little sugar, $4.20) would do wonders for those under-nourished pupils. Caution: those looking to avoid the freshman 15 should pass on the greasy pub fare pre-battered fish and chips, deep-fried chicken wings and spongy thin-crust pizzas spell L-A-ZY although well admit, sometimes these are all you crave when cramming for that big exam. Main courses $8.90-$12.90.

Managed by the same guys who run Senso, La Villa offers terrific parking and alfresco seating with twinkling garden lights. While the bar is well stocked, its better to avoid flashy cocktails and stick to something simple our martini wasnt dry and there was nothing orgasmic about their Sex on the Beach. Even though the service isnt speedy, the friendly nature of the staff makes up for it.

The pool table, game machine and $5 beers attract a young crowd, but football fanatics of all ages will appreciate that Premier League games are being projected straight onto the wall and budget boozers with a soft spot for old-school hip hop will be happy with the tracks. Cement floor, retro stools and low leather couches provide a chill atmosphere, and while the flow may not quite be free, its damn cheap.Drink $5 draft beer.

Succulent selections at this Tex-Mex-themed chain include sizzling fresh fajitas and the one-bite-and-yourehooked Southwestern Eggrolls of smokedchicken, black beans, corn and jalapeño jack cheese, enveloped in a crispy tortilla. A surprise catch is the Southwest Cedar Plank Tilipia, a flavourful grilled fish fillet doused in cilantro, garlic, lime and home-made pico de gallo salsa, and served on a plank of cedar. The margaritas (six types) and topnotch service help compensate for the heavy bill.

Stacks of crates with displays of mock produce and a rustic, all-wood interior overhung with dangling light bulbs greet you upon entry creating an interior reminiscent of quaint Japanese eateries. Aobas menu offers an array of ramen in flavours of shio (salt), miso and shoyu (soya sauce), all basking in a broth perfumed with pork and chicken bones; our top pick goes to shoyu tontoro ramen served with slices of roasted pork cheek and a komi tamago (boiled soya flavoured egg). Although Aoba doesnt offer desserts, there are Western and Japanese starters worth checking out, including the baconstreaked Caesar salad and grilled shishamo (boneless fish).

Teochew eateries are a dime and a dozen in the Lion City but Ah Orh remains one that we will revisit at the drop of a hat. Its allure cant be attributed to the far-flung location on the ground floor of an HDB flat at Jalan Bukit Merah, although we admit that there is a certain charm to its vibrant receptioncum- kitchen decked out with canned food. The roaring wok churns out recipes that have been passed down over the years from its first anchor at Hong Lim Green in the 1950s, to its current venue in the heartlands. The ba bao cai (eight treasure vegetables), a mound of melt-in-the-mouth white cabbages and black moss bathing in a savoury brown broth, is a must, as is the oil-fluffed oyster omelette topped with generous morsels of the mollusc. Meanwhile the mussels tossed in a wok, with sprigs of Chinese celery and curry leaves in a piquant paste, are out of this world.

25-year-old Deyana Goh opened her 'shop' in March 2010, proudly selling hard-to-find books that she gets from suppliers overseas and her travel hunts. Ms. Goh sells from her living room, by appointment only.
Read our story on Gohd Books here.

The latest pretender to join the noodle ranks is this cosy ramen joint in the Paragon basement. Here, aninterior of dark brown wood, jazz soundtrack, compact menu and a brisk kitchen make mealtimes a soothing exercise in Japanese effi ciency. There are interesting sides like unagi chawanmushi and fried oysters, but the starring roles are dominated by ramen thats cooked Tokyo-, Sapporo-, Kyushu-, and Kyushu Tonkatsu-style. This translates into stock thats miso-based, pork-fl avoured, or steeped in chicken for 11 hours; meanwhile springy noodles are paired with a variety of toppings ranging from tonkatsu pork and hard-boiled eggs to charred and crushed garlic. Tip: order the mini versions so you can try more dishes.Daven WuMain courses $8.90-$15.90.

If youd describe yourself as having champagne taste on a beer-bottle budget, then this tiny drinking hole is the place for you. In keeping with this citys growing trend for bottle shops, here youll find sheltered outdoor timber seating for up to 24, delightful if somewhat slow service, glasses of red and white for $8 and bottles for well under $30. But the hands-down, uncontested, very best deal to be had here is a 200ml bottle of sparkling wine for $8.80 or $5.28 on special. And the icing on the cake? Denise will let you order fries or a burger from Bergs, so you can line that tummy and continue to quaff the night away.

entry.name: En Japanese Dining Bar @ Bukit Timah

version.name: En Japanese Dining Bar @ Bukit Timah

content.description: If you are one of those who sniffs at all-you-can-eat buffets, do yourself a favour and make a trip down to En Japanese youll emerge a reformed character. The à la carte dishes are cooked with finesse, and several are presented in exquisite stoneware. In addition to the usual suspects of sashimi, sushi, noodles and tempura, for a fixed price of $48++, you get the option to indulge in a $10 top-up for a free-flow of Grade 9 Australian Wagyu beef, served either shabu shabu- or sukiyaki-style. A few other top picks include a refreshing pork salad in sesame dressing, piquant kimchi fried rice and heavenly soft-shell crab maki.Costs: $58++ per head

Bistro Senso straddles that uncomfortable spot between café and fast-food joint. Art-deco chandeliers hang over black-and-white tiling, which sounds charming but feels forced. The pizzas are definitely your best bet on these laminated menus, and I have to admit the prosciutto pizza was delicious, though the thin crust was so soft that it quickly warped into an oozing mess. Oh, and if your eyes widen at the 8-foot pizzas for $8.90 option, they mean 8 inches. All said, Bistro Senso is a viable option if youve been dragged to the Singapore Flyer by overly enthusiastic, out-of-town relatives; its prices are a snip compared to most other restaurants in the area. Except, of course, Pizza Hut.

If a sundowner on Sentosas Tanjong Beach is what youre after, and youre cool with cocktails served up in plastic cups by a grungy and bare-chested (actually, scrap that, nearly nude) barman/DJ, then this is the spot for you. Lo & Beholds latest drinking hole, The Shack, is a timber-covered shipping container-turned-bar, with a covered pergola, one bench seat and a few old oil barrels for tables. The bar itself is simple and small. The venue is just temporary, holding the place while Lo & Behold builds Sentosas next big restaurant- cum-bar behind it, right on KM8s gravesite. If youre hungry, theres a packet of crisps or two to choose from, and dont forget to show up sporting flip-flops and swimmers. Come prepared with low expectations and youll be pleasantly surprised.

UrbanWrite is chockfull of notebooks, paper and pens decked out in a variety of colours and arty designs. You'll also get craft, gift items and kitschy products imported from Japan, Korea, Taiwan, USA, UK and Europe.

Dont let the name mislead you into thinking theres wild game to be hunted. Instead, what youll find is a laidback, alfresco spot located smack bang in the city. Surrounded by lush greenery and water fountains that never fail to amuse, the bar offers a standard selection of martinis, housepours, liquors, and more than 30 types of wines all day. If youre a beer guzzler, Heineken and Erdinger Weiss are available on tap, along with a wide range of bottled beers.
Conveniently located near the Jurong East MRT interchange and bus interchange, IMM houses retail space, warehouse and office space spread within it 5-storey compund.

Dont be put off by the school-canteen vibe,or by the fact that the serving counter is so tiny. The nosh is excellent and incredibly good value. Unless youre Indian, the names of the dishes will probably mean nothing to you, but just about everything deserves a second helping including the sambal fish,a densely flavoured chicken curry, creamy dahl, and a wonderfully aromatic butter chicken. Wash it all down with masala teaor lime juice.
Golden Village Tampines has 8 screens and 3D Digital halls.

This is a multi-storey 344-seater theatre with digital audio and 2D/3D projection systems where movies are flashed onto a five-storey high screen. Most titles screen for several months. Please check the website for times and prices.

This Italian trattoria is already a hit with the neighbourhood set at Serangoon Garden. Chef-owner Salvatore Buono keeps things simple with well-executed dishes like carpaccio, portobello mushrooms in herbflecked cream, and linguine al cartoccio heavy loops of al dente pasta with fat mussels, baby langoustines and squid rings. Try the Buono, a slab of thin-crusted pizza that could feed two its base slathered with a light cream sauce and sprinkled with arugula and chunks of homemade sausages.Read our review of Buono here.

Lined with timber decking, Travertinemarble and day-bed seating along theedges, Superfamous almost seems like achic Sydney bolthole. This is especiallythe case in the evenings when, with thetwinkling lights of the Raffl es Placeskyscrapers serving as a backdrop, thecanopied alfresco space turns into a barand serves up tipples like $10 champagneand martinis.

Though it is touted as the worlds first museum devoted to the rareTibetan gemstone Dzi, the best part of this museum is its extensive section on the history and culture of Tibet, showcasing more than a thousand artefacts including giant prayer wheels, clay tablets, bronze amulets, paintings and sculptures. The museums shop is also worth a browse, for interesting Tibetan Buddhist historical relics, authenticTibetan handicrafts and rough gemstones.

entry.name: Nei Xue Tang - A Buddhist Art Museum

version.name: Nei Xue Tang - A Buddhist Art Museum

content.description: Spread over three floors of a four-storey conservation building whichis an attraction on its own right, Singapores first house museum is home to more than a thousand Buddhist artifacts from China, India, Tibet, Japan, Thailand, Cambodia and Afghanistan. Other exhibits include a wide selection of gold, silver, bronze, jade and crystal Buddhist amulets and talismans, as well as artworks by acclaimed Singapore artist Tan Swie Hian.
Just-opened space specialising in Filipinoart offering a wide spectrum of notableartists including Jose Joya, Arturo Luz, OnibOlmedo, Juvenal Sanso and Tam Austria.

Recently relocated, this gallery aims to create exposure for otherwise inaccessible art and new art forms and talents. Drawing froma stable of international names, it features paintings, sculpture, photography, digital art and sculptures. Asian art and ethnic textiles are predominantly exhibited.
This gallery consistsmainly of works by South Indiancomtemporary artists.

The SG Private Banking gallery houses itself in the Alliance Française, regularly exhibiting a wide range of international art and collaborating with galleries overseas, including Lotus Gallery from Vietnam.Alternatively, join Singapore's Francophile cineastes for Ciné Club every Tuesday evening at 8pm for an ongoing series of French movies both old and new.

Clean white walls make an excellentblank canvas for the numerous ceramicvases, Zen-type lamps, plush cushions and artwork sold inside. And while theeclectic stock of items is sourced fromThailand, Vietnam and Europe, HaierLivings uniquely shaped lamps andsofas are designed by a group of in-housedesigners who can make-to-orderaccording to your needs

content.openingtimes: Mondays to Fridays: 11.30am to midnight, Saturdays: 4pm to midnight, Sundays: Closed

content.description: Play retains much of the layout of the former Happy, although theyve trashed up the décor a lot more in a good way. The graffiti on the walls gives the place a slightly underground feel, and the deep funk house and cheerful pop remixes are a guaranteed crowd-pleaser. If you enjoy the sight of muscle-bound lads bouncing around gleefully, this is your bag, baby.Sat (after 11pm): $15, includes one drink.

Happy Hours: 5 pm to 9 pm - everyday
 Crazy Hours: 5pm to 9 pm (one for one) by glasses
content.openingtimes: Mondays to Thursdays: 5pm to 1am, Fridays: 5pm to 1am, Saturdays: 12pm to 2am, Sundays: 12pm to 1am

content.description:
Boat Quay is popular with tourists and city-boys alike from the nearby banks and trading offices. Harry's branch here is very much a traditional pub on the ground floor with live bands on many nights. Upstairs is a much smarter lounge area.Happy hour from 11am to 9pm everyday. 
Crazy Hour (not applicable on public holidays) Mon - Fri 5-7pm.
content.openingtimes: Mon-Thurs: 11am to 1am, Fri & Sat: 11am to 2am, Sun: 11am to 1am

content.description: A hidden gem of a live music venue behind The Substation. Timbre is open air, but covered, and features live music every night.Timbre have recently expanded to Timbre @ The Arts House opposite Boat Quay.

This watering hole is a hit with the boys for its double-shot drinks at no extra charge. Yes, double shots! Slow weekday nights see people chilling on the day beds in the (oddly) green-lit courtyard, while on weekends the joint is jam-packed, standingroom only. The dance tracks and kick-ass Long Island Teas are guaranteed to keep you happy and buzzing all night.

For a taste of the magic isle right here in Singapore, cross a wooden bridge into a luxuriant garden. Welcome to Villa Bali, the creation of owner-designers Robin Greatbatch and Andrew Seow, who set out to re-create their experiences in Indonesia with this bar, part of the larger Little Bali lifestyle resort. Filled with daybeds and divans, and surrounded by wild plants and ponds, its an idyllic drinking spot in the heart of Gillman Village. Service is efficient, but unobtrusive, allowing you to kick back and chill out undisturbed. The usual bar stock dominates, but there are also Balinese wines that go well with the Indian tapas.

The Japanese barmen at Bar 84 are hot, polite and pour a mean dram, with the bonus of putting on a nightly magic show. Take note, theres a $10 cover charge, but its a small price to pay for access to 300 bottles of whisky.

Billed as a sanctuary for fools and acanvas for the budding artist, Loof is an eccentric rooftop bar. A playful contrast toits neighbour, the Raffles Hotel, it attracts an easy-going, eclectic crowd (its particularly popular with media types). Punters relax on leather loungers and the deck is lit by a huge electric billboard. Pray for rain when the heavens open, drinks are two for the price of one.
A bohostyle café-cum-lounge that sees guest DJ gigs by the likes of funk and soul collective PushinOn. Its quirky, vibrant and altogether not quite Singaporean.

Packed to the rafters on weekends with lithe and youthful Chinese boys, this M-pop club is filled with people dancing to the techno beats. Expect stares if you are anything but male and Oriental-looking. KTV nights on week days ensure only warbler wannabes show up.
content.openingtimes: KTV nights Mon-Thu 8pm-3am; Disco nights Fri11pm-3am, Sat 11pm-4am.

content.description: Known for its rotating nights of rock, punk and metal, Gashaus is launching a new DJ night as well, Heart of Darkness (Wednesdays).Gashaus was included in our recent One Night Stand feature.

Club Momo heaves with a horny, nubile, up-for-anything crowd. Private dance platforms in the Boudoir, live bands in Momo Live, pool tables and games consoles in the Sports Bar, and the occasional pole-dancing performance vie for your attention. The look is Moroccan all colourful cushions and draped tents and the place is packed to the rafters on ladies, retro and R&B nights. Its a notorious hangout for Chinese working-class party-goers with a penchant for flashing their stash of cash.

Two parts bookshop, one part music store, this cosy hideout has every base covered when it comes to homegrown talent. Give music CDs by local artists like Electrico, Dick Lee and Tanya Chua a listen, or walk down memory lane while your fingers flip through the pages of books like Rickshaw Coolie: A Peoples History of Singapore (1880-1940) by James Francis Warren.

Its beloved of bikers and pool players, but the jurys still out on BLooiEs. On our first visit to their Bukit Timah outpost we faced a cold reception in every sense. Deafening rock, air-con so preposterously high it felt like winter in Montreal, brusque service (Here. Sign it. With the pen, ordered a waitress) and dire food (an undercooked steak, with carrots so hard they almost broke my fork). On returning, warmth was all around: soft pop music, the wait-staff all smiles and charm, and a perfectly decent Cajun chicken burger. Pick your night to avoid the Roadhouse blues, and youll find an enticing menu of high-cholesterol treats in a cosy, roadside-diner ambience: spacious surrounds, moose head and rugby shirts on the wall, well-stocked brickwork bar, TV screens and leafy, out-of-town location. A beery, blokeish bonhomie prevails, so dont take a date unless youre a serious ah beng. Botak Jones does this stuff much cheaper, too, but BLooiEs shades it for style and comfort.
content.openingtimes: Sun-Thu 11am-midnight; Fri, Sat and holiday eve 11am-1am.

content.description: Its safe to say that when Sticky Rice opened, it raised the glamour quotient of the residential suburb of Serangoon Gardens. The Thai restaurant has been designed to within an inch of its life, complete with smoky mirrors and dramatic splashes of blood-red lacquered panels. The set lunches (under $10) are a bargain. On weekends, the place buzzes as the owners fashionista friends tuck into crispy soft-shelled crabs served with a thick shower of pomelo pearls and translucent chopped garlic, and sweet mango desserts.Sticky Rice was featured in our recent Comfort Food - Basic Instincts - Where to Eat feature.

Nothing beats a hot dog and soda after a long day spent hunting for the perfect garbage can grab them at the Ikea food stand after checking out. Also: dont miss the Swedish meatballs for sale, both hot and frozen. A kilogram of frozen balls goes for $18 some might call that overpriced, but we say those delicious little buggers are priceless. Meatballs with pasta sauce, meatballs on toast, meatballs in the morning mmmm.

This lovely little restaurant is alittle tricky to fi nd, as its tuckedbehind the hawker stalls lining Smith Street,but its worth the hunt. Nepalese food in someways is similar to Indian (and the restaurant sellsthat cuisine as well), with pungent spices andfl avourful rice. For vegetarians, the palungo kosaag is a knockout: spinach sauted with cuminseeds ($6.50). Carnivorous types should try thepro kukhura ko masu, which is a Nepalese chillichicken dish. Or go for the momo ($8), whichlooks like a Nepalese version of fried Chinesedumplings, fi lled with minced meat and veggies.Its listed as an appetiser, but one serving canreally fi ll you up.

Opened by Werner Hochbaumin 1988, this favourite in the Eastis now run by the second generation of hisGerman-Singaporean family. And though someof the dishes are just shy of $20, you can chowon delicious grilled bratwurst and potato saladfor $8 or go right for the good stuff: a rangeof German beers is just $7.95 for 330ml.

Wiener Kaffeehaus has recently relocated, see here for more details.
To enter this little shophouse is to step into another world lined with romantic Art Nouveau timber panelling, wall lamps, marble-topped tables and sparkling glints of Klimt artwork, its old Vienna come to life and transplanted to the tropics. The fiaker gulasch a large serving of tender beef cuts, fried egg, sausage and a huge bread dumpling is terrific. Or just come for the house-ground coffee, a slice of the dense, chocolately Sachertorte and daily newspapers from around the world.

The interior decoration, haloed with fluorescentlight, is decidedly spartan and uninviting,but who cares, because the food here isfantastic. Peranakan owner and chef HelenSugiano Sim hails from Indonesia and so hermenu is overlaid with an additional layer ofintense flavour. Everything from the buahkeluak to the sambal kangkong and golden,coconut-infused chicken curry is worthy ofmultiple helpings. Watch out for the layeredkueh lapis which is flown in from Sims auntskitchen in Indonesia. Its sinfully good.

entry.name: Brown Sugar Caf - HAS MOVED LOCATION WATCH THIS SPACE

version.name: Brown Sugar Caf - HAS MOVED LOCATION WATCH THIS SPACE

content.description: Bistro cafe of modern classics.

It helps to know that this somewhat nondescript hawker stall is no longer at Newton Circus, but such is the cache of the name that its travelled all the way to its new digs in Serangoon Gardens. Diehard fans swear by the intense smokiness of the inky char kway teow, the fat strands silky with black sauce and studded with the sharp undertow of cockles.

The period bungalow could do with a little renovation the floorboards tremble as the waitresses pass and the lighting is dreadful but Hong Kongtrained owner and chef Ang Song Kangs nostalgic Cantonese fare is a treat. Any meal should include the silky tofu served in a sauce of dried scallops and shiitake mushrooms; an addictively crisp brinjal crowned with pork floss; and round discs of lotus root fried with black pepper. Portions come in the usual three options, but the smallest is enough to feed three to four comfortably. We hear the PMs wife has been spotted here.

Pakistani-born and ex-New Yorker Samia Ahad has been charming locals for years with her pan-Asian cooking. Dressed in a trademark starched white shirt, she effortlessly skates through a variety of subcontinental and South-East Asian cuisines, from golden Iranian pilafs and lamb kebabs to fresh Vietnamese rice-paper rolls; from melt-in-themouth garlic naans to saffron-scented snapper. Try to snag a table by the windows withviews of the Singapore River.Click for a full list of venues at Clarke Quay.

entry.name: shots. a caf on ann siang hill.

version.name: shots. a caf on ann siang hill.

content.description: A photo gallery-cum-café offering with a location and staff that are beyond reproac. Sit down, linger, and enjoy the reading material comprising nothing but photographic magazines.

The cappuccino at Dimbulahs banker-magnet branch holds its own with the very best in town: a deep, dark, seductively sweet Queensland arabica brew that, in their words, makes a kickass coffee beyond compare
Though this is a select bean retailer first and tasting spot second, its owners has gone to some lengths to generate a seriously comfy ambience at Papas oddly located bolthole.
content.openingtimes: Tue-Fri 9am-7.30pm; Sat 9am-9pm; Sun, public holidays 9am-7.30pm. Closed for roasting on Mondays.

content.description: Whether youre sprawling on a sofa, perching on a pouffe, plugged in to their Wi-Fi or perusing their well-stocked library with a frothy cappu gem, an appointment with the Dr amounts to the total coffee experience.
